Manx: CAB. I.
English: Matthew Chapter 1

Manx: 1 Lioar Sheeloghe Yeesey Creest, Mac Ghavid, Mac Abraham.
English: 1 The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham.

Manx: 2 Hooar Abraham Isaac, as hooar Isaac Jacob, as hooar Jacob Judas as e vraaraghyn.
English: 2 Abraham begat Isaac; and Isaac begat Jacob; and Jacob begat Judas and his brethren;

Manx: 3 As hooar Judas Phares as Zarah rish Thamar, as hooar Phares Esrom, as hooar Esrom Aram.
English: 3 And Judas begat Phares and Zara of Thamar; and Phares begat Esrom; and Esrom begat Aram;

Manx: 4 As hooar Aram Aminadab, as hooar Aminadab Naasson, as hooar Naasson Salmon.
English: 4 And Aram begat Aminadab; and Aminadab begat Naasson; and Naasson begat Salmon;

Manx: 5 As hooar Salmon Booz rish Rachab, as hooar Booz Obed rish Ruth, as hooar Obed Jesse.
English: 5 And Salmon begat Booz of Rachab; and Booz begat Obed of Ruth; and Obed begat Jesse;

Manx: 6 As hooar Jesse David yn Ree, as hooar David yn Ree Solomon ree-ish v’er ny ve Ben Urias.
English: 6 And Jesse begat David the king; and David the king begat Solomon of her that had been the wife of Urias;

Manx: 7 As hooar Solomon Roboam, as hooar Roboam Abia, as hooar Abia Asa.
English: 7 And Solomon begat Roboam; and Roboam begat Abia; and Abia begat Asa;

Manx: 8 As hooar Asa Josaphat, as hooar Josaphat Joram, as hooar Joram Ozias.
English: 8 And Asa begat Josaphat; and Josaphat begat Joram; and Joram begat Ozias;

Manx: 9 As hooar Ozias Joatham, as hooar Joatham Achaz, as hooar Achaz Ezekias.
English: 9 And Ozias begat Joatham; and Joatham begat Achaz; and Achaz begat Ezekias;

Manx: 10 As hooar Ezekias Manasses, as hooar Manasses Amon, as hooar Amon Josias.
English: 10 And Ezekias begat Manasses; and Manasses begat Amon; and Amon begat Josias;

Manx: 11 As hooar Josias Jechonias as e vraaraghyn, my-geart y tra va’d goit ersooyl nyn gappeeyn gys Babylon.
English: 11 And Josias begat Jechonias and his brethren, about the time they were carried away to Babylon:

Manx: 12 As ayns earish yn chappeeys ayns Babylon, hooar Jechonias Salathiel, as hooar Salathiel Zorobabel.
English: 12 And after they were brought to Babylon, Jechonias begat Salathiel; and Salathiel begat Zorobabel;

Manx: 13 As hooar Zorobabel Abiud, as hooar Abiud Eliakim, as hooar Eliakim Azor.
English: 13 And Zorobabel begat Abiud; and Abiud begat Eliakim; and Eliakim begat Azor;

Manx: 14 As hooar Azor Sadoc, as hooar Sadoc Achim, as hooar Achim Eliud.
English: 14 And Azor begat Sadoc; and Sadoc begat Achim; and Achim begat Eliud;

Manx: 15 As hooar Eliud Eleazar, as hooar Eleazar Matthan, as hooar Matthan Jacob.
English: 15 And Eliud begat Eleazar; and Eleazar begat Matthan; and Matthan begat Jacob;

Manx: 16 As hooar Jacob Joseph dooinney-poost Moirrey, jee ruggyr Yeesey, ta enmyssit Creest.
English: 16 And Jacob begat Joseph the husband of Mary, of whom was born Jesus, who is called Christ.

Manx: 17 Myr shen ta ooilley ny Sheeloghyn veih Abraham gys David, kiare Sheeloghyn jeig; as veih David derrey’n chappeeys ayns Babylon, kiare Sheeloghyn jeig; as veih’n chappeeys ayns Babylon derrey Creest, kiare Sheeloghyn jeig.
English: 17 So all the generations from Abraham to David are fourteen generations; and from David until the carrying away into Babylon are fourteen generations; and from the carrying away into Babylon unto Christ are fourteen generations.

Manx: 18 ¶ Nish va cheet er y teihl Yeesey Creest er yn aght shoh: Erreish da e Voir Moirrey ve poost rish Joseph, roish my daink ad dy vaghey cooidjagh, va liannoo er ny gheddyn dy ve aynjee, jeh’n Spyrryd Noo.
English: 18 Now the birth of Jesus Christ was on this wise: When as his mother Mary was espoused to Joseph, before they came together, she was found with child of the Holy Ghost.

Manx: 19 As va Joseph e Sheshey ny ghooinney Cairagh, as liorish dy row e niau-vooiaght yn narey eck y insh magh, ghow e ayns laue Screwnyn-scarree chur jee gy follit.
English: 19 Then Joseph her husband, being a just man, and not willing to make her a publick example, was minded to put her away privily.

Manx: 20 Agh choud as va ny reddyn shoh ayns e smooinaghtyn, cur-my-ner haink Ainle y Chiarn huggey ayns ashlish, gra, Yoseph Vac Ghavid, ny gow aggle Moirrey yn Ven ayd y ghoal, son shen t’er ny ye'ntyn aynjee, te jeh’n Spyrryd Noo.
English: 20 But while he thought on these things, behold, the angel of the Lord appeared unto him in a dream, saying, Joseph, thou son of David, fear not to take unto thee Mary thy wife: for that which is conceived in her is of the Holy Ghost.

Manx: 21 As ver ee Mac son y teihl, as enmys-ee oo yn ennym echey Yeesey; son Sauee e e phobble veih nyn beccaghyn.
English: 21 And she shall bring forth a son, and thou shalt call his name JESUS: for he shall save his people from their sins.

Manx: 22 (Nish va ooilley shoh jeant, dy voddagh shen ve cooilleenit va’n Chiarn er loart liorish y Phadeyr, gra,
English: 22 Now all this was done, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken of the Lord by the prophet, saying,

Manx: 23 Cur-my-ner bee Liannoo ec Moidyn, as ver ee Mac son y teihl, as nee ad e y enmys Emmanuel, ta shen dy ghra, Jee marin)
English: 23 Behold, a virgin shall be with child, and shall bring forth a son, and they shall call his name Emmanuel, which being interpreted is, God with us.

Manx: 24 Tra va Joseph eisht er nirree veih cadley, ren e myr va Ainle y Chiarn er noardagh da, as ghow e thie e Ven.
English: 24 Then Joseph being raised from sleep did as the angel of the Lord had bidden him, and took unto him his wife:

Manx: 25 As cha row veg echey dy yianoo ree, derrey hug ee e chied Mac son y teihl, as denmys e yn Ennym echey Yeesey.
English: 25 And knew her not till she had brought forth her firstborn son: and he called his name JESUS.

Manx: CAB. II
English: Matthew Chapter 2

Manx: 1 Nish tra va Yeesey er ny ve Ruggit ayns Bethlehem, dy Yudea, ayns laghyn Ree Herod, cur-my-ner haink deney creeney veih’n Shar gys Jerusalem,
English: 1 Now when Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judaea in the days of Herod the king, behold, there came wise men from the east to Jerusalem,

Manx: 2 Gra, Cre vel Ree ny Hewnyn t’er jeet er y teihl? Son honnick shin y Rollage echey ayns y Shar, as ta shin er jeet dy chur ooashley da.
English: 2 Saying, Where is he that is born King of the Jews? for we have seen his star in the east, and are come to worship him.

Manx: 3 Tra cheayl Ree Herod shoh, ve seaghnit as ooilley Jerusalem marish.
English: 3 When Herod the king had heard these things, he was troubled, and all Jerusalem with him.

Manx: 4 As tra ve er jaglym cooidjagh, ooilley ny ard-saggyrtyn as scruderyn y pobble, denee e jeu, cre’n raad va Creest dy heet er y teihl.
English: 4 And when he had gathered all the chief priests and scribes of the people together, he demanded of them where Christ should be born.

Manx: 5 As doort adsyn rish, Ayns Bethlehem dy Yudea: Son shoh myr te scruit liorish y Phadeyr;
English: 5 And they said unto him, In Bethlehem of Judaea: for thus it is written by the prophet,

Manx: 6 As uss Bethlehem ayns talloo Yuda, cha nee oo sloo ta mastey Prinsyn Yudah: Son assyds hig Kianoort nee reill my phobble Israel.
English: 6 And thou Bethlehem, in the land of Juda, art not the least among the princes of Juda: for out of thee shall come a Governor, that shall rule my people Israel.

Manx: 7 Eisht hug Herod fys gy follit er ny deney creeney, as, denee e jeu dy imneagh, cre’n tra va’n Rollage er ny akin.
English: 7 Then Herod, when he had privily called the wise men, enquired of them diligently what time the star appeared.

Manx: 8 As hug e ad gys Bethlehem, gra, immee-jee, as shir-jee magh dy kiaralagh son y liannoo aeg, as tra vees shiu er gheddyn e, tar-jee lesh fys hyms, dy voddyms myrgeddyn cheet as ooashley chur da.
English: 8 And he sent them to Bethlehem, and said, Go and search diligently for the young child; and when ye have found him, bring me word again, that I may come and worship him also.

Manx: 9 Tra va’n Ree erreish loart, jimmee ad rumboo, as cur-my-ner, hie yn Rollage honnick ad ayns y Shar, roue, derrey haink ee as hass ee harrish yn ynnyd, raad va’n liannoo.
English: 9 When they had heard the king, they departed; and, lo, the star, which they saw in the east, went before them, till it came and stood over where the young child was.

Manx: 10 Tra honnick ad y Rollage va’d lieent lesh boggey er-skyn towse.
English: 10 When they saw the star, they rejoiced with exceeding great joy.

Manx: 11 ¶ As tra va’d er jeet stiagh ayns y thie, honnick ad y liannoo aeg marish Moirrey e Voir, as huitt ad sheese as hug ad ooashley da; as tra va’d er vosley ny tashtaghyn oc, heb ad da giootyn, aer, as frankincense as myrrh.
English: 11 And when they were come into the house, they saw the young child with Mary his mother, and fell down, and worshipped him: and when they had opened their treasures, they presented unto him gifts; gold, and frankincense, and myrrh.

Manx: 12 As fakin dy row Jee er chur roue ayns ashlish, nagh row ad dy hyndaa gys Herod, jimmee ad gys nyn jeer hene raad elley.
English: 12 And being warned of God in a dream that they should not return to Herod, they departed into their own country another way.

Manx: 13 As tra va’d er gholl roue, haink Ainle y Chiarn gys Joseph ayns ashlish, gra, irree as gow yn Liannoo aeg as e voir, as gow er-chea gys Egypt, as furree ayns shen, derrey verryms liam fys hood: Son shirree Herod y liannoo dy stroie e.
English: 13 And when they were departed, behold, the angel of the Lord appeareth to Joseph in a dream, saying, Arise, and take the young child and his mother, and flee into Egypt, and be thou there until I bring thee word: for Herod will seek the young child to destroy him.

Manx: 14 Tra ve er nirree, ghow e yn liannoo as e voir ayns yn uy, as hie e roish gys Egypt.
English: 14 When he arose, he took the young child and his mother by night, and departed into Egypt:

Manx: 15 As ve ayns shen, derrey baase Herod: dy voddagh shen ve cooilleenit va’n Chiarn er loart liorish y Phadeyr, gra, Magh as Egypt deie mee er my Vac.
English: 15 And was there until the death of Herod: that it might be fulfilled which was spoken of the Lord by the prophet, saying, Out of Egypt have I called my son.

Manx: 16 ¶ Tra honnick Herod eisht, dy row e mollit liorish ny deney creeney, ve feer jymmoosagh, as hug e magh sarey, as var e ooilley yn chloan v’ayns Bethlehem, as ayns ooilley ny ardjyn shen, veih daa vleïn dy eash as fo, cordail rish yn earish ve dy imneagh er vriaght jeh ny deney creeney.
English: 16 Then Herod, when he saw that he was mocked of the wise men, was exceeding wroth, and sent forth, and slew all the children that were in Bethlehem, and in all the coasts thereof, from two years old and under, according to the time which he had diligently enquired of the wise men.

Manx: 17 Shen y tra va cooilleenit ny va loarit liorish Jeremy yn phadeyr gra,
English: 17 Then was fulfilled that which was spoken by Jeremy the prophet, saying,

Manx: 18 Ayns Rama va coraa er y chlashtyn, ullaghey as keaney as dobberan moar, Rachel keaney son e cloan, as gobbal dy ve er ny gerjaghey, er-yn-oyr nagh row ad er-mayrn.
English: 18 In Rama was there a voice heard, lamentation, and weeping, and great mourning, Rachel weeping for her children, and would not be comforted, because they are not.

Manx: 19 ¶ Agh tra va Herod marroo, cur-my-ner haink Ainle y Chiarn ayns ashlish gys Joseph ayns Egypt,
English: 19 But when Herod was dead, behold, an angel of the Lord appeareth in a dream to Joseph in Egypt,

Manx: 20 Gra, irree as gow yn liannoo as e voir, as gow gys talloo Israel, son tar adsyn marroo va shirrey bioys y liannoo.
English: 20 Saying, Arise, and take the young child and his mother, and go into the land of Israel: for they are dead which sought the young child's life.

Manx: 21 As dirree e, as ghow e yn liannoo as e Voir, as haink e gys talloo Israel.
English: 21 And he arose, and took the young child and his mother, and came into the land of Israel.

Manx: 22 Agh tra cheayl e, dy nee Archelaus va reil ayns Judea ayns ynnyd e ayr Herod, va aggle er dy gholl ayns shen, agh hyndaa e, myr va Jee er chur roish ayns ashlish, gys Ardjyn Galilee.
English: 22 But when he heard that Archelaus did reign in Judaea in the room of his father Herod, he was afraid to go thither: notwithstanding, being warned of God in a dream, he turned aside into the parts of Galilee:

Manx: 23 As haink e as ren e vaghey ayns ard-valley enmyssit Nazareth, dy voddagh ny va loarit liorish ny Phaderyn ve cooilleenit, Bee e enmyssit ny Nazarene.
English: 23 And he came and dwelt in a city called Nazareth: that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophets, He shall be called a Nazarene.

Manx: CAB. III.
English: Matthew Chapter 3

Manx: 1 Ayns ny laghyn shen haink Ean Bashtey, preacheil ayns faasagh Judea,
English: 1 In those days came John the Baptist, preaching in the wilderness of Judaea,

Manx: 2 As gra, gow-jee arrys: Son ta Reeriaght Yee er-gerrey.
English: 2 And saying, Repent ye: for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.

Manx: 3 Son shoh e va loarit jeh, liorish y Phadeyr Esaias, gra, Coraa fer gemagh ayns yn aasagh, Jean-jee aarloo raad y Chiarn, jean-jee ny cassanyn echey kiart.
English: 3 For this is he that was spoken of by the prophet Esaias, saying, The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make his paths straight.

Manx: 4 As va ec Ean keddyn coamrey dy chlooie chamel, as cryss liare mish ny meeghyn echey; as va e veaghey locustyn as mill feie.
English: 4 And the same John had his raiment of camel's hair, and a leathern girdle about his loins; and his meat was locusts and wild honey.

Manx: 5 Eisht hie magh huggey Jerusalem as ooilley Judea, as ooilley’n cheer my-geart Jordan,
English: 5 Then went out to him Jerusalem, and all Judaea, and all the region round about Jordan,

Manx: 6 As va’d er nyn mashtey liorish ayns Jordan, goall rish nyn beccaghyn.
English: 6 And were baptized of him in Jordan, confessing their sins.

Manx: 7 ¶ Agh tra honnick e ymmodee jeh ny Phariseyn as ny Sadduceyn cheet gys e vashtey, doort e roo, O heeloghe dy ard-nieughyn, quoi t’er chur raue div, dy hea veih’n chorree ta ry heet?
English: 7 But when he saw many of the Pharisees and Sadducees come to his baptism, he said unto them, O generation of vipers, who hath warned you to flee from the wrath to come?

Manx: 8 Ymmyrk-jee magh er-y-fa shen mess cooie jeh arrys.
English: 8 Bring forth therefore fruits meet for repentance:

Manx: 9 As ny smooinee-jee dy ghra cheu-stie jiu hene, Ta Abraham ain son nyn ayr: son ta mee gra riu, dy vel Jee able jeh ny claghyn shoh, cloan y hroggal seose da Abraham.
English: 9 And think not to say within yourselves, We have Abraham to ourfather: for I say unto you, that God is able of these stones to raise up children unto Abraham.

Manx: 10 As nish myrgeddyn ta’n teigh er ny choyrt gys fraue ny miljyn: shen-y-fa ta dy chooilley villey nagh vel gymmyrkey magh mess mie, dy ve giarit sheese as tilgit ayns yn aile.
English: 10 And now also the axe is laid unto the root of the trees: therefore every tree which bringeth not forth good fruit is hewn down, and cast into the fire.

Manx: 11 Ta mish dy jarroo dyn mashtey shiu lesh ushtey gys arrys; agh ta eshyn ta cheet my yei, ny spooaral ny mish, ny Braagyn echey cha vel mee feeu dy ymmyrkey: Bashtee eshyn shiu lesh y spyrryd Noo as lesh aile.
English: 11 I indeed baptize you with water unto repentance: but he that cometh after me is mightier than I, whose shoes I am not worthy to bear: he shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost, and with fire:

Manx: 12 Ta’n cleayst echey ayns e laue, as nee e dy bollagh e laare-arroo y ghlenney, as gowee e e churnaght stiagh ayns y thie-tashtee, agh loshtee e yn choau lesh aile nagh vod v’er ny vooghey.
English: 12 Whose fan is in his hand, and he will throughly purge his floor, and gather his wheat into the garner; but he will burn up the chaff with unquenchable fire.

Manx: 13 ¶ Eisht haink Yeesey veih Galilee gys Jordan gys Ean, dy ve er ny vashtey liorish.
English: 13 Then cometh Jesus from Galilee to Jordan unto John, to be baptized of him.

Manx: 14 Agh loar Ean noi, gra, Ta feme ayms er ve bashtit liorts, as vel uss er jeet hyms?
English: 14 But John forbad him, saying, I have need to be baptized of thee, and comest thou to me?

Manx: 15 Dreggyr Yeesey, as doort e rish, Cur raad dou nish: son shoh myr te cooie dooin dy chooilley chairys y chooilleeney. Eishtagh lig e da.
English: 15 And Jesus answering said unto him, Suffer it to be so now: for thus it becometh us to fulfil all righteousness. Then he suffered him.

Manx: 16 As hie Yeesey, tra ve’r ny vashtey, seose chelleeragh ass yn ushtey: as cur-my-ner va ny Niaughyn er nyn vosley er e skyn, as honnick e spyrryd Yee cheet neose goll rish calmane, as soie er.
English: 16 And Jesus, when he was baptized, went up straightway out of the water: and, lo, the heavens were opened unto him, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove, and lighting upon him:

Manx: 17 As cur-my-ner, coraa veih Niau, gra, Shoh my Vac graihagh, jeh ta mee dy moar soiaghey.
English: 17 And lo a voice from heaven, saying, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.

Manx: CAB. IV.
English: Matthew Chapter 4

Manx: 1 Eisht va Yeesey er ny leedeil liorish spyrryd Yee gys yn aasagh, dy ve’r ny violagh liorish y drogh spyrryd.
English: 1 Then was Jesus led up of the Spirit into the wilderness to be tempted of the devil.

Manx: 2 As tra ve er drostey da-eed laa as da-eed uy, ve ny lurg shen accryssagh.
English: 2 And when he had fasted forty days and forty nights, he was afterward an hungred.

Manx: 3 As haink y Miolyder huggey, gra, My she Mac Yee oo, cur sarey da ny claghyn shoh, dy ve jeant nyn arran.
English: 3 And when the tempter came to him, he said, If thou be the Son of God, command that these stones be made bread.

Manx: 4 Agh dreggyr eshyn, gra; Te scruit, Cha nee er arran ny lomarcan nee dooinney beaghey, agh liorish cre-erbee ta cheet magh ass beeal Yee.
English: 4 But he answered and said, It is written, Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God.

Manx: 5 Eisht hug y drogh spyrryd lesh e gys yn ard-valley casherick, as hoie e e, er eer-vullagh y chiamble,
English: 5 Then the devil taketh him up into the holy city, and setteth him on a pinnacle of the temple,

Manx: 6 As doort e rish, My she Mac Yee oo, tilg oo hene sheese: son te scruit, Ver e currym da e ainlyn my dty chione, as ayns nyn lauyn nee ad oo y ymmyrkey, er aggle ec earish erbee, dy bwoail oo dty chass noi clagh.
English: 6 And saith unto him, If thou be the Son of God, cast thyself down: for it is written, He shall give his angels charge concerning thee: and in their hands they shall bear thee up, lest at any time thou dash thy foot against a stone.

Manx: 7 Doort Yeesey rish, Te scruit reesht, Cha jean oo yn Chiarn dty Yee y violagh.
English: 7 Jesus said unto him, It is written again, Thou shalt not tempt the Lord thy God.

Manx: 8 Reeshtagh hug y drogh spyrryd lesh e seose, er slieau feer ard, as yeeagh e da ooilley reeriaghtyn y teihl as y ghloyr oc:
English: 8 Again, the devil taketh him up into an exceeding high mountain, and sheweth him all the kingdoms of the world, and the glory of them;

Manx: 9 As doort e rish, shoh ooilley verryms dhyt, my huittys oo sheese, as my ver oo ooashley dou.
English: 9 And saith unto him, All these things will I give thee, if thou wilt fall down and worship me.

Manx: 10 Eisht doort Yeesey rish, Gow ass my eanish, Noid-anmey: Son te scruit, Ver oo ooashley da’n Chiarn dty Yee, as eshyn ny lomarcan nee oo y hirveish.
English: 10 Then saith Jesus unto him, Get thee hence, Satan: for it is written, Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and him only shalt thou serve.

Manx: 11 Eishtagh daag y drogh spyrryd e, as cur-my-ner haink ainlyn as ren ad e y hirveish.
English: 11 Then the devil leaveth him, and, behold, angels came and ministered unto him.

Manx: 12 ¶ Nish tra cheayl Yeesey, dy row ad er ghoal Ean, jimmee e roish gys Galilee.
English: 12 Now when Jesus had heard that John was cast into prison, he departed into Galilee;

Manx: 13 As daag e Nazareth, as haink e dy vaghey ayns Capernaum, ta rish oirr ny marrey, ayns ardjyn Zabulon as Nephthalim.
English: 13 And leaving Nazareth, he came and dwelt in Capernaum, which is upon the sea coast, in the borders of Zabulon and Nephthalim:

Manx: 14 Dy voddagh ve cooilleenit ny va loarit liorish Esaias yn phadeyr, gra,
English: 14 That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by Esaias the prophet, saying,

Manx: 15 Talloo Zabulon as talloo Nephthalim, er slyst ny marrey, cheu elley dy Yordan, Galilee jeh ny Ashoonyn:
English: 15 The land of Zabulon, and the land of Nephthalim, by the way of the sea, beyond Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles;

Manx: 16 Ta’n pobble, va nyn soie ayns dorraghys, er vakin Soilshey moar: as dauesyn va nyn soie ayns cheer as scadoo’n vaish, ta soilshey er nirree seose.
English: 16 The people which sat in darkness saw great light; and to them which sat in the region and shadow of death light is sprung up.

Manx: 17 ¶ Veih’n tra shen, ren Yeesey toshiaght dy phreacheil, as dy ghra, Gow-jee arrys, son ta reeriaght Yee er-gerrey.
English: 17 From that time Jesus began to preach, and to say, Repent: for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.

Manx: 18 ¶ As honnick Yeesey, myr ve shooyl liorish keayn Galilee, daa vraar, Simon va enmyssit Peddyr as Andreays e vraar, cur magh lieen ’sy cheayn (son va’d nyn Eeastairyn,)
English: 18 And Jesus, walking by the sea of Galilee, saw two brethren, Simon called Peter, and Andrew his brother, casting a net into the sea: for they were fishers.

Manx: 19 As doort e roo, Eiyr-jee orryms, as neems shiu nyn[*] Eeastairyn dy gheney.
English: 19 And he saith unto them, Follow me, and I will make you fishers of men.

Manx: 20 As chelleeragh daag ad nyn lieenteenyn as deiyr ad er.
English: 20 And they straightway left their nets, and followed him.

Manx: 21 As tra ve er gholl veih shen, honnick e daa vraar elley, Jamys mac Zebedee as Ean e vraar, ayns long marish Zebedee nyn ayr, karraghey ny lieenteenyn oc: as deie e orroo.
English: 21 And going on from thence, he saw other two brethren, James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother, in a ship with Zebedee their father, mending their nets; and he called them.

Manx: 22 As daag ad chelleeragh y long as nyn ayr, as deiyr ad er.
English: 22 And they immediately left the ship and their father, and followed him.

Manx: 23 ¶ As hie Yeesey my-geart ooilley Galilee, gynsaghey ayns ny Kialteenyn oc, as preacheil Sushtal y Reeriaght, as leihys dy chooilley hingys as dy chooilley ghoghan, mastey’n pobble.
English: 23 And Jesus went about all Galilee, teaching in their synagogues, and preaching the gospel of the kingdom, and healing all manner of sickness and all manner of disease among the people.

Manx: 24 As hie yn ennym echey magh trooid ooilley Syria, as hug ad lieu huggey, ooilley adsyn va fo aslaintyn, adsyn va fo caghlaaghyn dy ghoghanyn as dy gheiaghyn, adsyn va drogh spyrrydyn ayndoo, yn vooinjer va eddrym ayns nyn geeal rish caghlaa ny haist, as adsyn va’n chingys-craa orroo, as ren e ad y leihys.
English: 24 And his fame went throughout all Syria: and they brought unto him all sick people that were taken with divers diseases and torments, and those which were possessed with devils, and those which were lunatick, and those that had the palsy; and he healed them.

Manx: 25 As deiyr er chaglym moar dy leih, veih Galilee, as Decapolis, as Jerusalem, as Judea, as veih cheu elley dy Yordan.
English: 25 And there followed him great multitudes of people from Galilee, and from Decapolis, and from Jerusalem, and from Judaea, and from beyond Jordan.

Manx: CAB. V.
English: Matthew Chapter 5

Manx: 1 As fakin leid ny earrooyn dy leih, hie e seose er slieau: as tra ve er hoie sheese, haink huggey yn vooinjer va sheer geyrt er.
English: 1 And seeing the multitudes, he went up into a mountain: and when he was set, his disciples came unto him:

Manx: 2 As dosle e e veeal, as dynsee e ad, gra,
English: 2 And he opened his mouth, and taught them, saying,

Manx: 3 Bannit tar adsyn ta bought ayns spyrryd; Son lieusyn reeriaght Niau.
English: 3 Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

Manx: 4 Bannit tar adsyn ta janoo dobberan: Son bee ad er nyn ngherjagh.
English: 4 Blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted.

Manx: 5 Bannit tar adsyn ta imlee: Son bee yn talloo oc ayns eiraght.
English: 5 Blessed are the meek: for they shall inherit the earth.

Manx: 6 Bannit tar adsyn ta accryssagh as paagh lurg cairys: Son bee ad er nyn nianoo magh.
English: 6 Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness: for they shall be filled.

Manx: 7 Bannit ta’n vooinjer vyghinagh: Son bee myghin er ny hoilshagh daue.
English: 7 Blessed are the merciful: for they shall obtain mercy.

Manx: 8 Bannit tar adsyn ta glen ayns cree: Son nee ad Jee y akin.
English: 8 Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God.

Manx: 9 Bannit tar adsyn ta tayrn sleih gys shee: Son bee ad enmyssit nyn gloan dy Yee.
English: 9 Blessed are the peacemakers: for they shall be called the children of God.

Manx: 10 Bannit tar adsyn ta surranse tranlaase er graih cairys: Son lieusyn reeriaght Niau.
English: 10 Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness' sake: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

Manx: 11 Bannit ta shiuish, tra vees shiu oltooanit, as tranlaasit, as dy chooilley ghrogh red er ny ghra nyn oi eu, dy breagagh, er y choontey ayms.
English: 11 Blessed are ye, when men shall revile you, and persecute you, and shall say all manner of evil against you falsely, for my sake.

Manx: 12 Gow-jee boggey as bee-jee feer vooiaght: Son moar ta’n leagh eu ayns Niau: Son shoh myr ren ad tranlaase er ny phaderyn va rumbeue.
English: 12 Rejoice, and be exceeding glad: for great is your reward in heaven: for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you.

Manx: 13 ¶ Shiuish sollan y talloo; agh my ta’n sollan er choall e vlass, kys hig e vree ayn reesht? cha vel ymmyd erbee sodjey ny chouyr, agh dy ve tilgit magh as stampit fo cassyn deney.
English: 13 Ye are the salt of the earth: but if the salt have lost his savour, wherewith shall it be salted? it is thenceforth good for nothing, but to be cast out, and to be trodden under foot of men.

Manx: 14 Shiuish soilshey’n teihll. Ta ard-valley ta soit er cronck feer chronnal.
English: 14 Ye are the light of the world. A city that is set on an hill cannot be hid.

Manx: 15 Cha-moo ta sleih foddey kainle as dy choyrt ee fo saagh, agh ayns kanlere, as tiee cur soilshey da ooilley ny t’ayns y thie.
English: 15 Neither do men light a candle, and put it under a bushel, but on a candlestick; and it giveth light unto all that are in the house.

Manx: 16 Lig da’n soilshey eauish myr shen soilshagh kiongoyrt rish deney, dy vod ad fakin ny obbraghyn mie eu, as gloyr y choyrt da nyn Ayr t’ayns niau.
English: 16 Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven.

Manx: 17 ¶ Ny smooinee-jee dy daink mish dy chur mow yn leigh as ny phaderyn: cha nee dy chur mow haink mee, agh dy lieeney.
English: 17 Think not that I am come to destroy the law, or the prophets: I am not come to destroy, but to fulfil.

Manx: 18 Son dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, derrey nee aer as talloo cherraghtyn, cha bee yn ockle ny yn tittle er ny ghoal veih yn leigh, derrey vees ooilley jeant magh.
English: 18 For verily I say unto you, Till heaven and earth pass, one jot or one tittle shall in no wise pass from the law, till all be fulfilled.

Manx: 19 Quoi-erbee er-y-fa shen vrishys annane jeh ny Saraghyn sloo shoh, as ynsys deney myr shen, bee e enmyssit yn fer sloo ayns reeriaght Niau: agh quoi-erbee nee nyn nianoo as nyn nynsaghey ad, bee e enmyssit moar ayns reeriaght Niau.
English: 19 Whosoever therefore shall break one of these least commandments, and shall teach men so, he shall be called the least in the kingdom of heaven: but whosoever shall do and teach them, the same shall be called great in the kingdom of heaven.

Manx: 20 Son ta mee gra riu, mannagh bee yn Ynrycys eauish er-skyn ynrycys ny Scruderyn as ny Phariseyn, nagh vod shiu er aght erbee goll stiagh ayns reeriaght niau.
English: 20 For I say unto you, That except your righteousness shall exceed the righteousness of the scribes and Pharisees, ye shall in no case enter into the kingdom of heaven.

Manx: 21 ¶ Ta shiu er chlashtyn, dy row eh er ny ghra roosyn jeh’n chen earish, Cha jean oo dunverys: as quoi-erbee nee dunverys, toillee e kerraghey’n vriwnys.
English: 21 Ye have heard that it was said by them of old time, Thou shalt not kill; and whosoever shall kill shall be in danger of the judgment:

Manx: 22 Agh ta mish gra riuish, quoi-erbee ta corree rish e vraar fegooish oyr, dy doill e dy ve deyrit liorish y vriwnys: as quoi-erbee jir rish e vraar, Raca, dy doill e ve’r ny gheyrey liorish y choonceil: agh quoi-erbee jir, Uss ommydan, dy doill e deyrey gys aile Nivrin.
English: 22 But I say unto you, That whosoever is angry with his brother without a cause shall be in danger of the judgment: and whosoever shall say to his brother, Raca, shall be in danger of the council: but whosoever shall say, Thou fool, shall be in danger of hell fire.

Manx: 23 Shen-y-fa tra vees oo chebbal dty yioot er yn altar, my chooinys oo ayns shen, dy vel nee erbee ec dty vraar dt’oi;
English: 23 Therefore if thou bring thy gift to the altar, and there rememberest that thy brother hath ought against thee;

Manx: 24 Faag ayns shen dty yioot kiongoyrt rish yn altar, as immee royd, tayrn hoshiaght dty vraar gys shee, as eisht tar as cheb dty yioot.
English: 24 Leave there thy gift before the altar, and go thy way; first be reconciled to thy brother, and then come and offer thy gift.

Manx: 25 Cord dy tappee rishyn ta streeu rhyt; choud as vees shiu goll cooidjagh er y raad: er aggle dy livrey e oo seose gys y Vriw, as dy livrey yn Briw oo huggeysyn ta goall kerraghey, as dy bee oo tilgit ayns pryssoon.
English: 25 Agree with thine adversary quickly, whiles thou art in the way with him; lest at any time the adversary deliver thee to the judge, and the judge deliver thee to the officer, and thou be cast into prison.

Manx: 26 Dy firrinagh ta mee gra rhyt, nagh jig oo magh ass shen, derrey vees oo erreish yn farling sodjey magh y eeck.
English: 26 Verily I say unto thee, Thou shalt by no means come out thence, till thou hast paid the uttermost farthing.

Manx: 27 ¶ Ta shiu er chlashtyn, dy row eh er ny ghra roosyn jeh’n chen earish, Cha jean oo poosey y vrishey.
English: 27 Ye have heard that it was said by them of old time, Thou shalt not commit adultery:

Manx: 28 Agh ta mish gra riu, quoi-erbee ta jeaghyn er ben dy chur saint jee, dy vel e er vrishey poosey ree hanna ayns e chree.
English: 28 But I say unto you, That whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her hath committed adultery with her already in his heart.

Manx: 29 As my ta dty hooil yesh dy dty hayrn gys peccah, pluck assyd ee, as tilg woid ee, son te ny share dhyt annane jeh dty hooillyn y choall, ny dty slane chorp dy ve tilgit ayns Nivrin.
English: 29 And if thy right eye offend thee, pluck it out, and cast it from thee: for it is profitable for thee that one of thy members should perish, and not that thy whole body should be cast into hell.

Manx: 30 As my vees dty laue yesh dy dty hayrn gys peccah, giare jeed as tilg woid ee: son te ny share dhyt annane jeh dty oltyn y choall, ny dty slane chorp dy ve tilgit ayns Nivrin.
English: 30 And if thy right hand offend thee, cut it off, and cast it from thee: for it is profitable for thee that one of thy members should perish, and not that thy whole body should be cast into hell.

Manx: 31 Ve er ny ghra, quoi-erbee scarrys rish e ven, lig da screwnyn-scarree y chur jee.
English: 31 It hath been said, Whosoever shall put away his wife, let him give her a writing of divorcement:

Manx: 32 Agh ta mish gra riu, quoi-erbee scarrys rish e ven, cheu-mooie jeh son oyr maarderys, dy vel e cur urree poosey vrishey: as quoi-erbee phoosys ish ta scart, te brishey poosey.
English: 32 But I say unto you, That whosoever shall put away his wife, saving for the cause of fornication, causeth her to commit adultery: and whosoever shall marry her that is divorced committeth adultery.

Manx: 33 ¶ Myrgeddyn ta shiu er chlashtyn, dy row eh er ny ghra roosyn jeh’n chen earish, Cha jean oo loo oiagh y ghoall, agh cooilleenee oo ny t’ow dy loo gys y Chiarn.
English: 33 Again, ye have heard that it hath been said by them of old time, Thou shalt not forswear thyself, but shalt perform unto the Lord thine oaths:

Manx: 34 Agh ta mish gra riu, Ny loo-jee er aght erbee, edyr liorish Niau, son she stoyl-reeoil Yee eh:
English: 34 But I say unto you, Swear not at all; neither by heaven; for it is God's throne:

Manx: 35 Ny liorish y talloo, son shen y stoyl ta fo e chassyn: ny liorish Jerusalem, son shen ard-valley’n Ree moar.
English: 35 Nor by the earth; for it is his footstool: neither by Jerusalem; for it is the city of the great King.

Manx: 36 Cha-moo looys oo liorish dty chione, er-yn-oyr nagh vod oo yn renaig y yanoo bane ny doo.
English: 36 Neither shalt thou swear by thy head, because thou canst not make one hair white or black.

Manx: 37 Agh lig da’n ghlare eu ve, She, She, Cha nee, Cha nee: Son cre-erbee ta er-skyn shoh, she jeh’n olk te cheet.
English: 37 But let your communication be, Yea, yea; Nay, nay: for whatsoever is more than these cometh of evil.

Manx: 38 Ta shiu er chlashtyn dy row eh er ny ghra, Sooyl son sooyl, as feeackle son feeackle.
English: 38 Ye have heard that it hath been said, An eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth:

Manx: 39 Agh ta mish gra riu, Ny shir-jee aggair y chooilleeney: agh quoi-erbee woaillys oo er y lieckan yesh, chyndaa huggey yn lieckan elley.
English: 39 But I say unto you, That ye resist not evil: but whosoever shall smite thee on thy right cheek, turn to him the other also.

Manx: 40 As my ta fer erbee dy dty chuir ec y leigh, as goall ersooyl dty chooat, lig dty chloagey lesh myrgeddyn.
English: 40 And if any man will sue thee at the law, and take away thy coat, let him have thy cloke also.

Manx: 41 As quoi-erbee ver lesh oo er niart yn veeley, gow marish jees.
English: 41 And whosoever shall compel thee to go a mile, go with him twain.

Manx: 42 Cur dasyn ta janoo aghin hood, as veihsyn ta shirrey geeasaght woid ny chyndaa ersooyl.
English: 42 Give to him that asketh thee, and from him that would borrow of thee turn not thou away.

Manx: 43 ¶ Ta shiu er chlashtyn, dy row eh er ny ghra, Cur graih da dty naboo as feoh da dty Noid:
English: 43 Ye have heard that it hath been said, Thou shalt love thy neighbour, and hate thine enemy.

Manx: 44 Agh ta mish gra riu, Bee-jee graihagh er nyn Noidjyn, bannee-jee adsyn ta guee mollaghtyn diu, jean-jee mie dauesyn ta cur feoh diu, as gow-jee padjer er nyn son ocsyn, ta cur seaghyn as janoo tranlaase erriu.
English: 44 But I say unto you, Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you;

Manx: 45 Dy vod shiu ve nyn gloan da’n Ayr eu t’ayns Niau, Son te eshyn cur er e ghrian girree er olk as er mie, as cur fliaghey neose er y vooinjer chairagh as niau-chairagh.
English: 45 That ye may be the children of your Father which is in heaven: for he maketh his sun to rise on the evil and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust.

Manx: 46 Son my ta shiu soilshaghey graih dauesyn ta graihagh erriuish, cre’n leagh ta nyn gouyr? Nagh nee shoh myr ta ny eer publicanee janoo?
English: 46 For if ye love them which love you, what reward have ye? do not even the publicans the same?

Manx: 47 My she rish nyn mraaraghyn ny lomarcan ta shiu loart dy dooie, cre smoo ta shiu dy yanoo ny feallagh elley? nagh vel ny eer publicanee janoo myr shen?
English: 47 And if ye salute your brethren only, what do ye more than others? do not even the publicans so?

Manx: 48 Bee-jee shiuish er-y-fa shen dy firrinagh mie, myr ta’n Ayr eu t’ayns niau laane dy oays firrinagh.
English: 48 Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in heaven is perfect.

Manx: CAB. VI.
English: Matthew Chapter 6

Manx: 1 Cur-jee twoai nagh der shiu da ny Boughtyn, kiongoyrt rish deney, er coontey dy ve er ny akin lioroo: er nonney cha vow shiu leagh veih’n Ayr eu t’ayns niau.
English: 1 Take heed that ye do not your alms before men, to be seen of them: otherwise ye have no reward of your Father which is in heaven.

Manx: 2 Shen-y-fa tra t’ow coyrt da ny Boughtyn, ny lig da cayrn ve’r ny heidey royd, lurg aght ny crauee-foalsey, ayns ny kialteenyn, as ayns ny straadjyn, er coontey moylley gheddyn veih deney. Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, ta nyn Leagh oc.
English: 2 Therefore when thou doest thine alms, do not sound a trumpet before thee, as the hypocrites do in the synagogues and in the streets, that they may have glory of men. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward.

Manx: 3 Agh tra t’ow uss cur da ny Boughtyn, ny lig da fys y ve ec dty laue chiare, cre ta dty laue yesh dy yannoo.
English: 3 But when thou doest alms, let not thy left hand know what thy right hand doeth:

Manx: 4 Dy vod dty yeirk ve’r ny choyrt gy follit, as nee dty Ayr ta fakin ny ta jeant gy follit, dty leagh y chur dhyt gy foslit.
English: 4 That thine alms may be in secret: and thy Father which seeth in secret himself shall reward thee openly.

Manx: 5 ¶ As tra vees oo goall padjer, cha bee oo myr ny crauee-foalsey: son shynney lieusyn shassoo seose ayns ny kialteenyn, as ayns corneilyn ny straadjyn dy ghoall padjer, er chee dy ve’r ny akin liorish deney. Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy vel ad er gheddyn nyn leagh.
English: 5 And when thou prayest, thou shalt not be as the hypocrites are: for they love to pray standing in the synagogues and in the corners of the streets, that they may be seen of men. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward.

Manx: 6 Agh gow uss, tra vees oo goall padjer, stiagh ayns dty hiamyr, as erreish dhyt dty ghorrys y yeih, guee gys dty Ayr gy follit, as nee dty Ayr, ta fakin ny ta jeant gy follit, leagh y chur dhyt gy foslit.
English: 6 But thou, when thou prayest, enter into thy closet, and when thou hast shut thy door, pray to thy Father which is in secret; and thy Father which seeth in secret shall reward thee openly.

Manx: 7 Ny yei tra vees shiu guee, ny gow-jee rouyr taggloo erriu, goll rish ny angreesteenyn: son tar adsyn goall ayns laue, dy vow ad nyn aghinyn, liorish nyn ymmodee goan fardalagh.
English: 7 But when ye pray, use not vain repetitions, as the heathen do: for they think that they shall be heard for their much speaking.

Manx: 8 Ny eiyr-jee shiuish er-y-fa shen er yn aght ocsyn: son ta fys ec nyn Ayr cre ta ymmyrtsagh diu, roish my jean shiu aghin huggey.
English: 8 Be not ye therefore like unto them: for your Father knoweth what things ye have need of, before ye ask him.

Manx: 9 Er yn aght shoh er-y-fa shen gow-jee padjer: Ayr ainyn t’ayns niau, Casherick dy row dt’ennym.
English: 9 After this manner therefore pray ye: Our Father which art in heaven, Hallowed be thy name.

Manx: 10 Dy jig dty reeriaght. Dt’aigney dy row jeant er y talloo, myr te ayns niau.
English: 10 Thy kingdom come. Thy will be done in earth, as it is in heaven.

Manx: 11 Cur dooin nyn arran jiu as gagh laa.
English: 11 Give us this day our daily bread.

Manx: 12 As leih dooin nyn loghtyn, myr ta shin leih dauesyn ta janoo loghtyn nyn oi shin.
English: 12 And forgive us our debts, as we forgive our debtors.

Manx: 13 As ny leeid shin ayns miolagh, agh livrey shin veih olk: son she liats y reeriaght, as y phooar, as y ghloyr, son dy bragh. Amen.
English: 13 And lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from evil: For thine is the kingdom, and the power, and the glory, for ever. Amen.

Manx: 14 Son my leihys shiuish da deney nyn loghtyn, leihee nyn Ayr flaunyssagh myrgeddyn diuish.
English: 14 For if ye forgive men their trespasses, your heavenly Father will also forgive you:

Manx: 15 Agh mannagh leih shiu da deney nyn voiljyn, cha jean yn Ayr eu nyn voiljyn y leih diuish.
English: 15 But if ye forgive not men their trespasses, neither will your Father forgive your trespasses.

Manx: 16 ¶ As tra vees shiu trostey, ny bee-jee jeaghyn trimshagh, myr ny crauee-foalsey, son tar adsyn sollagh nyn eddinyn er chee deney dy chur tastey da’n trostey oc. Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy vel nyn leagh oc.
English: 16 Moreover when ye fast, be not, as the hypocrites, of a sad countenance: for they disfigure their faces, that they may appear unto men to fast. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward.

Manx: 17 Agh jean uss, tra vees oo trostey, dty chione y ooillagh as dt’eddin y oonlagh:
English: 17 But thou, when thou fastest, anoint thine head, and wash thy face;

Manx: 18 Er coontey nagh nee deney ver tastey da’n trostey ayd, agh dty Ayr ta toiggal folliaghtyn, as nee dty Ayr ta fakin ny ta [jeant] gy follit, leagh y chur dhyt gy foslit.
English: 18 That thou appear not unto men to fast, but unto thy Father which is in secret: and thy Father, which seeth in secret, shall reward thee openly.

Manx: 19 ¶ Ny stoyr-jee seose berchys, er nyn son eu hene, er y talloo, raad ta’n lhemeen as y mergey cur mow, as raad ta maarlee brishey stiagh as geid.
English: 19 Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth and rust doth corrupt, and where thieves break through and steal:

Manx: 20 Agh stoyr-jee [seose] er nyn son hene, berchys ayns niau; raad nagh vel y lhemeen ny’n mergey cur mow, as raad nagh vel maarlee brishey stiagh as geid.
English: 20 But lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust doth corrupt, and where thieves do not break through nor steal:

Manx: 21 Son raad vees nyn stoyr, ayns shen myrgeddyn vees y cree eu.
English: 21 For where your treasure is, there will your heart be also.

Manx: 22 Yn tooil ta cur soilshey da’n chorp; shen-y-fa my ta’n tooil fegooish foill, bee soilshey ec ooilley dty chorp.
English: 22 The light of the body is the eye: if therefore thine eye be single, thy whole body shall be full of light.

Manx: 23 Agh my ta foill ayns dty hooil, bee dty slane chorp ayns dorraghys. My she dorraghys eisht yn soilshey ta aynyd, nagh moar y dorraghys eh!
English: 23 But if thine eye be evil, thy whole body shall be full of darkness. If therefore the light that is in thee be darkness, how great is that darkness!

Manx: 24 ¶ Cha vod dooinney erbee daa vainshter y hirveish: son edyr ver e dwoai da’n derrey yeh as graih da’n jeh elley, ny bee e jeidjagh da’n derrey yeh as soiee e beg jeh’n jeh elley. Cha vod shiu Jee as Mammon y hirveish.
English: 24 No man can serve two masters: for either he will hate the one, and love the other; or else he will hold to the one, and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon.

Manx: 25 Er-yn-oyr shoh ta mee gra riu, ny bee-jee imneagh son nyn mea, cre nee shiu y ee, ny cre nee shiu y iv; ny foast son nyn girp, cre ver shiu y miu: Nagh vel y vea ny smoo dy ve soit jeh ny beaghey, as y corp ny coamrey?
English: 25 Therefore I say unto you, Take no thought for your life, what ye shall eat, or what ye shall drink; nor yet for your body, what ye shall put on. Is not the life more than meat, and the body than raiment?

Manx: 26 Cur-jee tastey da Eeanlee’n aer: son cha vel ad cuirr ny buin, ny chymsagh stiagh ayns soaltyn; foast ta nyn Ayr flaunyssagh dyn meaghey ad. Nagh vel shiuish foddey share ny adsyn?
English: 26 Behold the fowls of the air: for they sow not, neither do they reap, nor gather into barns; yet your heavenly Father feedeth them. Are ye not much better than they?

Manx: 27 Quoi eavish, liorish ve imneagh, oddys yn chraue-roih y chur gys yn aase echey?
English: 27 Which of you by taking thought can add one cubit unto his stature?

Manx: 28 As cre’n fa ta shiu imneagh son coamraghyn? Gow-jee eu hene kys ta lilleeyn y vagher gaase; cha vel ad laboragh ny sneeu.
English: 28 And why take ye thought for raiment? Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow; they toil not, neither do they spin:

Manx: 29 As foast ta mee gra riu, nagh row Solomon hene, ayns ooilley e ghloyr, er ny choamrey myr annane jeu shoh.
English: 29 And yet I say unto you, That even Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these.

Manx: 30 My ta Jee, er-y-fa shen, myr shoh coamrey’n faar ta jiu ’sy vagher as mairagh caeu’t stiagh ayns yn oghe, nagh jean e foddey smoo er nyn son eavish, O gheney faase-chredjuagh?
English: 30 Wherefore, if God so clothe the grass of the field, which to day is, and to morrow is cast into the oven, shall he not much more clotheyou, O ye of little faith?

Manx: 31 Ny bee-jee er-y-fa shen imneagh, gra, Cre nee mad y ee? ny cre nee mad y iv? ny cre yiow mad, dy chur y mooin?
English: 31 Therefore take no thought, saying, What shall we eat? or, What shall we drink? or, Wherewithal shall we be clothed?

Manx: 32 (Son ooilley ny reddyn shoh, ta ny Angreesteenyn imneagh er nyn son) agh ec yn Ayr flaunyssagh eavish ta fys dy vel feme eu er dy chooilley nee jeu shoh.
English: 32 (For after all these things do the Gentiles seek:) for your heavenly Father knoweth that ye have need of all these things.

Manx: 33 Agh shir-jee hoshiaght reeriaght Yee as e chairys, as bee shiu jeant magh lesh ooilley ny reddyn shoh.
English: 33 But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.

Manx: 34 Ny bee-jee er-y-fa shen ayns imnea erbee son y laa mairagh, son tra hig y laa mairagh, hig e chiarrail marish: ta e heaghyn hene dy liooar er son y tra t’ayn.
English: 34 Take therefore no thought for the morrow: for the morrow shall take thought for the things of itself. Sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof.

Manx: CAB. VII.
English: Matthew Chapter 7

Manx: 1 Ny briwnys-jee, as cha bee shiu er nyn mriwnys.
English: 1 Judge not, that ye be not judged.

Manx: 2 Son lesh y vriwnys ta shiu briwnys, bee shiu hene er nyn mriwnys. As lesh y towse ta shiu towse, bee eh er ny howse diu reesht.
English: 2 For with what judgment ye judge, ye shall be judged: and with what measure ye mete, it shall be measured to you again.

Manx: 3 As cre’n fa t’ow cronnagh yn brenneein t’ayns sooyl dty vraar, agh cha vel oo smooinaght er y beam t’ayns dty hooyl hene?
English: 3 And why beholdest thou the mote that is in thy brother's eye, but considerest not the beam that is in thine own eye?

Manx: 4 Ny kys jir oo rish dty vraar, Lig dou yn brenneein y ghoall ass dty hooyl, as cur-my-ner ta beam ayns dty hooyl hene?
English: 4 Or how wilt thou say to thy brother, Let me pull out the mote out of thine eye; and, behold, a beam is in thine own eye?

Manx: 5 Er-crauee-oalsey, tilg hoshiaght yn beam ass dty hooyl hene, eisht bee soilshey ayd dy ghoal yn brenneein ass sooyl dty vraarey.
English: 5 Thou hypocrite, first cast out the beam out of thine own eye; and then shalt thou see clearly to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye.

Manx: 6 ¶ Ny cur-jee ny ta casherick da ny moddee, cha-moo hilgys shiu ny pearlyn eu roish muckyn, er aggle dy stamp ad ad fo nyn gassyn, as dy jyndaa ad reesht as dy lot ad shiu.
English: 6 Give not that which is holy unto the dogs, neither cast ye your pearls before swine, lest they trample them under their feet, and turn again and rend you.

Manx: 7 ¶ Yearree-jee, as yiow shiu: shir-jee as nee shiu feddyn; bee-jee aignagh fosley gheddyn, as bee eh er ny osley diu.
English: 7 Ask, and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you:

Manx: 8 Son ta dy chooilley annane ta gearree, geddyn; as y fer ta shirrey, feddyn: as eshyn ta aignagh fosley gheddyn, bee eh er ny osley da.
English: 8 For every one that asketh receiveth; and he that seeketh findeth; and to him that knocketh it shall be opened.

Manx: 9 Ny quoi’n dooinney nyn mast eavish, ver clagh da e vac, [my hirrys e meer?]
English: 9 Or what man is there of you, whom if his son ask bread, will he give him a stone?

Manx: 10 [Ny] my hirrys e eeast, der e ard-nieu da?
English: 10 Or if he ask a fish, will he give him a serpent?

Manx: 11 My ta toiggal er-y-fa shen eavish ta olk, kys dy choyrt giootyn mie da nyn gloan, cre woad smoo nee’n Ayr eu t’ayns Niau reddyn mie y choyrt dauesyn ta janoo aghin huggey.
English: 11 If ye then, being evil, know how to give good gifts unto your children, how much more shall your Father which is in heaven give good things to them that ask him?

Manx: 12 Shen-y-fa dy chooilley nee cre-erbee balliuish deney dy yanoo riuish, jean-jee shiuish myr shen roosyn: son shoh yn leigh as ny phaderyn.
English: 12 Therefore all things whatsoever ye would that men should do to you, do ye even so to them: for this is the law and the prophets.

Manx: 13 ¶ Gow-jee stiagh er y yiat coon; son liane ta’n giat, as moar ta’n raad ta leeideil gys toyrt-mow, as shimmey ta goll er:
English: 13 Enter ye in at the strait gate: for wide is the gate, and broad is the way, that leadeth to destruction, and many there be which go in thereat:

Manx: 14 Er-y-fa dy nee chion ta’n giat, as coon ta’n raad ta leeideil gys bea, as schiark ta dy gheddyn magh eh.
English: 14 Because strait is the gate, and narrow is the way, which leadeth unto life, and few there be that find it.

Manx: 15 Cur-jee twoai jeh phaderyn foalsey, ta cheet hiu ayns coamraghyn keyrragh, agh cheu-stie ta’d nyn moddee-oaldey jollyssagh.
English: 15 Beware of false prophets, which come to you in sheep's clothing, but inwardly they are ravening wolves.

Manx: 16 Ver shiu enney orroo liorish nyn mess: vel mess y villey-feeney er ny heiy jeh drinyn, ny mess y villey-figgagh jeh onnanyn?
English: 16 Ye shall know them by their fruits. Do men gather grapes of thorns, or figs of thistles?

Manx: 17 Myr shen ta dagh billey mie tilgey mess mie, agh ta drogh villey tilgey drogh vess.
English: 17 Even so every good tree bringeth forth good fruit; but a corrupt tree bringeth forth evil fruit.

Manx: 18 Cha vod billey mie drogh vess y chur magh, ny drogh villey mess mie.
English: 18 A good tree cannot bring forth evil fruit, neither can a corrupt tree bring forth good fruit.

Manx: 19 Ta dy chooilley villey, nagh vel gymmyrkey magh mess mie, dy ve giarit sheese as tilgit ayns yn aile.
English: 19 Every tree that bringeth not forth good fruit is hewn down, and cast into the fire.

Manx: 20 Shen-y-fa liorish nyn mess ver shiu enney orroo.
English: 20 Wherefore by their fruits ye shall know them.

Manx: 21 ¶ Cha nee dy chooilley annane jir rhyms, Hiarn, Hiarn, hed stiagh ayns reeriaght niau: agh eshyn ta janoo aigney m’Ayrey t’ayns Niau.
English: 21 Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in heaven.

Manx: 22 Jir ymmodee rhyms ’sy laa shen, Hiarn, Hiarn, nagh vel shin er nianoo phaderys ayns dt’ennyms? as ayns dt’ennym er hilgey magh drogh spyrrydyn? as ayns dt’ennym er nianoo ymmodee obbraghyn Yyndyssagh?
English: 22 Many will say to me in that day, Lord, Lord, have we not prophesied in thy name? and in thy name have cast out devils? and in thy name done many wonderful works?

Manx: 23 As eishtagh focklyms magh daue, Cha ren mee rieau goall riu, immee-jee voym, ghrogh yantee.
English: 23 And then will I profess unto them, I never knew you: depart from me, ye that work iniquity.

Manx: 24 ¶ Quoi-erbee er-y-fa shen ta clashtyn ny goan shoh ayms, as ta janoo ymmyd mie jeu, soyllee-ym e gys dooinney creeney hrog e hie er creg:
English: 24 Therefore whosoever heareth these sayings of mine, and doeth them, I will liken him unto a wise man, which built his house upon a rock:

Manx: 25 As haink y fliaghey neose, as dhatt ny tuillaghyn, as heid ny geayghyn, as chaeu ad er y thie shen. As cha huitt eh, son dy row yn undin echey er creg.
English: 25 And the rain descended, and the floods came, and the winds blew, and beat upon that house; and it fell not: for it was founded upon a rock.

Manx: 26 As bee dy chooilley annane ta clashtyn my ghoan shoh, as nagh vel janoo ymmyd mie jeu, er ny hoylagh gys dooinney ommijagh, hrog e hie er y gheinnagh:
English: 26 And every one that heareth these sayings of mine, and doeth them not, shall be likened unto a foolish man, which built his house upon the sand:

Manx: 27 As huitt y fliaghey, as dhatt ny tuillaghyn, as heid ny geayghyn, as chaeu ad er y thie shen: as huitt eh, as moar va’n toyrt-mow echey.
English: 27 And the rain descended, and the floods came, and the winds blew, and beat upon that house; and it fell: and great was the fall of it.

Manx: 28 As haink eh gy kione, tra va Yeesey erreish ny goan shoh y livrey, dy ghow yn pobble yyndyss moar jeh’n ynsaghey echey.
English: 28 And it came to pass, when Jesus had ended these sayings, the people were astonished at his doctrine:

Manx: 29 Son dynsee e ad, myr fer va pooar echey, as cha nee myr ny scruderyn.
English: 29 For he taught them as one having authority, and not as the scribes.

Manx: CAB. VIII.
English: Matthew Chapter 8

Manx: 1 Tra ve er jeet neose jeh’n clieau, deiyr earrooyn moar dy leih er.
English: 1 When he was come down from the mountain, great multitudes followed him.

Manx: 2 As cur-my-ner haink lourane as hug e ooashley da, gra, Hiarn, my she dt’aigney eh, foddee oo mish y yanoo glen.
English: 2 And, behold, there came a leper and worshipped him, saying, Lord, if thou wilt, thou canst make me clean.

Manx: 3 As hug Yeesey magh e laue as venn e rish, gra, M’aigneys eh, bee er dty ghlenney. As chelleeragh va’n louranys echey er ny ghlenney.
English: 3 And Jesus put forth his hand, and touched him, saying, I will; be thou clean. And immediately his leprosy was cleansed.

Manx: 4 As doort Yeesey rish, Jeagh nagh ninsh oo shoh da dooinney erbee, agh gow, as jeagh oo hene da’n taggyrt, as cheb yn gioot doardee Moses, dy ve son fenish daue.
English: 4 And Jesus saith unto him, See thou tell no man; but go thy way, shew thyself to the priest, and offer the gift that Moses commanded, for a testimony unto them.

Manx: 5 ¶ As tra va Yeesey er gholl stiagh ayns Capernaum, haink captan-keead huggey guee er,
English: 5 And when Jesus was entered into Capernaum, there came unto him a centurion, beseeching him,

Manx: 6 As gra, Hiarn, ta my er-mooinjerey ny lhie ec y thie, ching jeh’n chingys-cra, ayns stayd feer treih.
English: 6 And saying, Lord, my servant lieth at home sick of the palsy, grievously tormented.

Manx: 7 As doort Yeesey rish, Higgyms as neem e y leihys.
English: 7 And Jesus saith unto him, I will come and heal him.

Manx: 8 As dreggyr y captan-keead gra, Hiarn, Cha vel mee feeu, oo dy heet stiagh fo my chlea: agh ny lomarcan loar y fockle, as bee my er-mooinjerey er ny leihys.
English: 8 The centurion answered and said, Lord, I am not worthy that thou shouldest come under my roof: but speak the word only, and my servant shall be healed.

Manx: 9 Son ta mish mee hene my ghooinney ta fo pooar, as ta sidooryn aym foym: as ta mee gra [rish shoh, Immee, as te goll; as] rish fer elley, Tar, as te cheet: as rish my harvaant, Jean shoh, as te dy yanoo eh.
English: 9 For I am a man under authority, having soldiers under me: and I say to this man, Go, and he goeth; and to another, Come, and he cometh; and to my servant, Do this, and he doeth it.

Manx: 10 Tra cheayl Yeesey shoh, ghow e yyndyss, as doort e roosyn va geyrt er, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Leid y credjue lajer shoh, cha vel mee er gheddyn ayns Israel hene.
English: 10 When Jesus heard it, he marvelled, and said to them that followed, Verily I say unto you, I have not found so great faith, no, not in Israel.

Manx: 11 As ta mee gra riu, dy jig ymmodee veih’n Niar as yn Neear, as dy soie ad sheese marish Abraham as Isaac as Jacob, ayns reeriaght Niau.
English: 11 And I say unto you, That many shall come from the east and west, and shall sit down with Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, in the kingdom of heaven.

Manx: 12 Agh bee cloan y reeriaght er nyn dilgey magh gys y dorraghys sodjey mooie: ayns shen vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn.
English: 12 But the children of the kingdom shall be cast out into outer darkness: there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.

Manx: 13 As doort Yeesey rish y captan-keead, Immee royd, as ’naght myr t’ow er chredjal, myr shen dy jig oo jeh. As va e er-mooinjerey er ny leihys ayns yn oor keddyn.
English: 13 And Jesus said unto the centurion, Go thy way; and as thou hast believed, so be it done unto thee. And his servant was healed in the selfsame hour.

Manx: 14 ¶ As tra va Yeesey er jeet stiagh ayns thie Pheddyr, honnick e Moir y Ven echey ny lhie as ching ayns y chiassaghey.
English: 14 And when Jesus was come into Peter's house, he saw his wife's mother laid, and sick of a fever.

Manx: 15 As venn e rish y laue eck, as daag y chiassaghey ee: as hug ee e headdagh y mee, as ren ee ad y hirveish.
English: 15 And he touched her hand, and the fever left her: and she arose, and ministered unto them.

Manx: 16 ¶ Tra va’n fastyr er jeet, hug ad lieu huggey ymmodee va drogh spyrrydyn ayndoo, as deiyr e magh ny spyrrydyn lesh fockle, as laanee e ooilley ny va ching.
English: 16 When the even was come, they brought unto him many that were possessed with devils: and he cast out the spirits with his word, and healed all that were sick:

Manx: 17 Dy voddagh shen ve cooilleenit va loarit liorish Esaias y Phadeyr, gra, Ghow e hene er nyn aslaintyn, as dymmyrk e nyn jingyssyn.
English: 17 That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by Esaias the prophet, saying, Himself took our infirmities, and bare our sicknesses.

Manx: 18 Nish tra honnick Yeesey earrooyn moarey dy leih my-geart y mish, hug e sarey dy gholl gys y cheu elley.
English: 18 Now when Jesus saw great multitudes about him, he gave commandment to depart unto the other side.

Manx: 19 As haink scrudere dy row huggey, as doort e rish, Vainshter, eiyryms ort raad erbee dy jeu.
English: 19 And a certain scribe came, and said unto him, Master, I will follow thee whithersoever thou goest.

Manx: 20 As doort Yeesey rish, Ta tuill ec ny shynnee, as idd ec eeanlee’n aer, agh ec Mac y dooinney cha vel boal dy chur e chione ayn.
English: 20 And Jesus saith unto him, The foxes have holes, and the birds of the air have nests; but the Son of man hath not where to lay his head.

Manx: 21 As doort fer elley jeusyn va sheer geyrt er, rish, Hiarn, cur kied dou hoshiaght goll thie, dy oanluckey my ayr[†].
English: 21 And another of his disciples said unto him, Lord, suffer me first to go and bury my father.

Manx: 22 Agh doort Yeesey rish, Eiyr orryms, as lig da ny merriu nyn merriu y oanluckey.
English: 22 But Jesus said unto him, Follow me; and let the dead bury their dead.

Manx: 23 ¶ As tra ve er ghoall luingys, hie yn vooinjer va sheer geyrt er marish.
English: 23 And when he was entered into a ship, his disciples followed him.

Manx: 24 As cur-my-ner, dirree sterrym moar ayns y cheayn, ayns wheesh as dy row yn long coodit rish ny tonnyn; agh ve eshyn ny chadley.
English: 24 And, behold, there arose a great tempest in the sea, insomuch that the ship was covered with the waves: but he was asleep.

Manx: 25 As haink adsyn va sheer geyrt er huggey, as ghooisht ad e, gra, Hiarn, saue shin, bee mad callit.
English: 25 And his disciples came to him, and awoke him, saying, Lord, save us: we perish.

Manx: 26 As doort e roo, cre’n fa ta shiu agglagh, shiuish dy chredjue moal? Eisht dirree e seose, as smaghtee e ny geayghyn as y faarkey, as va kuiney woar ayn.
English: 26 And he saith unto them, Why are ye fearful, O ye of little faith? Then he arose, and rebuked the winds and the sea; and there was a great calm.

Manx: 27 Agh ghow ny deney yyndyss, gra, Cre’n keint dy ghooinney e shoh, dy vel ny eer geayghyn as y faarkey cur bialys da!
English: 27 But the men marvelled, saying, What manner of man is this, that even the winds and the sea obey him!

Manx: 28 ¶ As tra ve er jeet gys y cheu elley gys cheer ny Gergesenee, haink daa ghooinney va drogh spyrrydyn ayndoo, magh ny whail, veih mastey ny hoaiaghyn, as cha keoie shen va’d, nagh by loys da dooinney erbee goll shiaghey yn raad shen.
English: 28 And when he was come to the other side into the country of the Gergesenes, there met him two possessed with devils, coming out of the tombs, exceeding fierce, so that no man might pass by that way.

Manx: 29 As cur-my-ner deie ad, gra, Cre’n eie t’ayd orrin, Yeesey Vac Yee? vel oo er jeet dy nyn dorchaghey roish y tra?
English: 29 And, behold, they cried out, saying, What have we to do with thee, Jesus, thou Son of God? art thou come hither to torment us before the time?

Manx: 30 As va foddey vow griagh moar dy vuckyn fo bochillyn.
English: 30 And there was a good way off from them an herd of many swine feeding.

Manx: 31 As ghuee ny drogh spyrrydyn er, gra, My eiyrys oo shin magh, cur kied dooin goll stiagh ayns ny muckyn.
English: 31 So the devils besought him, saying, If thou cast us out, suffer us to go away into the herd of swine.

Manx: 32 As doort e roo, Gow-jee reue, as tra va’d er jeet ass ny deney, hie ad stiagh ayns y ghriagh dy vuckyn; as cur-my-ner, roie yn slane ghriagh gouyr nyn mullee, lesh yn ughtagh gys y cheayn, as va’d baiht ayns ny ushtaghyn.
English: 32 And he said unto them, Go. And when they were come out, they went into the herd of swine: and, behold, the whole herd of swine ran violently down a steep place into the sea, and perished in the waters.

Manx: 33 As roie ny bochillyn rowe, as haink ad gys yn ard-valley, as dinsh ad dy chooilley nee, as my-chione ny deney va ny drogh spyrrydyn ayndoo.
English: 33 And they that kept them fled, and went their ways into the city, and told every thing, and what was befallen to the possessed of the devils.

Manx: 34 As cur-my-ner, haink y slane ard-valley magh quail Yeesey, as tra honnick ad e, ghuee ad er, e dy gholl roish ass ny ardjyn oc.
English: 34 And, behold, the whole city came out to meet Jesus: and when they saw him, they besought him that he would depart out of their coasts.

Manx: CAB. IX.
English: Matthew Chapter 9

Manx: 1 As ghow e luingys, as hioil e harrish, as haink e gys e ard-valley hene.
English: 1 And he entered into a ship, and passed over, and came into his own city.

Manx: 2 As cur-my-ner hug ad lieu huggey dooinney va ching jeh’n chingys-cra, ny lhie er lhiabbee: as hug Yeesey tastey da’n chredjue oc, as doort e rishyn va ching jeh’n chingys-cra, Vac, bee dy yien mie, ta dty pheccaghyn er nyn leih dhyt.
English: 2 And, behold, they brought to him a man sick of the palsy, lying on a bed: and Jesus seeing their faith said unto the sick of the palsy; Son, be of good cheer; thy sins be forgiven thee.

Manx: 3 As cur-my-ner, doort shiartance jeh ny scruderyn roo hene, Te shoh loart goan mollaghtagh.
English: 3 And, behold, certain of the scribes said within themselves, This man blasphemeth.

Manx: 4 As hoig Yeesey ny smooinaghtyn oc, as doort e, Cre’n fa ta drogh smooinaghtyn ayns ny creeaghyn eu?
English: 4 And Jesus knowing their thoughts said, Wherefore think ye evil in your hearts?

Manx: 5 Son quoi sassey dy ghra, Ta dty pheccaghyn er nyn leih dhyt? ny dy ghra, Irree seose as shooil?
English: 5 For whether is easier, to say, Thy sins be forgiven thee; or to say, Arise, and walk?

Manx: 6 Agh dy vod fys y ve eu, dy vel pooar ec mac y dooinney er y talloo, dy leih peccaghyn, (eisht doort e rishyn va ching jeh’n chingys-cra) Irree, trog liat dty lhiabbee, as gow royd gys dty hie.
English: 6 But that ye may know that the Son of man hath power on earth to forgive sins, (then saith he to the sick of the palsy,) Arise, take up thy bed, and go unto thine house.

Manx: 7 As dirree e seose, as jimmee e gys e hie.
English: 7 And he arose, and departed to his house.

Manx: 8 Agh tra honnick y pobble shoh, ghow ad yyndyss, as hug ad moylley da Jee, v’er choyrt leid y phooar da deney.
English: 8 But when the multitudes saw it, they marvelled, and glorified God, which had given such power unto men.

Manx: 9 ¶ As tra va Yeesey er gholl veih shen, honnick e dooinney va enmyssit Mian, ny hoie ec board y cheesh: as doort e rish, Eiyr orryms. As dirree e seose as deiyr e er.
English: 9 And as Jesus passed forth from thence, he saw a man, named Matthew, sitting at the receipt of custom: and he saith unto him, Follow me. And he arose, and followed him.

Manx: 10 ¶ As haink eh gy kione, myr va Yeesey ny hoie ec bee ayns y thie, cur-my-ner, haink ymmodee publicanee as peccee, as hoie ad sheese marishyn as marish y vooinjer va sheer geyrt er.
English: 10 And it came to pass, as Jesus sat at meat in the house, behold, many publicans and sinners came and sat down with him and his disciples.

Manx: 11 Tra honnick ny Phariseyn shoh, doort ad roosyn va sheer marish, Cre’n fa ta’n mainshter eu gee marish publicanee as peccee?
English: 11 And when the Pharisees saw it, they said unto his disciples, Why eateth your Master with publicans and sinners?

Manx: 12 Agh cheayl Yeesey ad, as doort e roo, Cha vel feme ocsyn ta slane er y lhee, agh ec sleih chingey.
English: 12 But when Jesus heard that, he said unto them, They that be whole need not a physician, but they that are sick.

Manx: 13 Agh gow-jee shiuish as ynsee-jee cre ta dy ve toiggit liorish y raa shoh, Ta mee ny sbooie er myghin ny oural: son cha daink mish dy emagh er y vooinjer chairagh, agh er peccee gys arrys.
English: 13 But go ye and learn what that meaneth, I will have mercy, and not sacrifice: for I am not come to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.

Manx: 14 ¶ Eisht haink huggey adsyn va sheer geyrt er Ean, as doort ad, Cre’n fa ta shinyn as ny Phariseyn trostey dy mennick, agh cha vel adsyn ta geyrt orts trostey?
English: 14 Then came to him the disciples of John, saying, Why do we and the Pharisees fast oft, but thy disciples fast not?

Manx: 15 As doort Yeesey roo, Vod ny caarjyn ta marish dooinney’n phoosee ayns e hiamyr ve er drogh yien, choud as ta dooinney’n phoosee mâroo? agh hig ny laghyn, tra vees dooinney’n phoosee er ny ghoal ersooyl vow, as shen y tra nee ad trostey.
English: 15 And Jesus said unto them, Can the children of the bridechamber mourn, as long as the bridegroom is with them? but the days will come, when the bridegroom shall be taken from them, and then shall they fast.

Manx: 16 Cha vel dooinney erbee cur peesh dy eaddagh lajer er shen gharmad, son ta’n pheesh goall y laane ass y gharmad, as te rapit ny smessey ny ve.
English: 16 No man putteth a piece of new cloth unto an old garment, for that which is put in to fill it up taketh from the garment, and the rent is made worse.

Manx: 17 Cha-moo ta sleih coyrt feeyn noa ayns shen voteilyn[‡]: er nonney ta ny boteilyn brishey, as ta’n feeyn deartit, as ta ny boteilyn dy choall orroo; agh ta’d cur feeyn noa ayns boteilyn noa, as ta’d nyn neesht sauchey.
English: 17 Neither do men put new wine into old bottles: else the bottles break, and the wine runneth out, and the bottles perish: but they put new wine into new bottles, and both are preserved.

Manx: 18 ¶ Choud as ve loart ny goan shoh roo, cur-my-ner, haink fer-reil as hug e ooashley da, gra, Ta m’inneen nish er gheddyn baase: agh tar as cur dty laue urree, as bee ee bio reesht.
English: 18 While he spake these things unto them, behold, there came a certain ruler, and worshipped him, saying, My daughter is even now dead: but come and lay thy hand upon her, and she shall live.

Manx: 19 As dirree Yeesey as deiyr e er, as myr shen ren yn vooinjer va sheer geyrt er.
English: 19 And Jesus arose, and followed him, and so did his disciples.

Manx: 20 (As cur-my-ner haink ben cheu-y-choolloo, va doghanit rish roie-folley choud as daa vlein jeig, as venn ee rish oirr e gharmad.
English: 20 And, behold, a woman, which was diseased with an issue of blood twelve years, came behind him, and touched the hem of his garment:

Manx: 21 Son doort ee cheu-stie jee hene, My oddym agh bentyn rish e gharmad, beeym er my leihys.
English: 21 For she said within herself, If I may but touch his garment, I shall be whole.

Manx: 22 Agh hyndaa Yeesey my-geart, as tra honnick e ee, doort e, Inneen, bee dy yien mie; ta dty chredjue er dty laanaghey. As va’n ven er ny leihys veih yn oor shen.)
English: 22 But Jesus turned him about, and when he saw her, he said, Daughter, be of good comfort; thy faith hath made thee whole. And the woman was made whole from that hour.

Manx: 23 As tra va Yeesey er jeet stiagh ayns thie yn fer-reil as tra honnick e yn vooinjer va janoo kiaull, as y cheshaght ooilley bun-rish-kyn.
English: 23 And when Jesus came into the ruler's house, and saw the minstrels and the people making a noise,

Manx: 24 Doort e roo, scugh-jee ass y raad, son cha vel y ven-aeg marroo, agh ny cadley. As hie ad son craidey mish.
English: 24 He said unto them, Give place: for the maid is not dead, but sleepeth. And they laughed him to scorn.

Manx: 25 Agh tra va’n sleih er nyn eyrt magh, hie e stiagh, as ghow e ee er laue as dirree yn ven-aeg seose.
English: 25 But when the people were put forth, he went in, and took her by the hand, and the maid arose.

Manx: 26 As hie goo magh jeh shoh, trooid ooilley’n cheer.
English: 26 And the fame hereof went abroad into all that land.

Manx: 27 ¶ As tra va Yeesey er gholl veih shen, deiyr daa ghooinney doall er, gemagh as gra, Jean chymmey orrin, vac Ghavid.
English: 27 And when Jesus departed thence, two blind men followed him, crying, and saying, Thou Son of David, have mercy on us.

Manx: 28 As tra ve er jeet stiagh ayns y thie, haink ny deney doall huggey: as doort Yeesey roo, Vel shiu credjal dy vel mish able shoh y yanoo? Doort adsyn rish, Ta, Hiarn.
English: 28 And when he was come into the house, the blind men came to him: and Jesus saith unto them, Believe ye that I am able to do this?They said unto him, Yea, Lord.

Manx: 29 Eisht venn e rish ny sooyllyn oc, gra, Cordail rish nyn gredjue, dy row nyn aghin eu.
English: 29 Then touched he their eyes, saying, According to your faith be it unto you.

Manx: 30 As va ny sooyllyn oc er nyn vosley, as hug Yeesey currym geyr daue, gra, Jeagh-jee nagh vow dooinney erbee fys er.
English: 30 And their eyes were opened; and Jesus straitly charged them, saying, See that no man know it.

Manx: 31 Agh tra var adsyn er gholl rowe, hug ad magh yn goo echey trooid ooilley’n cheer shen.
English: 31 But they, when they were departed, spread abroad his fame in all that country.

Manx: 32 ¶ Erreish daue shoh v’er gholl ersooyl, cur-my-ner hug ad lieu huggey dooinney balloo, va drogh spyrryd ayn.
English: 32 As they went out, behold, they brought to him a dumb man possessed with a devil.

Manx: 33 As tra va’n drogh spyrryd er ny eyrt ass, ren y balloo loart: as ghow yn pobble yyndyss, gra, Cha row rieau leid shoh er ny akin ayns Israel.
English: 33 And when the devil was cast out, the dumb spake: and the multitudes marvelled, saying, It was never so seen in Israel.

Manx: 34 Agh doort ny Phariseyn, Liorish prince ny drogh spyrrydyn te tilgey magh drogh spyrrydyn.
English: 34 But the Pharisees said, He casteth out devils through the prince of the devils.

Manx: 35 As hie Yeesey my-geart ooilley ny ard-valjyn as ny baljyn beggey oc, gynsaghey ayns ny kialteenyn oc, as preacheil sushtal yn reeriaght, as leihys dy chooilley hingys as dy chooilley ghoghan mastey’n pobble.
English: 35 And Jesus went about all the cities and villages, teaching in their synagogues, and preaching the gospel of the kingdom, and healing every sickness and every disease among the people.

Manx: 36 ¶ Agh tra honnick e yn chaglym moar dy leih, ve er ny veyghey lesh chymmey orroo, er-yn-oyr dy row ad ass cree, as nyn lhie noon as noal, myr kirree fegooish bochilley.
English: 36 But when he saw the multitudes, he was moved with compassion on them, because they fainted, and were scattered abroad, as sheep having no shepherd.

Manx: 37 Eisht doort e roosyn va sheer geyrt er, Ta’n fouyr dy jarroo palchey, agh ny labreeyn beggan.
English: 37 Then saith he unto his disciples, The harvest truly is plenteous, but the labourers are few;

Manx: 38 Guee-jee shiuish er-y-fa shen er Chiarn y fouyr, e dy chur magh labreeyn gys y fouyr echey.
English: 38 Pray ye therefore the Lord of the harvest, that he will send forth labourers into his harvest.

Manx: CAB. X.
English: Matthew Chapter 10

Manx: 1 As tra ve er nemagh er e ghaa ostyl jeig huggey, hug e daue pooar harrish spyrrydyn niau-ghlen, dyn eyrt magh ad, as dy [leihys dy chooilley hingys, as dy] chooilley ghoghan.
English: 1 And when he had called unto him his twelve disciples, he gave them power against unclean spirits, to cast them out, and to heal all manner of sickness and all manner of disease.

Manx: 2 As shoh va enmyn yn daa ostyl yeig; yn chied er, Simon ta enmyssit Peddyr, as Andreays e vraar. Jamys mac Zebedee, as Ean y braar echyssyn,
English: 2 Now the names of the twelve apostles are these; The first, Simon, who is called Peter, and Andrew his brother; James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother;

Manx: 3 Philip as Bartholomew, Thomas, as Mian yn publican, Jamys mac Alpheus, as Lebbeus va slennooit Thaddeus.
English: 3 Philip, and Bartholomew; Thomas, and Matthew the publican; James the son of Alphaeus, and Lebbaeus, whose surname was Thaddaeus;

Manx: 4 Simon yn Canaanite, as Yuase Iscariot, ren myrgeddyn e y vrah.
English: 4 Simon the Canaanite, and Judas Iscariot, who also betrayed him.

Manx: 5 Yn ghaa yeig shoh hug Yeesey magh, as doardee e daue, gra, Ny gow-jee ayns raad ny Ashoonyn quaagh, ny gys ard-valjyn ny Samaritanee.
English: 5 These twelve Jesus sent forth, and commanded them, saying, Go not into the way of the Gentiles, and into any city of the Samaritans enter ye not:

Manx: 6 Agh gow-jee hoshiaght gys kirree cailjey thie Israel.
English: 6 But go rather to the lost sheep of the house of Israel.

Manx: 7 As myr vees shiu goll, jean-jee preacheil, gra, Ta reeriaght Niau er-gerrey.
English: 7 And as ye go, preach, saying, The kingdom of heaven is at hand.

Manx: 8 Slaanee-jee sleih chingey, glen-jee ny louranee, jean-jee ny merriu y vioghey, tilg-jee magh drogh spyrrydyn: nastee ta shiu er gheddyn, as dy nastee cur-jee veu.
English: 8 Heal the sick, cleanse the lepers, raise the dead, cast out devils: freely ye have received, freely give.

Manx: 9 Ny cur-jee lieu aer, ny argid, ny prash ayns ny sporranyn eu:
English: 9 Provide neither gold, nor silver, nor brass in your purses,

Manx: 10 Ny stoyr dy vee son y raad, ny daa chooat, ny braagyn, ny luirg (son ta’n obbree feeu e veaghey.)
English: 10 Nor scrip for your journey, neither two coats, neither shoes, nor yet staves: for the workman is worthy of his meat.

Manx: 11 As ard-valley ny balley erbee dy jed shiu stiagh ayn, fenee-jee quoi ayn ta feeu, as marishyn furree-jee, derrey hed shiu reue.
English: 11 And into whatsoever city or town ye shall enter, enquire who in it is worthy; and there abide till ye go thence.

Manx: 12 As tra vees shiu goll stiagh ayns thie, bannee-jee daue.
English: 12 And when ye come into an house, salute it.

Manx: 13 As my vees y thie feeu, lig da’n shee eu cheet er: agh mannagh bee eh feeu, lig da’n shee eu chyndaa hiu hene reesht.
English: 13 And if the house be worthy, let your peace come upon it: but if it be not worthy, let your peace return to you.

Manx: 14 As quoi-erbee nagh jean nyn mea y oltaghey, as nagh der geill da ny goan eu, tra aagys shiu yn thie ny’n ard-valley shen, crie-jee yn joan jeh ny cassyn eu.
English: 14 And whosoever shall not receive you, nor hear your words, when ye depart out of that house or city, shake off the dust of your feet.

Manx: 15 Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy vow cheer Sodom as Gomorrah ny smoo dy foar, ec laa ny briwnys, ny yiow yn ard-valley shen.
English: 15 Verily I say unto you, It shall be more tolerable for the land of Sodom and Gomorrha in the day of judgment, than for that city.

Manx: 16 ¶ Cur-my-ner ta mish dyn goyrt shiu magh, myr kirree mastey moddee-oaldey. Bee-jee er-y-fa shen creeney myr ard-nieughyn, as gyn loght myr calmanyn.
English: 16 Behold, I send you forth as sheep in the midst of wolves: be ye therefore wise as serpents, and harmless as doves.

Manx: 17 Agh cur-jee twoai jeh deney, son livrey-ee ad shiu seose gys ny coonceilyn as custee ad shiu ayns ny kialteenyn oc.
English: 17 But beware of men: for they will deliver you up to the councils, and they will scourge you in their synagogues;

Manx: 18 As bee shiu er nyn goyrt fenish kianoortyn as reeaghyn er y choontey ayms, dy vod oyr y ve eu, fenish y ymmyrkey[§] dauesyn as da ny Ashoonyn quaagh.
English: 18 And ye shall be brought before governors and kings for my sake, for a testimony against them and the Gentiles.

Manx: 19 Agh tra livrey-ys ad shiu seose, ny bee-jee imneagh kys ny cre nee shiu y loart, son bee eh er ny choyrt diu ayns yn oor keddyn, cre nee shiu y loart.
English: 19 But when they deliver you up, take no thought how or what ye shall speak: for it shall be given you in that same hour what ye shall speak.

Manx: 20 Son cha nee shiuish ta loart, agh spyrryd yn Ayr eu ta loart ayndiu.
English: 20 For it is not ye that speak, but the Spirit of your Father which speaketh in you.

Manx: 21 As livrey-ee yn derrey vraar yn braar elley gys baase, as yn ayr y liannoo; as nee cloan girree seose noi nyn ayr as nyn moir, as deyree[**] ad ad gys baase.
English: 21 And the brother shall deliver up the brother to death, and the father the child: and the children shall rise up against their parents, and cause them to be put to death.

Manx: 22 As ver dy chooilley ghooinney feoh diu, kyndagh rish yn ennym ayms: agh eshyn nee fannaghtyn gys y jerrey, bee e er ny hauail.
English: 22 And ye shall be hated of all men for my name's sake: but he that endureth to the end shall be saved.

Manx: 23 Agh tra vees ad janoo tranlaase erriu ’sy derrey ard-valley, roie-jee shiuish er-chea gys ard-valley elley: son dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy bee mac y dooinney er jeet[††], roish my bee shiu er gholl harrish ard-valjyn Israel.
English: 23 But when they persecute you in this city, flee ye into another: for verily I say unto you, Ye shall not have gone over the cities of Israel, till the Son of man be come.

Manx: 24 Cha vel yn scoyllar er-skyn e vainshter, ny’n chiarvaant er-skyn e hiarn.
English: 24 The disciple is not above his master, nor the servant above his lord.

Manx: 25 Slioyr da’n scoyllar dy ve myr e vainshter, as da’n chiarvaant myr e hiarn: my ta’d er chaeu Beelzebub er mainshter y thie, cre woad smoo nee ad e vooinjer y oltooan?
English: 25 It is enough for the disciple that he be as his master, and the servant as his lord. If they have called the master of the house Beelzebub, how much more shall they call them of his household?

Manx: 26 Ny gow-jee er-y-fa shen aggle rowe: son cha vel nee erbee follit, nagh jig gys soilshey, ny nee erbee kellit nagh jig magh.
English: 26 Fear them not therefore: for there is nothing covered, that shall not be revealed; and hid, that shall not be known.

Manx: 27 Shen ta mish dy insh diu ayns y dorraghys, loar-jee shiuish jeh ayns y toilshey, as ny ta shiu er chlashtyn ayns y chleash eu voyms, jean-jee y phreacheil er mullagh ny thiyn.
English: 27 What I tell you in darkness, that speak ye in light: and what ye hear in the ear, that preach ye upon the housetops.
