Manx: 28 As ny bee-jee agglagh rowesyn varrys y corp, agh nagh jiarg er yn annym y varroo: agh bee-jee ayns aggle smoo roishyn, oddys corp as annym neesht y stroie ayns Nivrin.
English: 28 And fear not them which kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul: but rather fear him which is able to destroy both soul and body in hell.

Manx: 29 Nagh vel daa sparrow er nyn greck son farling? as cha duitt annane oc marroo er y talloo fegooish oardaghey’n Ayr eu.
English: 29 Are not two sparrows sold for a farthing? and one of them shall not fall on the ground without your Father.

Manx: 30 Agh ta eer renaigyn nyn ging ooilley er nyn earroo.
English: 30 But the very hairs of your head are all numbered.

Manx: 31 Ny bee-jee shiuish er-y-fa shen ayns aggle, ta ny smoo dy ve soit jiu, ny jeh ymmodee sperriu.
English: 31 Fear ye not therefore, ye are of more value than many sparrows.

Manx: 32 Quoi-erbee er-y-fa shen ghoys rhyms kiongoyrt rish deney, goyms rishyn myrgeddyn kiongoyrt rish my Ayr t’ayns niau.
English: 32 Whosoever therefore shall confess me before men, him will I confess also before my Father which is in heaven.

Manx: 33 Agh quoi-erbee obbys mish kiongoyrt rish deney, eshyn neems myrgeddyn y obbal kiongoyrt rish my Ayr t’ayns niau.
English: 33 But whosoever shall deny me before men, him will I also deny before my Father which is in heaven.

Manx: 34 Ny smooinee-jee dy daink mish dy chur liam shee gys y talloo, cha daink mee dy chur liam shee, agh cliwe.
English: 34 Think not that I am come to send peace on earth: I came not to send peace, but a sword.

Manx: 35 Son ta mish er jeet dy scarrey dooinney veih e ayr, as yn inneen veih e moir, as y ven chlewn veih e moir ’sy leigh.
English: 35 For I am come to set a man at variance against his father, and the daughter against her mother, and the daughter in law against her mother in law.

Manx: 36 As noidjyn dooinney vees adsyn jeh’n lught-thie echey hene.
English: 36 And a man's foes shall be they of his own household.

Manx: 37 Eshyn ta ny sgraihee er ayr ny moir ny orryms, cha vel e feeu jeem: as eshyn ta ny sgraihee er mac ny inneen ny orryms, cha vel e feeu jeem.
English: 37 He that loveth father or mother more than me is not worthy of me: and he that loveth son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me.

Manx: 38 As eshyn nagh jean e chrosh y ymmyrkey as geyrt orryms, cha vel e feeu jeem.
English: 38 And he that taketh not his cross, and followeth after me, is not worthy of me.

Manx: 39 Eshyn nee e vioys y hauail, caillee e eh, agh eshyn chaillys e vioys er my ghraih’s, nee e eh y hauail.
English: 39 He that findeth his life shall lose it: and he that loseth his life for my sake shall find it.

Manx: 40 Eshyn ta soiaghey jiuish, te soiaghey jeems, as eshyn ta soiaghey jeems, te soiaghey jehsyn t’er my choyrt.
English: 40 He that receiveth you receiveth me, and he that receiveth me receiveth him that sent me.

Manx: 41 Eshyn ta cur oltaghey-bea da phadeyr ayns ennym phadeyr, yiow e leagh phadeyr, as eshyn ta cur oltaghey-bea da dooinney cairagh ayns ennym dooinney cairagh, yiow e leagh dooinney cairagh.
English: 41 He that receiveth a prophet in the name of a prophet shall receive a prophet's reward; and he that receiveth a righteous man in the name of a righteous man shall receive a righteous man's reward.

Manx: 42 As quoi-erbee ver cappan dy ushtey feayr da annane jeh’n vooinjer veggey shoh dy iv, ayns ennym annane jeusyn ta sheer geyrt orryms, dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, nagh jean e er aght erbee e leagh y choall.
English: 42 And whosoever shall give to drink unto one of these little ones a cup of cold water only in the name of a disciple, verily I say unto you, he shall in no wise lose his reward.

Manx: CAB. XI.
English: Matthew Chapter 11

Manx: 1 As haink eh gy kione, tra va Yeesey erreish saraghyn y choyrt da e ghaa ostyl jeig, dy jagh e veih shen dy ynsaghey as dy phreacheil ayns ny kialteenyn oc.
English: 1 And it came to pass, when Jesus had made an end of commanding his twelve disciples, he departed thence to teach and to preach in their cities.

Manx: 2 Nish tra va Ean er chlashtyn ayns y phryssoon jeh obbraghyn Chreest, hug e jees jeusyn v’er ny ve sheer marish er chaghteraght huggey,
English: 2 Now when John had heard in the prison the works of Christ, he sent two of his disciples,

Manx: 3 Dy ghra rish, Nee uss e[‡‡], va dy heet, ny vel shin dy yeaghyn son fer elley?
English: 3 And said unto him, Art thou he that should come, or do we look for another?

Manx: 4 Dreggyr Yeesey as doort e roo, Immee-jee as soilshee-jee da Ean ny reddyn ta shiu dy chlashtyn as dy akin:
English: 4 Jesus answered and said unto them, Go and shew John again those things which ye do hear and see:

Manx: 5 Ta ny doall geddyn nyn soilshey, as ny croobee gimmeeaght, ny louranee er nyn ghlenney, ny beuyr clashtyn, ny merriu er nyn mioghey, as y sushtal er ny phreacheil da ny boughtyn.
English: 5 The blind receive their sight, and the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, and the deaf hear, the dead are raised up, and the poor have the gospel preached to them.

Manx: 6 As bannit ta eshyn nagh gow oyr dy huittym ayns peccah, my my chiones.
English: 6 And blessed is he, whosoever shall not be offended in me.

Manx: 7 ¶ As myr va’d goll rowe, ren Yeesey toshiaght dy ghra rish y pobble my-chione Ean, Cre hie shiu magh gys yn aasagh dy akin? cuirtlagh criht rish y gheay?
English: 7 And as they departed, Jesus began to say unto the multitudes concerning John, What went ye out into the wilderness to see? A reed shaken with the wind?

Manx: 8 Agh cre hie shiu magh dy akin? Dooinney coamrit ayns sheedey? Cur-my-ner, tar adsyn ta caeu sheedey ayns thiyn reeaghyn.
English: 8 But what went ye out for to see? A man clothed in soft raiment? behold, they that wear soft clothing are in kings' houses.

Manx: 9 Agh cre hie shiu magh dy akin? Phadeyr? Dy jarroo, ta mee gra riu, as fer syrjey ny phadeyr.
English: 9 But what went ye out for to see? A prophet? yea, I say unto you, and more than a prophet.

Manx: 10 Son shoh e, jeh te scruit, Cur-my-ner ta mee cur my haghter magh royd, dy yanoo aarloo jeh’n raad er dty hon.
English: 10 For this is he, of whom it is written, Behold, I send my messenger before thy face, which shall prepare thy way before thee.

Manx: 11 Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, nyn mastey ocsyn t’er nyn mreh jeh mraane, cha vel fer syrjey ny Ean Bashtey er nirree seose: ny yei ta’n fer[§§] sloo t’ayns reeriaght niau ny syrjey ny eshyn.
English: 11 Verily I say unto you, Among them that are born of women there hath not risen a greater than John the Baptist: notwithstanding he that is least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than he.

Manx: 12 As er dy laghyn Ean Bashtey derrey nish, ta sleih chionney stiagh gys reeriaght niau, as tar adsyn ta cheet lesh jeeanit cosney stiagh ayn.
English: 12 And from the days of John the Baptist until now the kingdom of heaven suffereth violence, and the violent take it by force.

Manx: 13 Son ren ooilley ny phaderyn as y leigh phaderys derrey Ean.
English: 13 For all the prophets and the law prophesied until John.

Manx: 14 As my ta shiu booiaght y chlashtyn eh, shoh Elias va ry hoi cheet.
English: 14 And if ye will receive it, this is Elias, which was for to come.

Manx: 15 Eshyn ta cleashyn echey dy chlashtyn, lig e clashtyn.
English: 15 He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.

Manx: 16 ¶ Agh cre gys neem yn cheeloghe shoh y holaghey? Ta’d goll rish cloan ta nyn soie ayns ny margaghyn, as gemagh da ny sheshaghyn oc,
English: 16 But whereunto shall I liken this generation? It is like unto children sitting in the markets, and calling unto their fellows,

Manx: 17 As gra, Ta shin er nianoo bingys diu, as cha vel shiu er ghonsin; ta shin er nianoo kiaull hrimshagh diu, as cha vel shiu er cheaney.
English: 17 And saying, We have piped unto you, and ye have not danced; we have mourned unto you, and ye have not lamented.

Manx: 18 Son cha daink Ean gee ny giv, as ta’d gra, Ta drogh spyrryd ayn.
English: 18 For John came neither eating nor drinking, and they say, He hath a devil.

Manx: 19 Haink yn mac dooinney gee as giv, as ta’d gra, Cur-my-ner dooinney jollyssagh, as ivder-feeney, carrey dy phublicanee as dy pheccee: Agh ta creenaght er ny seyrey liorish e cloan hene.
English: 19 The Son of man came eating and drinking, and they say, Behold a man gluttonous, and a winebibber, a friend of publicans and sinners. But wisdom is justified of her children.

Manx: 20 ¶ Eishtagh ren e toshiaght dy gheddyn foill da ny ard-valjyn, ayndoo va’n chooid smoo jeh e obbraghyn yyndyssagh er nyn nianoo, er-yn-oyr nagh ghow ad arrys.
English: 20 Then began he to upbraid the cities wherein most of his mighty works were done, because they repented not:

Manx: 21 Smerg dhyts, Chorazin, smerg dhyts, Vethsaida: son dy beagh ny obbraghyn yyndyssagh er ny ve jeant ayns Tyre as Sidon, t’er ve jeant ayndivish, veagh ad er ghoall arrys foddey er dy henney, ayns aanrit sack as leoai.
English: 21 Woe unto thee, Chorazin! woe unto thee, Bethsaida! for if the mighty works, which were done in you, had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago in sackcloth and ashes.

Manx: 22 Agh ta mee gra riu, dy bee kerraghey s’eddrymmee er ny choyrt er Tyre as Sidon ec laa ny briwnys, ny vees er ny choyrt erriuish.
English: 22 But I say unto you, It shall be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon at the day of judgment, than for you.

Manx: 23 As uss Capernaum, ta dt’ooashley roshtin gys niau, bee oo er dty hilgey sheese gys nivrin; son dy beagh ny obbraghyn yyndyssagh er ve jeant ayns Sodom, t’er ve jeant aynyds, veagh eh er ve er-mayrn gys y laa t’ayn jiu.
English: 23 And thou, Capernaum, which art exalted unto heaven, shalt be brought down to hell: for if the mighty works, which have been done in thee, had been done in Sodom, it would have remained until this day.

Manx: 24 Agh ta mee gra riu, dy bee kerraghey s’eddrymmee er ny choyrt er talloo Sodom ec laa ny briwnys, ny vees orts.
English: 24 But I say unto you, That it shall be more tolerable for the land of Sodom in the day of judgment, than for thee.

Manx: 25 ¶ Ec y tra shen, dreggyr Yeesey as doort e, Ta mee cur booise dhyt, O Ayr, Hiarn niau as talloo, er-yn-oyr dy vel oo er chieltyn ny reddyn shoh vowsyn ta creeney as tushtagh, as dy vel oo er hoilshaghey ad da ooikanyn.
English: 25 At that time Jesus answered and said, I thank thee, O Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast revealed them unto babes.

Manx: 26 Shen dy jarroo myr te, Ayr, son shen myr ve mie ayns dty hilleys.
English: 26 Even so, Father: for so it seemed good in thy sight.

Manx: 27 Ta dy chooilley nee er ny livrey doos liorish my Ayr: as cha nione da dooinney erbee yn mac, agh yn Ayr: cha-moo shione da dooinney erbee yn Ayr, agh y mac, as eshyn da nee yn mac e y hoilshaghey.
English: 27 All things are delivered unto me of my Father: and no man knoweth the Son, but the Father; neither knoweth any man the Father, save the Son, and he to whomsoever the Son will reveal him.

Manx: 28 ¶ Tar-jee hyms ooilley shiuish ta laboragh as ta laadit dy trome, as neems shiu y ooraghey.
English: 28 Come unto me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.

Manx: 29 Gow-jee my whing erriu, as ynsee-jee voyms, son ta mee meen as imlee ayns spyrryd: as yiow shiu fea da nyn anmeenyn.
English: 29 Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart: and ye shall find rest unto your souls.

Manx: 30 Son ta my whing aashagh, as my errey eddrym.
English: 30 For my yoke is easy, and my burden is light.

Manx: CAB. XII.
English: Matthew Chapter 12

Manx: 1 Ec y tra shen, hie Yeesey trooid arroo er y doonaght, as var adsyn va sheer geyrt er accryssagh, as ren ad toshiaght dy phluckey jeeasyn jeh’n arroo, as dy ee.
English: 1 At that time Jesus went on the sabbath day through the corn; and his disciples were an hungred, and began to pluck the ears of corn, and to eat.

Manx: 2 Agh tra honnick ny Phariseyn ad, doort ad rish, Cur-my-ner ta’n vooinjer ta kinjagh geyrt ort, janoo red nagh vel lowit dy ve jeant er y doonaght.
English: 2 But when the Pharisees saw it, they said unto him, Behold, thy disciples do that which is not lawful to do upon the sabbath day.

Manx: 3 Agh doort eshyn roo, Nagh vel shiuish er lhaih, cre ren David, tra ve hene as e heshaght accryssagh,
English: 3 But he said unto them, Have ye not read what David did, when he was an hungred, and they that were with him;

Manx: 4 Kys hie e stiagh ayns thie Yee, as die e yn arran casherick, nagh row lowit dashyn ny da’n vooinjer va marish dy ee, agh da ny saggyrtyn ny lomarcan.
English: 4 How he entered into the house of God, and did eat the shewbread, which was not lawful for him to eat, neither for them which were with him, but only for the priests?

Manx: 5 Ny, nagh vel shiu er lhaih ayns y leigh, kys er laghyn y doonaght ta ny saggyrtyn ayns y chiamble brishey’n doonaght, as foast cha vel peccah er ny choyrt nyn lieh.
English: 5 Or have ye not read in the law, how that on the sabbath days the priests in the temple profane the sabbath, and are blameless?

Manx: 6 Agh ta mish gra riu, dy vel ayns shoh fer syrjey ny’n chiamble.
English: 6 But I say unto you, That in this place is one greater than the temple.

Manx: 7 Agh dy beagh fys er ve eavish, cre ta dy ve toiggit liorish y raa shoh, Ta mee ny sbooie er myghin ny oural, cha beagh shiu er gheyrey yn vooinjer niau-chyndagh.
English: 7 But if ye had known what this meaneth, I will have mercy, and not sacrifice, ye would not have condemned the guiltless.

Manx: 8 Son ta mac y dooinney ny Hiarn, er y doonaght hene.
English: 8 For the Son of man is Lord even of the sabbath day.

Manx: 9 As tra ve er gholl veih shen, hie e stiagh ayns y cheell oc.
English: 9 And when he was departed thence, he went into their synagogue:

Manx: 10 ¶ As cur-my-ner va dooinney ayns shen va’n laue echey er shyrgaghey, as, dy voddagh oyr y ve oc dy loart noi Yeesey, denee ad jeh, gra, Vel eh lowal dy leihys er laghyn y doonaght?
English: 10 And, behold, there was a man which had his hand withered. And they asked him, saying, Is it lawful to heal on the sabbath days? that they might accuse him.

Manx: 11 As doort e roo, Quoi’n dooinney nyn mast eavish, vees ynn cheyrrey echey, as my huittys ee ayns jeeg er y doonaght, nagh daar e greme urree, as nagh drog e ass ee?
English: 11 And he said unto them, What man shall there be among you, that shall have one sheep, and if it fall into a pit on the sabbath day, will he not lay hold on it, and lift it out?

Manx: 12 Nagh vel dooinney eisht foddey share ny keyrrey? Shen-y-fa te lowal dy yanoo mie er y doonaght.
English: 12 How much then is a man better than a sheep? Wherefore it is lawful to do well on the sabbath days.

Manx: 13 Eishtagh doort e rish y dooinney, Sheen magh dty laue, as heen e magh ee, as va’n laue echey er ny leihys myr y laue elley.
English: 13 Then saith he to the man, Stretch forth thine hand. And he stretched it forth; and it was restored whole, like as the other.

Manx: 14 ¶ Eishtagh hie ny Phariseyn magh, as hug ad nyn goyrle dy cheilley noi, my-chione yn aght oddagh ad e y stroie.
English: 14 Then the Pharisees went out, and held a council against him, how they might destroy him.

Manx: 15 Agh tra va fys ec Yeesey er, jimmee e veih shen: as deiyr earrooyn moarey dy leih er, as ren e ad ooilley y leihys.
English: 15 But when Jesus knew it, he withdrew himself from thence: and great multitudes followed him, and he healed them all;

Manx: 16 As hug e currym daue, gyn ad dy vrah e.
English: 16 And charged them that they should not make him known:

Manx: 17 Dy voddagh ve cooilleenit ny va loarit liorish Esaias y phadeyr, gra,
English: 17 That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by Esaias the prophet, saying,

Manx: 18 Cur-my-ner, my harvaant ta mee er ny reih, my er-ghraihagh jeh ta mee dy moar soiaghey ayns m’annym; nee yn spyrryd aym vaghey ayn, as soilshee e briwnys da ny ashoonyn.
English: 18 Behold my servant, whom I have chosen; my beloved, in whom my soul is well pleased: I will put my spirit upon him, and he shall shew judgment to the Gentiles.

Manx: 19 Cha jean e streeu, ny keaney, cha-moo chlinnys annane erbee e choraa ayns ny straadjyn.
English: 19 He shall not strive, nor cry; neither shall any man hear his voice in the streets.

Manx: 20 Cuirtlagh vroojit cha jean e y vrishey, as lieen vees jaagh jeh, cha jean e y vooghey, derrey ver e magh briwnys lesh barriaght.
English: 20 A bruised reed shall he not break, and smoking flax shall he not quench, till he send forth judgment unto victory.

Manx: 21 As ayns yn ennym echey, nee ny Ashoonyn quaagh treshteil.
English: 21 And in his name shall the Gentiles trust.

Manx: 22 ¶ Eishtagh hoie ad kiongoyrt rish dooinney va drogh spyrryd ayn, as ve doall as balloo: as laanee e e, ayns wheesh as dy ren eshyn va doall as balloo chammah loart as fakin.
English: 22 Then was brought unto him one possessed with a devil, blind, and dumb: and he healed him, insomuch that the blind and dumb both spake and saw.

Manx: 23 As ghow ooilley’n pobble yyndyss, as doort ad, Nagh nee shoh mac Ghavid?
English: 23 And all the people were amazed, and said, Is not this the son of David?

Manx: 24 Agh tra cheayl ny Phariseyn jeh, doort ad, Cha vel e shoh tilgey magh drogh spyrrydyn, agh liorish Beelzebub, prince ny drogh spyrrydyn.
English: 24 But when the Pharisees heard it, they said, This fellow doth not cast out devils, but by Beelzebub the prince of the devils.

Manx: 25 As va fys ec Yeesey er ny smooinaghtyn oc, as doort e roo, Ta dy chooilley reeriaght ta girree magh ny oi hene er ny choyrt mow; as cha vod ard-valley ny thie erbee ta girree magh ny oi hene, shassoo.
English: 25 And Jesus knew their thoughts, and said unto them, Every kingdom divided against itself is brought to desolation; and every city or house divided against itself shall not stand:

Manx: 26 As my ta’n Jouyl tilgey magh Jouyl, te girree magh ny oi hene, kys eisht oddys y reeriaght echey shassoo?
English: 26 And if Satan cast out Satan, he is divided against himself; how shall then his kingdom stand?

Manx: 27 As my ta mish liorish Beelzebub tilgey magh drogh spyrrydyn, quoi liorish ta nyn gloan hene dyn dilgey ad magh? adsyn er-y-fa shen vees ny briwnyn eu.
English: 27 And if I by Beelzebub cast out devils, by whom do your children cast them out? therefore they shall be your judges.

Manx: 28 Agh my ta mish geyrt magh drogh spyrrydyn liorish spyrryd Yee, eisht ta reeriaght Yee er jeet hiu.
English: 28 But if I cast out devils by the Spirit of God, then the kingdom of God is come unto you.

Manx: 29 Er nonney kys oddys peccagh goll stiagh ayns thie dooinney lajer, as e chooid y ghoal liorish roosteraght, mannagh gianle e hoshiaght yn dooinney lajer? as eisht nee e e hie y roostey.
English: 29 Or else how can one enter into a strong man's house, and spoil his goods, except he first bind the strong man? and then he will spoil his house.

Manx: 30 Eshyn nagh vel liam, te m’oi; as eshyn nagh vel chymsaghey mârym, te skeylley.
English: 30 He that is not with me is against me; and he that gathereth not with me scattereth abroad.

Manx: 31 ¶ Shen-y-fa ta mee gra riu, Bee dy chooilley pheccah as raa mollaghtagh er ny leih da deney; agh goan mollaghtagh noi’n spyrryd noo cha bee er nyn leih da deney.
English: 31 Wherefore I say unto you, All manner of sin and blasphemy shall be forgiven unto men: but the blasphemy against the Holy Ghost shall not be forgiven unto men.

Manx: 32 As quoi-erbee loarys fockle noi yn mac dooinney, bee eh er ny leih da: agh quoi-erbee loarys noi yn spyrryd noo, cha bee eh er ny leih da, edyr ayns y teihl shoh, ny ayns y teihl ta ry heet.
English: 32 And whosoever speaketh a word against the Son of man, it shall be forgiven him: but whosoever speaketh against the Holy Ghost, it shall not be forgiven him, neither in this world, neither in the world to come.

Manx: 33 Edyr jean-jee yn billey mie, as e vess mie; er nonney jean-jee yn billey olk, as e vess olk: son liorish e vess, ta enney er ny choyrt er y villey.
English: 33 Either make the tree good, and his fruit good; or else make the tree corrupt, and his fruit corrupt: for the tree is known by his fruit.

Manx: 34 O heeloghe dy ard-nieughyn, kys oddys shiuish, ta olk, reddyn mie y loart? son magh veih stoyr y chree, ta’n beeal loart.
English: 34 O generation of vipers, how can ye, being evil, speak good things? for out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaketh.

Manx: 35 Ta dooinney mie, ass stoyr mie yn chree echey, cur magh reddyn mie; as drogh ghooinney ass y drogh stoyr cur magh drogh reddyn.
English: 35 A good man out of the good treasure of the heart bringeth forth good things: and an evil man out of the evil treasure bringeth forth evil things.

Manx: 36 Agh ta mee gra riu, dy chooilley ockle niau-chooie nee deney y loart, dy der ad coontey er y hon, ec laa ny briwnys.
English: 36 But I say unto you, That every idle word that men shall speak, they shall give account thereof in the day of judgment.

Manx: 37 Son liorish dty ghoan vees oo er dty heyrey, as liorish dty ghoan vees oo er dty gheyrey.
English: 37 For by thy words thou shalt be justified, and by thy words thou shalt be condemned.

Manx: 38 ¶ Eisht dreggyr shiartance jeh ny scruderyn as jeh ny Phariseyn, gra, Vainshter, baillin cowrey y akin woid.
English: 38 Then certain of the scribes and of the Pharisees answered, saying, Master, we would see a sign from thee.

Manx: 39 Agh dreggyr eshyn, as doort e roo, she sheeloghe olk as maardyragh ta shirrey cowrey, as cha bee cowrey erbee er ny chur daue, agh cowrey yn phadeyr Jonas.
English: 39 But he answered and said unto them, An evil and adulterous generation seeketh after a sign; and there shall no sign be given to it, but the sign of the prophet Jonas:

Manx: 40 Son ’naght myr va Jonas tree laa as tree uiyghyn ayns bolg y whale: myr shen bee mac y dooinney tree laa as tree uiyghyn ayns cree’n tallooin.
English: 40 For as Jonas was three days and three nights in the whale's belly; so shall the Son of man be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth.

Manx: 41 Nee deney Nineveh girree seose ayns briwnys, as y cheeloghe shoh y gheyrey, er-yn-oyr dy ghow ad arrys ec preacheil Jonas, as cur-my-ner, ta fer smoo ny Jonas ayns shoh.
English: 41 The men of Nineveh shall rise in judgment with this generation, and shall condemn it: because they repented at the preaching of Jonas; and, behold, a greater than Jonas is here.

Manx: 42 Nee ben-rein y jass girree seose ayns briwnys noi yn cheeloghe shoh, as ad y gheyrey: son haink ish veih ny ardjyn sodjey er y talloo, dy eashtagh rish creenaght Solomon, as cur-my-ner ta fer smoo ny Solomon ayns shoh.
English: 42 The queen of the south shall rise up in the judgment with this generation, and shall condemn it: for she came from the uttermost parts of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon; and, behold, a greater than Solomon is here.

Manx: 43 Tra ta’n spyrryd niau-ghlen er gholl ass dooinney, te shooyl trooid ynnydyn chyrmey, shirrey fea, as cha vel e dy gheddyn eh.
English: 43 When the unclean spirit is gone out of a man, he walketh through dry places, seeking rest, and findeth none.

Manx: 44 Eishtagh te gra, Chyndaa-ym gys my hie, ass haink mee, as tra te cheet, te dy gheddyn eh follym, sceabit as soit magh dy stoamey.
English: 44 Then he saith, I will return into my house from whence I came out; and when he is come, he findeth it empty, swept, and garnished.

Manx: 45 Eisht te goll, as cur lesh marish shiaght spyrrydyn elley ta ny smessey ny e hene, as ta’d goll stiagh as vaghey ayns shen: as ta’n jerrey ny smessey da’n dooinney shen ny’n toshiaght, As shoh myr nee eh taghert da’n drogh heeloghe shoh.
English: 45 Then goeth he, and taketh with himself seven other spirits more wicked than himself, and they enter in and dwell there: and the last state of that man is worse than the first. Even so shall it be also unto this wicked generation.

Manx: 46 ¶ Choud as ve foast loart rish y pobble, cur-my-ner va e voir as e vraaraghyn nyn shassoo mooie, shirrey loart rish.
English: 46 While he yet talked to the people, behold, his mother and his brethren stood without, desiring to speak with him.

Manx: 47 Eishtagh doort fer rish, Cur-my-ner ta dty voir as dty vraaraghyn nyn shassoo mooie, as ta’d booiaght loart rhyt.
English: 47 Then one said unto him, Behold, thy mother and thy brethren stand without, desiring to speak with thee.

Manx: 48 Agh dreggyr eshyn yn fer dinsh shoh da, gra, Quoi my voir? as quoi my vraaraghyn?
English: 48 But he answered and said unto him that told him, Who is my mother? and who are my brethren?

Manx: 49 As heen e magh e laue hucsyn va sheer geyrt er, as doort e, Cur-my-ner my voir as my vraaraghyn.
English: 49 And he stretched forth his hand toward his disciples, and said, Behold my mother and my brethren!

Manx: 50 Son quoi-erbee nee aigney my Ayr t’ayns niau, e shen my vraar as my huyr as my voir.
English: 50 For whosoever shall do the will of my Father which is in heaven, the same is my brother, and sister, and mother.

Manx: CAB. XIII.
English: Matthew Chapter 13

Manx: 1 Yn laa keddyn hie Yeesey magh ass y thie, as hoie e sheese rish oirr ny marrey.
English: 1 The same day went Jesus out of the house, and sat by the sea side.

Manx: 2 As va earrooyn moarey dy leih er nyn jaglym cooidjagh huggey, myr shen dy jagh e seose ayns long, as hoie e, as va ooilley’n pobble nyn shassoo er y traie.
English: 2 And great multitudes were gathered together unto him, so that he went into a ship, and sat; and the whole multitude stood on the shore.

Manx: 3 As loar e ymmodee dy reddyn roo ayns coraaghyn dorraghey, gra, Cur-my-ner hie corryder magh dy chuirr.
English: 3 And he spake many things unto them in parables, saying, Behold, a sower went forth to sow;

Manx: 4 As myr ve cuirr, huit part jeh’n rass rish oirr y raad, as haink ny eeanlee as die ad seose eh.
English: 4 And when he sowed, some seeds fell by the way side, and the fowls came and devoured them up:

Manx: 5 Huit part ayns ynnydyn claghagh, raad nagh row cooid woar dy ooir echey, as chelleeragh daase eh, er-y-fa nagh row divnit tallooin echey.
English: 5 Some fell upon stony places, where they had not much earth: and forthwith they sprung up, because they had no deepness of earth:

Manx: 6 As ghow niart ny greiney yn soo ass, as er-yn-oyr nagh row eh er ghoal fraue, hie eh naardey.
English: 6 And when the sun was up, they were scorched; and because they had no root, they withered away.

Manx: 7 As huit part mastey drinyn; as daase ny drinyn seose as hoght ad eh.
English: 7 And some fell among thorns; and the thorns sprung up, and choked them:

Manx: 8 Agh huit cooid elley jeh ayns talloo mie, as dymmyrk eh mess, part keead filley, part three feed filley, as part jeih fillaghyn as feed.
English: 8 But other fell into good ground, and brought forth fruit, some an hundredfold, some sixtyfold, some thirtyfold.

Manx: 9 Eshyn ta cleashyn echey dy chlashtyn, lig e clashtyn.
English: 9 Who hath ears to hear, let him hear.

Manx: 10 As haink y vooinjer va sheer geyrt er, as doort ad rish, Cre’n fa t’ow loart roo ayns coraaghyn dorraghey?
English: 10 And the disciples came, and said unto him, Why speakest thou unto them in parables?

Manx: 11 Dreggyr eshyn as doort e roo, Er-yn-oyr dy vel eh er ny choyrt divish folliaghtyn reeriaght niau y hoiggal, agh dauesyn cha vel eh er ny choyrt.
English: 11 He answered and said unto them, Because it is given unto you to know the mysteries of the kingdom of heaven, but to them it is not given.

Manx: 12 Son quoi-erbee ta echey, dashyn vees er ny choyrt, as bee towse smoo echey: agh quoi-erbee nagh vel echey, veihsyn vees shen ny ta echey er ny ghoal ersooyl.
English: 12 For whosoever hath, to him shall be given, and he shall have more abundance: but whosoever hath not, from him shall be taken away even that he hath.

Manx: 13 Shen-y-fa ta mee loart roo ayns coraaghyn dorraghey; er-yn-oyr fakin, nagh vel ad fakin, as clashtyn nagh vel ad clashtyn, cha-moo ta’d toiggal.
English: 13 Therefore speak I to them in parables: because they seeing see not; and hearing they hear not, neither do they understand.

Manx: 14 As ayndoosyn ta cooilleenit phaderys Esaias, ta gra, Liorish clashtyn nee shiu clashtyn, as cha jean shiu toiggal, as fakin, nee shiu fakin, as cha gronnee shiu.
English: 14 And in them is fulfilled the prophecy of Esaias, which saith, By hearing ye shall hear, and shall not understand; and seeing ye shall see, and shall not perceive:

Manx: 15 Son ta cree yn pobble shoh er naase roauyr, as ta ny cleashyn oc moal dy chlashtyn, as ny sooyllyn oc, ta’d er neigh, er aggle dy vaikagh ad lesh nyn sooyllyn, as dy glinnagh ad lesh nyn gleashyn, as dy doiggagh ad lesh nyn gree, as dy beagh ad er nyn jyndaa, as dy jinnin ad y leihys.
English: 15 For this people's heart is waxed gross, and their ears are dull of hearing, and their eyes they have closed; lest at any time they should see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and should understand with their heart, and should be converted, and I should heal them.

Manx: 16 Agh bannit ta ny sooyllyn eavish, son ta’d fakin, as ny cleashyn eu, son ta’d clashtyn.
English: 16 But blessed are your eyes, for they see: and your ears, for they hear.

Manx: 17 Son dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy vel ymmodee phaderyn as deney cairagh er ve aignagh dy akin ny reddyn ta shiuish dy akin, as cha vel ad er nyn vakin ad; as dy chlashtyn ny reddyn ta shiu dy chlashtyn, as cha vel ad er chlashtyn ad.
English: 17 For verily I say unto you, That many prophets and righteous men have desired to see those things which ye see, and have not seen them; and to hear those things which ye hear, and have not heard them.

Manx: 18 ¶ Clasht-jee er-y-fa shen coraa dorraghey’n corryder.
English: 18 Hear ye therefore the parable of the sower.

Manx: 19 Fer erbee dy vel clashtyn goo yn reeriaght, as nagh vel dy hoiggal eh, ta’n drogh er cheet as tayrtyn lesh shen ny va cuirt ayns e chree: shoh e ghow yn rass rish oirr y raad.
English: 19 When any one heareth the word of the kingdom, and understandeth it not, then cometh the wicked one, and catcheth away that which was sown in his heart. This is he which received seed by the way side.

Manx: 20 Agh eshyn ghow yn rass ayns ynnydyn claghagh, yn fer ta clashtyn yn goo, as ayns y tullogh lesh boggey dy ghoall eh:
English: 20 But he that received the seed into stony places, the same is he that heareth the word, and anon with joy receiveth it;

Manx: 21 Foast cha vel fraue echey ayn hene, agh te cummal rish son tammylt: agh tra ta seaghyn ny tranlaase cheet er, er coontey’n ghoo, chelleeragh ta e chredjue falail.
English: 21 Yet hath he not root in himself, but dureth for a while: for when tribulation or persecution ariseth because of the word, by and by he is offended.

Manx: 22 Eshyn myrgeddyn ghow yn rass mastey ny drinyn, yn fer ta clashtyn y goo: as ta kiarrail y teihll shoh as moalteraght berchys plooghey’n goo, as te cheet dy ve niau-vessoil.
English: 22 He also that received seed among the thorns is he that heareth the word; and the care of this world, and the deceitfulness of riches, choke the word, and he becometh unfruitful.

Manx: 23 Agh eshyn ghow yn rass ayns talloo mie, yn fer ta clashtyn y goo as dy hoiggal eh, as te tilgey mess as gymmyrkey, part keead filley, part tree feed, as part jeih fillaghyn as feed.
English: 23 But he that received seed into the good ground is he that heareth the word, and understandeth it; which also beareth fruit, and bringeth forth, some an hundredfold, some sixty, some thirty.

Manx: 24 ¶ Coraa dorraghey elley loar e roo, gra, Ta reeriaght niau er ny holaghey gys dooinney, chuirr rass mie ayns e vagher:
English: 24 Another parable put he forth unto them, saying, The kingdom of heaven is likened unto a man which sowed good seed in his field:

Manx: 25 Agh choud as va sleih nyn gadley, haink e noid, as chuirr e coggyl mastey’n churnaght, as jimmee e roish.
English: 25 But while men slept, his enemy came and sowed tares among the wheat, and went his way.

Manx: 26 Agh tra va’n chass er naase, as er gholl my yeish, eisht haink y coggyl rish myrgeddyn.
English: 26 But when the blade was sprung up, and brought forth fruit, then appeared the tares also.

Manx: 27 Er shen haink fir-vooinjerey yn far-thie, as doort ad rish, Vainshter, nagh chuirr uss rass mie ayns dty vagher? cre woish eisht ta’n coggyl t’ayn?
English: 27 So the servants of the householder came and said unto him, Sir, didst not thou sow good seed in thy field? from whence then hath it tares?

Manx: 28 Doort eshyn roo, Noid t’er nianoo shoh. Doort ny fir-vooinjerey rish, nailt eisht shin dy gholl as dy heigh ass eh?
English: 28 He said unto them, An enemy hath done this. The servants said unto him, Wilt thou then that we go and gather them up?

Manx: 29 Agh doort eshyn, Ny jean-jee, er aggle, ayns teigh yn coggyl, dy dayrn shiu yn churnaght ass ny frauyn marish.
English: 29 But he said, Nay; lest while ye gather up the tares, ye root up also the wheat with them.

Manx: 30 Lig-jee daue ny neesht gaase cooidjagh derrey’n fouyr: as ayns earish yn ouyr jirryms rish ny beayneeyn, Chymsee-jee cooidjagh hoshiaght yn coggyl ayns bunneenyn ry hoi y lostey; agh chaglee-jee yn churnaght stiagh ayns my hoalt.
English: 30 Let both grow together until the harvest: and in the time of harvest I will say to the reapers, Gather ye together first the tares, and bind them in bundles to burn them: but gather the wheat into my barn.

Manx: 31 ¶ Coraa dorraghey elley loar e roo, gra, Ta reeriaght niau goll rish greine dy rass mustard, ren dooinney y ghoal as y chuirr ayns e vagher.
English: 31 Another parable put he forth unto them, saying, The kingdom of heaven is like to a grain of mustard seed, which a man took, and sowed in his field:

Manx: 32 As ga dy nee eh sloo jeh dy chooilley rass: foast tra te er naase, eh smoo ta mastey lossyreeyn, as te cheet dy ve ny villey; myr shen dy vel eeanlee’n aer cheet, as goall fastee ayns ny banglanyn echey.
English: 32 Which indeed is the least of all seeds: but when it is grown, it is the greatest among herbs, and becometh a tree, so that the birds of the air come and lodge in the branches thereof.

Manx: 33 ¶ Coraa dorraghey elley loar e roo, Ta reeriaght niau goll rish soorit, ren ben y ghoal as y ollaghey ayns three towsyn dy veinn, derrey ve ooilley soor.
English: 33 Another parable spake he unto them; The kingdom of heaven is like unto leaven, which a woman took, and hid in three measures of meal, till the whole was leavened.

Manx: 34 Ooilley ny reddyn shoh loar Yeesey rish y pobble ayns coraaghyn dorraghey, as fegooish coraa dorraghey, cha loar e roo:
English: 34 All these things spake Jesus unto the multitude in parables; and without a parable spake he not unto them:

Manx: 35 Dy voddagh shen ve cooilleenit va loarit liorish y phadeyr, gra, Foslym my veeal dy loart coraaghyn dorraghey, soilshee-ym magh reddyn t’er ve follit er dy hoshiaght y teihll.
English: 35 That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet, saying, I will open my mouth in parables; I will utter things which have been kept secret from the foundation of the world.

Manx: 36 Eishtagh hug Yeesey yn cheshaght ersooyl, as hie e stiagh ayns y thie; as haink huggey adsyn va sheer marish, gra, Soilshee dooin coraa dorraghey coggyl yn vagher.
English: 36 Then Jesus sent the multitude away, and went into the house: and his disciples came unto him, saying, Declare unto us the parable of the tares of the field.

Manx: 37 Dreggyr eshyn as doort e roo, Eshyn chuir yn rass mie, yn mac dooinney:
English: 37 He answered and said unto them, He that soweth the good seed is the Son of man;

Manx: 38 Yn magher y seihl: yn rass mie cloan y reeriaght: agh yn coggyl cloan y drogh er:
English: 38 The field is the world; the good seed are the children of the kingdom; but the tares are the children of the wicked one;

Manx: 39 Yn noid chuir ad yn Jouyl: yn fouyr jerrey’n teihl: as ny beayneeyn ny ainlyn.
English: 39 The enemy that sowed them is the devil; the harvest is the end of the world; and the reapers are the angels.

Manx: 40 Myr er-y-fa shen ta’n coggyl er ny haglym as er ny lostey ayns yn aile; myr shen vees eh ec jerrey’n teihl.
English: 40 As therefore the tares are gathered and burned in the fire; so shall it be in the end of this world.

Manx: 41 Ver yn mac dooinney magh e ainlyn, as teighee ad ass e reeriaght dy chooilley nee ta tayrn sleih gys peccah as adsyn ta cur rish yn olk;
English: 41 The Son of man shall send forth his angels, and they shall gather out of his kingdom all things that offend, and them which do iniquity;

Manx: 42 As tilgee ad ad ayns coirrey ailagh: ayns shen vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn.
English: 42 And shall cast them into a furnace of fire: there shall be wailing and gnashing of teeth.

Manx: 43 Eishtagh nee yn chloan chairagh soilshain magh myr y ghrian ayns reeriaght nyn Ayrey. Eshyn ta cleashyn echey dy chlashtyn, lig e clashtyn.
English: 43 Then shall the righteous shine forth as the sun in the kingdom of their Father. Who hath ears to hear, let him hear.

Manx: 44 ¶ Reeshtagh ta reeriaght niau goll rish berchys va follit ayns magher: yn verchys keddyn tra ta dooinney dy gheddyn magh, te dy choodaghey eh, as ayns boggey jeh, te goll as creck ooilley ny t’echey as kionnaghey’n magher shen.
English: 44 Again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto treasure hid in a field; the which when a man hath found, he hideth, and for joy thereof goeth and selleth all that he hath, and buyeth that field.

Manx: 45 Reeshtagh ta reeriaght niau goll rish merchand va shirrey pearlyn mie:
English: 45 Again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto a merchant man, seeking goodly pearls:

Manx: 46 As tra ve er gheddyn yn phearl dy phrice woar, hie e as chreck e ooilley ny v’echey, as chionnee e eh.
English: 46 Who, when he had found one pearl of great price, went and sold all that he had, and bought it.

Manx: 47 ¶ Reeshtagh ta reeriaght niau goll rish lieen, va tilgit magh ’sy cheayn, as ghow jeh dy chooilley horch dy eeast.
English: 47 Again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto a net, that was cast into the sea, and gathered of every kind:

Manx: 48 As tra ve laane, hayrn ad eh gys talloo, as hoie ad sheese, as haue ad yn eeast mie ayns siyn, agh chaeu ad yn drogh eeast ersooyl.
English: 48 Which, when it was full, they drew to shore, and sat down, and gathered the good into vessels, but cast the bad away.

Manx: 49 Myr shen vees eh, ec jerrey’n teihl: hig ny ainlyn magh, as scarree ad y vee-chrauee veih mastey’n chloan chairagh;
English: 49 So shall it be at the end of the world: the angels shall come forth, and sever the wicked from among the just,

Manx: 50 As tilgee ad ad ayns coirrey dy aile: ayns shen vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn.
English: 50 And shall cast them into the furnace of fire: there shall be wailing and gnashing of teeth.

Manx: 51 Doort Yeesey roo, Vel shiu er hoiggal ooilley ny reddyn shoh? Doort adsyn rish, Ta shin, Hiarn.
English: 51 Jesus saith unto them, Have ye understood all these things? They say unto him, Yea, Lord.

Manx: 52 Eishtagh doort e roo, shen-y-fa ta dy chooilley scrudere ta ynsit gys reeriaght niau, goll rish dooinney ta ny ar-thie, ta cur magh ass y stoyr echey reddyn noa as shen.
English: 52 Then said he unto them, Therefore every scribe which is instructed unto the kingdom of heaven is like unto a man that is an householder, which bringeth forth out of his treasure things new and old.

Manx: 53 ¶ As haink eh gy kione, tra va Yeesey erreish ny coraaghyn dorraghey shoh y loart, dy jimmee e veih shen.
English: 53 And it came to pass, that when Jesus had finished these parables, he departed thence.

Manx: 54 As tra ve er jeet gys e heer hene, dynsee e ad ayns ny kialteenyn oc, ayns wheesh as dy row ad atchimagh, as dy doort ad, Cre woish ta creenaght as mirillyn y dooinney shoh?
English: 54 And when he was come into his own country, he taught them in their synagogue, insomuch that they were astonished, and said, Whence hath this man this wisdom, and these mighty works?

Manx: 55 Nagh nee shoh mac y seyr? Nagh vel e voir enmyssit Moirrey, as e vraaraghyn Jamys as Joses, as Simon, as Judas?
English: 55 Is not this the carpenter's son? is not his mother called Mary? and his brethren, James, and Joses, and Simon, and Judas?

Manx: 56 As nagh vel ny shairaghyn echey ooilley marin? cre woish eisht ta ooilley ny reddyn t’ec y dooinney shoh.
English: 56 And his sisters, are they not all with us? Whence then hath this man all these things?

Manx: 57 As var ad jymmoosagh rish. Agh doort Yeesey roo, Cha vel phadeyr fegooish ooashley, cheu-mooie jeh ayns e heer hene as ayns e hie hene.
English: 57 And they were offended in him. But Jesus said unto them, A prophet is not without honour, save in his own country, and in his own house.

Manx: 58 As cha nimmey miril dobbree e ayns shen, kyndagh rish y vee-chredjue oc.
English: 58 And he did not many mighty works there because of their unbelief.

Manx: CAB. XIV.
English: Matthew Chapter 14

Manx: 1 Ec y tra shen, cheayl Herod yn Tetrarch jeh Goo Yeesey,
English: 1 At that time Herod the tetrarch heard of the fame of Jesus,

Manx: 2 As doort e rish e harvaantyn, Shoh Ean Bashtey; te er nirree veih ny merriu, as er-yn-oyr shen ta mirillyn er nyn obbraghey liorish.
English: 2 And said unto his servants, This is John the Baptist; he is risen from the dead; and therefore mighty works do shew forth themselves in him.

Manx: 3 ¶ Son va Herod er ghoal Ean, as er chiangley, as er hilgey e ayns pryssoon, kyndagh rish Herodias, ben e vraar Philip.
English: 3 For Herod had laid hold on John, and bound him, and put him in prison for Herodias' sake, his brother Philip's wife.

Manx: 4 Son va Ean er ghra rish, Cha vel eh lowit dhyt, ee y ve ayd son ben.
English: 4 For John said unto him, It is not lawful for thee to have her.

Manx: 5 As tra ballish ve’r choyrt e gy baase, ve ayns aggle roish y pobble, er-y-fa dy row ad dy ghoal e son phadeyr.
English: 5 And when he would have put him to death, he feared the multitude, because they counted him as a prophet.

Manx: 6 Agh er y laa v’er ny realley corrym rish y laa ruggyr Herod, ghonse inneen Herodias ayns yn eanish oc as ghow Herod laane boggey jee.
English: 6 But when Herod's birthday was kept, the daughter of Herodias danced before them, and pleased Herod.

Manx: 7 As yioal e lesh loo, dy jinnagh e jee red erbee dy shirragh ee.
English: 7 Whereupon he promised with an oath to give her whatsoever she would ask.

Manx: 8 As doort ish, myr va e moir er chur roie, Cur dou ayns shoh kione Ean Bashtey er claare.
English: 8 And she, being before instructed of her mother, said, Give me here John Baptist's head in a charger.

Manx: 9 As huit y Ree ayns trimshey: ny yei er coontey yn loo, as y vooinjer v’ec gien marish, hug e sarey, eh dy ve er ny choyrt jee.
English: 9 And the king was sorry: nevertheless for the oath's sake, and them which sat with him at meat, he commanded it to be given her.

Manx: 10 As hug e fys, yn kione dy ve’r ny ghoal jeh Ean ayns y phryssoon.
English: 10 And he sent, and beheaded John in the prison.

Manx: 11 As va’n kione er ny choyrt er claare as livreit dys y ven aeg, as hug ish lieie eh gys e moir.
English: 11 And his head was brought in a charger, and given to the damsel: and she brought it to her mother.

Manx: 12 As haink y vooinjer va sheer geyrt er, as hrog ad y corp, as doanluck ad eh, as hie ad as dinsh ad da Yeesey.
English: 12 And his disciples came, and took up the body, and buried it, and went and told Jesus.

Manx: 13 ¶ Tra cheayl Yeesey jeh, jimmee e veih shen ayns long gys ynnyd-faasagh er lieh, as tra cheayl y pobble jeh, deiyr ad er rish nyn gosh ass ny ard-valjyn.
English: 13 When Jesus heard of it, he departed thence by ship into a desert place apart: and when the people had heard thereof, they followed him on foot out of the cities.

Manx: 14 As hie Yeesey magh, as honnick e chaglym moar dy leih, as ve er ny veyghey lesh chymmey orroo, as laanee e adsyn va ching.
English: 14 And Jesus went forth, and saw a great multitude, and was moved with compassion toward them, and he healed their sick.

Manx: 15 As tra va’n fastyr ayn, haink huggey adsyn va sheer geyrt er, gra, She boal faasagh shoh, as ta’n tra nish er gholl shiaghey; lig y raad da’n cheshaght, dy vod ad goll rowe gys ny baljyn beggey, as beaghey y chionnaghey daue hene.
English: 15 And when it was evening, his disciples came to him, saying, This is a desert place, and the time is now past; send the multitude away, that they may go into the villages, and buy themselves victuals.

Manx: 16 Agh doort Yeesey roo, Cha lias daue goll rowe, cur-jee shiuish bee daue.
English: 16 But Jesus said unto them, They need not depart; give ye them to eat.

Manx: 17 As doort ad rish, Cha vel ain ayns shoh agh queg bwilleenyn as daa eeast.
English: 17 And they say unto him, We have here but five loaves, and two fishes.

Manx: 18 Doort eshyn, Cur-jee lieu ad ayns shoh hyms.
English: 18 He said, Bring them hither to me.

Manx: 19 As hug e sarey da’n pobble dy hoie sheese er y faiyr, as ghow e ny queg bwilleenyn as y daa eeast, as yeagh e seose gys niau, as vannee e, as vrish e as hug e ny bwilleenyn dauesyn va sheer marish, as hug adsyn ad da’n pobble.
English: 19 And he commanded the multitude to sit down on the grass, and took the five loaves, and the two fishes, and looking up to heaven, he blessed, and brake, and gave the loaves to his disciples, and the disciples to the multitude.

Manx: 20 As ren ad ooilley gee, as va’d er nyn nianoo magh: as hrog ad jeh’n fooillagh daag ad, laane daa vasket jeig.
English: 20 And they did all eat, and were filled: and they took up of the fragments that remained twelve baskets full.

Manx: 21 As var adsyn v’er nee queg thousane dooinney, cheu-mooie jeh mraane as cloan.
English: 21 And they that had eaten were about five thousand men, beside women and children.

Manx: 22 ¶ As chelleeragh hug Yeesey er y vooinjer va sheer geyrt er, luingys y ghoal, as ad dy gholl roish gys y cheu elley, choud as ve cur y pobble ersooyl.
English: 22 And straightway Jesus constrained his disciples to get into a ship, and to go before him unto the other side, while he sent the multitudes away.

Manx: 23 As tra ve er chur yn pobble ersooyl, hie [e] hene er lieh seose er slieau, dy ghoal padjer: as tra va’n fastyr er jeet, ve ayns shen ny lomarcan.
English: 23 And when he had sent the multitudes away, he went up into a mountain apart to pray: and when the evening was come, he was there alone.

Manx: 24 Agh va’n long nish ayns main ny marrey eiyrit noon as noal lesh ny tonnyn: son va’n gheay nyn oi oc.
English: 24 But the ship was now in the midst of the sea, tossed with waves: for the wind was contrary.

Manx: 25 As ayns y chiarroo ghoostey jeh’n uy, haink Yeesey huc, shooyl er y cheayn.
English: 25 And in the fourth watch of the night Jesus went unto them, walking on the sea.

Manx: 26 As tra honnick adsyn va sheer marish e shooyl er y cheayn, va’d seaghnit, gra, She scaan t’ayn, as va’d ayns aggle, as deie ad.
English: 26 And when the disciples saw him walking on the sea, they were troubled, saying, It is a spirit; and they cried out for fear.

Manx: 27 Agh chelleeragh loar Yeesey roo, gra, Bee-jee dy yien mie, she mish t’ayn, ny gow-jee aggle.
English: 27 But straightway Jesus spake unto them, saying, Be of good cheer; it is I; be not afraid.

Manx: 28 As dreggyr Peddyr e, gra, Hiarn, My she oo t’ayn, oardee doos cheet hood er yn ushtey.
English: 28 And Peter answered him and said, Lord, if it be thou, bid me come unto thee on the water.

Manx: 29 As doort e, Tar. As tra va Peddyr er jeet neose ass y long, hooyl e er yn ushtey, dy heet gys Yeesey.
English: 29 And he said, Come. And when Peter was come down out of the ship, he walked on the water, to go to Jesus.

Manx: 30 Agh tra dennee e dy row yn gheay lajer, ghow e aggle, as myr ve er-gerrey dy ve baiht, dyllee e, gra, Hiarn, saue mee.
English: 30 But when he saw the wind boisterous, he was afraid; and beginning to sink, he cried, saying, Lord, save me.

Manx: 31 As ayns y tullogh heen Yeesey magh e laue, as haar e e, as doort e rish, O ghooinney faase-chredjuagh, cre’n fa v’ow ayns imnea?
English: 31 And immediately Jesus stretched forth his hand, and caught him, and said unto him, O thou of little faith, wherefore didst thou doubt?

Manx: 32 As tra va’d er gholl seose ayns y long, ghow yn gheay fea.
English: 32 And when they were come into the ship, the wind ceased.

Manx: 33 Eishtagh haink adsyn v’ayns y long, as hug ad ooashley da, gra, Ayns firrinys she mac Yee oo.
English: 33 Then they that were in the ship came and worshipped him, saying, Of a truth thou art the Son of God.

Manx: 34 As tra va’d er gholl harrish, haink ad gys cheer Gennesaret.
English: 34 And when they were gone over, they came into the land of Gennesaret.

Manx: 35 As tra hoig yn vooinjer va vaghey ayns shen, quoi ve, hug ad fys magh gys ooilley’n cheer my-geart, as hug ad lieu huggey ooilley adsyn va doghanit.
English: 35 And when the men of that place had knowledge of him, they sent out into all that country round about, and brought unto him all that were diseased;

Manx: 36 As ghuee ad er, ad ny lomarcan dy vennalt rish oirr e gharmad: as chooilleen as venn rish, va’d er nyn leihys.
English: 36 And besought him that they might only touch the hem of his garment: and as many as touched were made perfectly whole.

Manx: CAB. XV.
English: Matthew Chapter 15

Manx: 1 Eishtagh haink gys Yeesey scruderyn as Phariseyn, veih Jerusalem, gra,
English: 1 Then came to Jesus scribes and Pharisees, which were of Jerusalem, saying,

Manx: 2 Cre’n fa tar adsyn ta sheer geyrt orts brishey oardaghyn y chanstyr? Son cha vel ad niee nyn lauyn, tra ta’d gee arran.
English: 2 Why do thy disciples transgress the tradition of the elders? for they wash not their hands when they eat bread.

Manx: 3 Agh dreggyr eshyn, as doort e roo, Cre’n oyr ta shiuish brishey sarey Yee liorish ny oardaghyn eu?
English: 3 But he answered and said unto them, Why do ye also transgress the commandment of God by your tradition?

Manx: 4 Son hug Jee sarey, gra, Cur arrym da dt’ayr as da dty voir: as eshyn ta gueeaghyn da ayr as moir, lig e ve kerrit lesh baase.
English: 4 For God commanded, saying, Honour thy father and mother: and, He that curseth father or mother, let him die the death.

Manx: 5 Agh ta shiuish gra, Quoi-erbee jir rish ayr ny moir, Cre-erbee ta mish dy hebbal da Jee, bee vondeish ayds liorish,
English: 5 But ye say, Whosoever shall say to his father or his mother, It is a gift, by whatsoever thou mightest be profited by me;

Manx: 6 As nagh lias da cooney choyrt da e ayr ny e voir, Ta shiu myr shoh janoo sarey Yee gyn vree, liorish ny oardaghyn eu.
English: 6 And honour not his father or his mother, he shall be free. Thus have ye made the commandment of God of none effect by your tradition.

Manx: 7 Chrauee-foalsey, smie ren Esaias faishnagh jiu, gra,
English: 7 Ye hypocrites, well did Esaias prophesy of you, saying,

Manx: 8 Ta’n pobble shoh tayrn er-gerrey dou lesh nyn meeal, as cur ooashley dou lesh nyn meyllyn: agh ta’n cree oc foddey voym.
English: 8 This people draweth nigh unto me with their mouth, and honoureth me with their lips; but their heart is far from me.

Manx: 9 Agh ayns fardail ta’d cur ooashley dou, gynsaghey son y goo ayms oardaghyn deney.
English: 9 But in vain they do worship me, teaching for doctrines the commandments of men.

Manx: 10 ¶ As deie e er y pobble, as doort e roo, Easht-jee as toig-jee.
English: 10 And he called the multitude, and said unto them, Hear, and understand:

Manx: 11 Cha nee shen ta goll stiagh ayns y veeal, ta janoo dooinney niau-ghlen; agh ny ta cheet magh ass y veeal, shen ta janoo dooinney niau-ghlen.
English: 11 Not that which goeth into the mouth defileth a man; but that which cometh out of the mouth, this defileth a man.

Manx: 12 Eishtagh haink huggey yn vooinjer va sheer marish, as doort ad rish, Nagh vel fys ayd dy row ny Phariseyn jymmoosagh, tra cheayl ad y raa shoh?
English: 12 Then came his disciples, and said unto him, Knowest thou that the Pharisees were offended, after they heard this saying?

Manx: 13 Agh dreggyr eshyn, as doort e, Bee dy chooilley villey, nagh vel my Ayr flaunyssagh er ny hoiaghey, er ny ghoal ass ny frauyn.
English: 13 But he answered and said, Every plant, which my heavenly Father hath not planted, shall be rooted up.

Manx: 14 Lig-jee daue: she leedeilee doal ta kione y vooinjer ghoal ad. As my ta’n doal shooyl kione y doal, tuittee ad ny neesht ayns y jeeg.
English: 14 Let them alone: they be blind leaders of the blind. And if the blind lead the blind, both shall fall into the ditch.

Manx: 15 Eishtagh dreggyr Peddyr, as doort e rish, Soilshee dooinyn yn coraa dorraghey shoh.
English: 15 Then answered Peter and said unto him, Declare unto us this parable.

Manx: 16 Doort Yeesey rish, Vel shiuish neesht foast fegooish tushtey?
English: 16 And Jesus said, Are ye also yet without understanding?

Manx: 17 Nagh vel shiu foast toiggal, cre-erbee ta goit stiagh ayns y veeal, dy vel eh goll sheese ayns y volg, as goll magh trooid y chorp.
English: 17 Do not ye yet understand, that whatsoever entereth in at the mouth goeth into the belly, and is cast out into the draught?

Manx: 18 Agh ta ny reddyn ta cheet magh ass y veeal, cheet veih’n chree, as ta’d shen janoo dooinney niau-ghlen.
English: 18 But those things which proceed out of the mouth come forth from the heart; and they defile the man.

Manx: 19 Son magh veih’n chree ta cheet drogh smooinaghtyn, dunverys, brishey-poosey, maarderys, maarlys, fenish foalsey, goan mollaghtagh.
English: 19 For out of the heart proceed evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, fornications, thefts, false witness, blasphemies:

Manx: 20 Ad shoh ny reddyn ta sollaghey dooinney; agh dy ee lesh lauyn nagh vel neeit, cha vel shen janoo dooinney niau-ghlen.
English: 20 These are the things which defile a man: but to eat with unwashen hands defileth not a man.

Manx: 21 ¶ Eishtagh hie Yeesey veih shen, as jimmee e gys ardjyn Tyre as Sidon.
English: 21 Then Jesus went thence, and departed into the coasts of Tyre and Sidon.

Manx: 22 As cur-my-ner va ben va ny Canaanite haink magh ass ny ardjyn shen, gemagh as gra, Jean myghin orrym, O Hiarn, vac Ghavid; smoar ta m’inneen er ny torchaghey lesh drogh spyrryd.
English: 22 And, behold, a woman of Canaan came out of the same coasts, and cried unto him, saying, Have mercy on me, O Lord, thou Son of David; my daughter is grievously vexed with a devil.

Manx: 23 Agh cha dug e fockle dy ansoor jee. As haink y vooinjer va sheer geyrt er, as ghuee ad er, gra, Lig y raad jee, son tiee gemagh nyn nei ain.
English: 23 But he answered her not a word. And his disciples came and besought him, saying, Send her away; for she crieth after us.

Manx: 24 Agh dreggyr eshyn, as doort e, Cha vel mish er my choyrt agh gys kirree cailjey thie Israel.
English: 24 But he answered and said, I am not sent but unto the lost sheep of the house of Israel.

Manx: 25 Eishtagh haink ee as hug ee ooashley da, gra, Hiarn, cooin liam.
English: 25 Then came she and worshipped him, saying, Lord, help me.

Manx: 26 Agh dreggyr e, as doort e, Cha vel eh cooie arran y chloan y ghoal, as y hilgey gys moddee.
English: 26 But he answered and said, It is not meet to take the children's bread, and to cast it to dogs.

Manx: 27 Spheer shen, doort ish, Hiarn: foast ta ny moddee gee jeh’n brooilliagh, ta tuittym jeh board nyn mainshter.
English: 27 And she said, Truth, Lord: yet the dogs eat of the crumbs which fall from their masters' table.

Manx: 28 Er shen dansoor Yeesey as doort e ree, O ven, moar ta dty chredjue: yn aghin t’ow dy yearree dy row ayd. As va’n inneen eck er ny leihys veih’n oor keddyn.
English: 28 Then Jesus answered and said unto her, O woman, great is thy faith: be it unto thee even as thou wilt. And her daughter was made whole from that very hour.

Manx: 29 As jimmee Yeesey veih shen, as haink e er-gerrey da faarkey Galilee, as hie e seose er slieau as hoie e ayns shen.
English: 29 And Jesus departed from thence, and came nigh unto the sea of Galilee; and went up into a mountain, and sat down there.

Manx: 30 As haink earrooyn moarey dy leih huggey, as nyn mast oc va croobee, doal, balloo, baccee, as ymmodee elley, as hug ad ad nyn lhie ec cassyn Yeesey, as ren e ad y leihys:
English: 30 And great multitudes came unto him, having with them those that were lame, blind, dumb, maimed, and many others, and cast them down at Jesus' feet; and he healed them:

Manx: 31 Ayns wheesh as dy ghow ooilley’n pobble yyndyss, tra honnick ad ny balloo loart, ny baccee slane, ny croobee shooyl, as ny doal fakin, as hug ad gloyr da Jee Israel:
English: 31 Insomuch that the multitude wondered, when they saw the dumb to speak, the maimed to be whole, the lame to walk, and the blind to see: and they glorified the God of Israel.

Manx: 32 ¶ Eishtagh deie Yeesey er y vooinjer hene va kinjagh marish, as doort e, Ta chymmey aym er y pobble, er-yn-oyr dy vel ad er ny ve mârym nish tree laa, as cha vel veg y vee oc, as cha derrym ad ersooyl nyn drostey, er aggle dy der ad naardey er y raad.
English: 32 Then Jesus called his disciples unto him, and said, I have compassion on the multitude, because they continue with me now three days, and have nothing to eat: and I will not send them away fasting, lest they faint in the way.

Manx: 33 Doort adsyn va sheer geyrt er, rish, Cre woish oddys mad wheesh dy arran y gheddyn ayns yn aasagh, as nee leid y chaglym moar shoh dy leih y yanoo magh?
English: 33 And his disciples say unto him, Whence should we have so much bread in the wilderness, as to fill so great a multitude?

Manx: 34 Doort Yeesey roo, Cre woad bwilleen t’eu? Doort adsyn, shiaght as beggan dy eeastyn beggey.
English: 34 And Jesus saith unto them, How many loaves have ye? And they said, Seven, and a few little fishes.

Manx: 35 As doardee e da’n pobble soie sheese er y talloo.
English: 35 And he commanded the multitude to sit down on the ground.

Manx: 36 As ghow e ny shiaght bwilleenyn as ny eeastyn, as hug e booise, as vrish e, as hug e ad dauesyn va sheer geyrt er, as hug adsyn ad da’n pobble.
English: 36 And he took the seven loaves and the fishes, and gave thanks, and brake them, and gave to his disciples, and the disciples to the multitude.

Manx: 37 As ren ad ooilley gee, as va’d er nyn nianoo magh, as hrog ad jeh’n fooillagh va er-mayrn laane shiaght baskettyn.
English: 37 And they did all eat, and were filled: and they took up of the broken meat that was left seven baskets full.

Manx: 38 As var adsyn ren gee kiare thousane dooinney, cheu-mooie jeh mraane as cloan.
English: 38 And they that did eat were four thousand men, beside women and children.

Manx: 39 As hug e ersooyl yn pobble as ghow e luingys, as haink e gys ardjyn Magdala.
English: 39 And he sent away the multitude, and took ship, and came into the coasts of Magdala.

Manx: CAB. XVI.
English: Matthew Chapter 16

Manx: 1 As haink ny Phariseyn as ny Sadduceyn, dy violaghey e, as hir ad er, e dy yeaghyn cowrey ennagh daue veih niau.
English: 1 The Pharisees also with the Sadducees came, and tempting desired him that he would shew them a sign from heaven.

Manx: 2 Dreggyr eshyn as doort e roo, Tra ta’n fastyr ayn, ta shiuish gra, Bee emshir aalin ayn: son dy vel jirgid ’sy’n aer.
English: 2 He answered and said unto them, When it is evening, ye say, It will be fair weather: for the sky is red.

Manx: 3 As ayns y voghrey, Bee emshir vroghe ayn jiu; son ta’n aer jiarg as bodjallagh. Chrauee-foalsey, ta toiggal eu, kys dy chur tastey da neeal yn aer; as nagh vod shiu tastey choyrt da cowraghyn ny earishyn?
English: 3 And in the morning, It will be foul weather to day: for the sky is red and lowring. O ye hypocrites, ye can discern the face of the sky; but can ye not discern the signs of the times?

Manx: 4 She sheeloghe dy ghrogh yanoo as dy vrishey poosey ta shirrey cowrey, as cha bee cowrey er ny chur daue, agh cowrey’n phadeyr Jonas. As daag e ad, as jimmee e roish.
English: 4 A wicked and adulterous generation seeketh after a sign; and there shall no sign be given unto it, but the sign of the prophet Jonas. And he left them, and departed.

Manx: 5 As tra var adsyn va kinjagh geyrt er, er jeet gys y cheu elley, va’d er yarood arran y chur lieu.
English: 5 And when his disciples were come to the other side, they had forgotten to take bread.

Manx: 6 ¶ Eishtagh doort Yeesey roo, Cur-jee twoai as gow-jee tastey jeh soorit ny Phariseyn as ny Sadduceyn.
English: 6 Then Jesus said unto them, Take heed and beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and of the Sadducees.

Manx: 7 As loar ad eddyr ad hene, gra, Ta shoh er-yn-oyr nagh dug shin lien arran.
English: 7 And they reasoned among themselves, saying, It is because we have taken no bread.

Manx: 8 Tra hoig Yeesey shoh, doort e roo, Gheney faase-chredjuagh, cre’n fa ta shiu imneagh ayndiu hene er-yn-oyr nagh dug shiu lieu arran?
English: 8 Which when Jesus perceived, he said unto them, O ye of little faith, why reason ye among yourselves, because ye have brought no bread?

Manx: 9 Nagh vel shiu foast toiggal, as nagh vel cooinaghtyn eu er ny queg bwilleenyn ren magh ny queg thousanyn, as cre chooilleen basket d’ooillagh v’eu?
English: 9 Do ye not yet understand, neither remember the five loaves of the five thousand, and how many baskets ye took up?

Manx: 10 Ny er ny shiaght bwilleenyn ren magh ny kiare thousanyn, as cre woad basket hrog shiu?
English: 10 Neither the seven loaves of the four thousand, and how many baskets ye took up?

Manx: 11 Kys te, nagh vel shiu goall eu hene, nagh nee my-chione arran loar mee riu, agh shiu dy chur twoai jeh soorit ny Phariseyn as ny Sadduceyn.
English: 11 How is it that ye do not understand that I spake it not to you concerning bread, that ye should beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and of the Sadducees?

Manx: 12 Eishtagh hoig ad, nagh doardee e daue ad dy chur twoai jeh soorit yn arran, agh jeh ny va ny Phariseyn as ny Sadduceyn dy ynsaghey.
English: 12 Then understood they how that he bade them not beware of the leaven of bread, but of the doctrine of the Pharisees and of the Sadducees.

Manx: 13 ¶ Tra va Yeesey er jeet gys ardjyn Cesarea Philippi, denee e jeusyn va sheer geyrt er gra, Cre ta deney dy ghra my my-chiones, mac y dooinney, quoi mee?
English: 13 When Jesus came into the coasts of Caesarea Philippi, he asked his disciples, saying, Whom do men say that I the Son of man am?

Manx: 14 Doort adsyn, Ta part gra, dy nee Ean Bashtey oo, as part Elias, as ta feallagh elley gra dy nee Jeremias oo, ny annane jeh ny phaderyn.
English: 14 And they said, Some say that thou art John the Baptist: some, Elias; and others, Jeremias, or one of the prophets.

Manx: 15 Doort eshyn roo, Agh quoi ta shiuish dy ghra mee?
English: 15 He saith unto them, But whom say ye that I am?

Manx: 16 Dreggyr Simon Peddyr as doort e, Oo yn Creest, mac y Jee bio.
English: 16 And Simon Peter answered and said, Thou art the Christ, the Son of the living God.

Manx: 17 Dansoor Yeesey as doort e rish, Bannit t’ow uss, Simon Bar-jona: son cha nee feill as fuill t’er hoilshaghey shoh dhyts, agh my Ayr, ta ayns niau.
English: 17 And Jesus answered and said unto him, Blessed art thou, Simon Barjona: for flesh and blood hath not revealed it unto thee, but my Father which is in heaven.

Manx: 18 As ta mee myrgeddyn gra rhyt, Dy nee uss Peddyr, as dy nee er y chreg shoh hroggyms m’agglish; as cha vow giattyn nivrin yn varriaght urree.
English: 18 And I say also unto thee, That thou art Peter, and upon this rock I will build my church; and the gates of hell shall not prevail against it.

Manx: 19 As verryms dhyts ogheryn reeriaght niau, as cre-erbee chianglys oo er y talloo, bee eh kainlt ayns niau; as cre-erbee eyslys oo er y talloo, bee eh feyslit ayns niau.
English: 19 And I will give unto thee the keys of the kingdom of heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt bind on earth shall be bound in heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.

Manx: 20 Eishtagh hug e currym dauesyn va kinjagh geyrt er, gyn ad dy insh da dooinney erbee dy nee eshyn va Yeesey yn Creest.
English: 20 Then charged he his disciples that they should tell no man that he was Jesus the Christ.

Manx: 21 ¶ Veih’n tra shen magh, ren Yeesey toshiaght dy hoilshaghey dauesyn va kinjagh geyrt er, kys dy begin da goll seose gys Jerusalem, as ymmodee dy reddyn y hurranse veih’n chanstyr, as ny ard-saggyrtyn, as ny scruderyn, as dy beagh e er ny choyrt gy baase, as dy nirragh e reesht kione y tress laa.
English: 21 From that time forth began Jesus to shew unto his disciples, how that he must go unto Jerusalem, and suffer many things of the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed, and be raised again the third day.

Manx: 22 Eishtagh ghow Peddyr e, as ren e toshiaght dy chur oghsan da, gra, Foddey dy row eh woid, Hiarn, leid shoh dy haghert dhyt.
English: 22 Then Peter took him, and began to rebuke him, saying, Be it far from thee, Lord: this shall not be unto thee.

Manx: 23 Agh hyndaa eshyn, as doort e rish Peddyr, Ass my eanish, Noid anmey, t’ow cur rybbey ayns my raad: son cha vel ennaghtyn ayd jeh ny reddyn ta bennalt rish [Jee, agh jeh ny reddyn ta bennalt rish] deney.
English: 23 But he turned, and said unto Peter, Get thee behind me, Satan: thou art an offence unto me: for thou savourest not the things that be of God, but those that be of men.

Manx: 24 ¶ Eishtagh doort Yeesey roosyn va sheer marish, My ta dooinney erbee booiaght geyrt orryms, lig e e hene y obbal as e chrosh y hroggal, as geyrt orrym.
English: 24 Then said Jesus unto his disciples, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.

Manx: 25 Son quoi-erbee ballish e vioys y hauail, caillee e eh: as quoi-erbee chaillys e vioys er my ghraih’s, sauee e eh.
English: 25 For whosoever will save his life shall lose it: and whosoever will lose his life for my sake shall find it.

Manx: 26 Son cre’n vondeish t’ec dooinney, my chosnys e yn seihll ooilley as e annym hene y choall? ny cre nee dooinney y choyrt ayns coonrey son e annym?
English: 26 For what is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul?

Manx: 27 Son hig mac y dooinney ayns gloyr e Ayrey, as e ainlyn casherick marish, as ec y tra shen cooilleenee e da dy chooilley ghooinney cordail rish e obbraghyn.
English: 27 For the Son of man shall come in the glory of his Father with his angels; and then he shall reward every man according to his works.

Manx: 28 Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Dy vel part nyn shassoo ayns shoh, nagh jean blashtyn er y baase, derrey hee ad mac y dooinney cheet ayns e reeriaght.
English: 28 Verily I say unto you, There be some standing here, which shall not taste of death, till they see the Son of man coming in his kingdom.

Manx: CAB. XVII.
English: Matthew Chapter 17

Manx: 1 As ec kione shey laa, ghow Yeesey Peddyr, as Jamys, as Ean e vraar, as hug e lesh ad er lieh, seose er slieau ard.
English: 1 And after six days Jesus taketh Peter, James, and John his brother, and bringeth them up into an high mountain apart,

Manx: 2 As va’n cummey echey er ny chaghlaa kiongoyrt roo, as ren yn eddin echey soilshain myr y ghrian, as va’n coamrey echey gial myr y soilshey.
English: 2 And was transfigured before them: and his face did shine as the sun, and his raiment was white as the light.

Manx: 3 As cur-my-ner haink Moses as Elias ayns yn eanish echey, as va’d taggloo rish.
English: 3 And, behold, there appeared unto them Moses and Elias talking with him.

Manx: 4 Eishtagh dreggyr Peddyr as doort e rish Yeesey, Hiarn, Te mie er nyn son ainyn dy ve ayns shoh; My she dt’aigneys eh, lig dooin three cabbanyn y yanoo, cabbane er dty hons, as cabbane son Moses, as cabbane son Elias.
English: 4 Then answered Peter, and said unto Jesus, Lord, it is good for us to be here: if thou wilt, let us make here three tabernacles; one for thee, and one for Moses, and one for Elias.

Manx: 5 Choud as ve foast loart, cur-my-ner, ren bodjal sollys scadoo y hilgey harrystoo, as cur-my-ner coraa ass y vodjal, doort, Shoh my vac graihagh, jeh ta mee dy moar soiaghey, easht-jee rish.
English: 5 While he yet spake, behold, a bright cloud overshadowed them: and behold a voice out of the cloud, which said, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased; hear ye him.

Manx: 6 As tra cheayl ny ostyllyn eh, huit ad sheese lesh nyn eddinyn gys y talloo, as va’d feer agglagh.
English: 6 And when the disciples heard it, they fell on their face, and were sore afraid.

Manx: 7 As haink Yeesey as venn e roo, as doort e, Irree-jee seose as ny gow-jee aggle.
English: 7 And Jesus came and touched them, and said, Arise, and be not afraid.

Manx: 8 As tra hrog ad seose nyn sooyllyn, cha vaik ad annane erbee, agh Yeesey ny lomarcan.
English: 8 And when they had lifted up their eyes, they saw no man, save Jesus only.

Manx: 9 As myr va’d cheet neose jeh’n clieau, hug Yeesey currym daue, gra, Ny insh-jee yn ashlish da annane erbee, derrey vees yn mac dooinney er nirree veih ny merriu.
English: 9 And as they came down from the mountain, Jesus charged them, saying, Tell the vision to no man, until the Son of man be risen again from the dead.

Manx: 10 As denee e ostyllyn jeh, gra, Cre’n oyr ta ny scruderyn gra, dy vel Elias dy heet hoshiaght?
English: 10 And his disciples asked him, saying, Why then say the scribes that Elias must first come?

Manx: 11 Dansoor Yeesey as doort e roo, Hig Elias hoshiaght, as liassee e dy chooilley nee.
English: 11 And Jesus answered and said unto them, Elias truly shall first come, and restore all things.

Manx: 12 Agh ta mish gra riu, dy vel Elias er jeet hanna, as cha dug ad enney er, agh ta’d er ghellal rish lurg nyn aigney hene, as er yn aght keddyn ghellys ad myrgeddyn rish yn mac dooinney.
English: 12 But I say unto you, That Elias is come already, and they knew him not, but have done unto him whatsoever they listed. Likewise shall also the Son of man suffer of them.

Manx: 13 Eishtagh hoig e ostyllyn dy nee my-chione Ean Bashtey ve loart roo.
English: 13 Then the disciples understood that he spake unto them of John the Baptist.

Manx: 14 ¶ As tra va’d er jeet gys y cheshaght, haink huggey dooinney dy row, as huit e sheese er e ghlioonyn, gra,
English: 14 And when they were come to the multitude, there came to him a certain man, kneeling down to him, and saying,

Manx: 15 Hiarn, jean chymmey er my vac, son te eddrym ayns e cheeal, rish caghlaa ny haist, as dy moar seaghnit, son dy mennick te tuittym ayns yn aile, as dy mennick ayns yn ushtey.
English: 15 Lord, have mercy on my son: for he is lunatick, and sore vexed: for ofttimes he falleth into the fire, and oft into the water.

Manx: 16 As hug mee liam e gys dty ostyllyn, as cha yiarg ad e y leihys.
English: 16 And I brought him to thy disciples, and they could not cure him.

Manx: 17 Dansoor Yeesey as doort e, O Heeloghe vee-chredjuagh as niau-yeeragh, Caid ta mish dy ve meriu? Caid ta mee dy hurranse diu? Cur liat ayns shoh hyms e.
English: 17 Then Jesus answered and said, O faithless and perverse generation, how long shall I be with you? how long shall I suffer you? bring him hither to me.

Manx: 18 As vaggyr Yeesey er y drogh spyrryd, as hie e magh ass, as va’n liannoo er ny leihys veih’n oor shen.
English: 18 And Jesus rebuked the devil; and he departed out of him: and the child was cured from that very hour.

Manx: 19 Eishtagh haink e ostyllyn gys Yeesey er lieh, as doort ad, Cre liorish nagh voddagh shinyn e y hilgey ass?
English: 19 Then came the disciples to Jesus apart, and said, Why could not we cast him out?

Manx: 20 Doort Yeesey roo, Kyndagh rish y vee-chredjue eu: son dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, My ta credjue eu myr greine dy rass mustard, jir shiu rish y slieau shoh, Scugh ass shoh noon ayns shid, as nee eh scughey; as cha bee nee erbee niau-phossible diu.
English: 20 And Jesus said unto them, Because of your unbelief: for verily I say unto you, If ye have faith as a grain of mustard seed, ye shall say unto this mountain, Remove hence to yonder place; and it shall remove; and nothing shall be impossible unto you.

Manx: 21 Ny yei cha vel y sorch shoh dy ghrogh spyrrydyn er nyn eiyrt magh, agh liorish padjer as trostey.
English: 21 Howbeit this kind goeth not out but by prayer and fasting.

Manx: 22 ¶ As choud as va’d ayns Galilee, doort Yeesey roo, Bee mac y dooinney er ny vrah gys lauyn deney.
English: 22 And while they abode in Galilee, Jesus said unto them, The Son of man shall be betrayed into the hands of men:

Manx: 23 As ver ad e gy baase, as y trass laa nee e girree reesht. As var ad feer trimshagh.
English: 23 And they shall kill him, and the third day he shall be raised again.And they were exceeding sorry.

Manx: 24 ¶ As tra va’d er jeet gys Capernaum, haink y vooinjer va troggal argid y cheesh gys Peddyr, gra, Nagh vel y mainshter eauish geeck y cheesh?
English: 24 And when they were come to Capernaum, they that received tribute money came to Peter, and said, Doth not your master pay tribute?

Manx: 25 Doort eshyn, dy row: As tra ve er jeet stiagh ayns y thie, loar Yeesey rishyn hoshiaght, gra, Cre t’ow dy smooinaght, Simon? quoi jeh ta reeaghyn y tallooin troggal custom ny keesh? jeh nyn gloan hene, ny jeh joarreeyn?
English: 25 He saith, Yes. And when he was come into the house, Jesus prevented him, saying, What thinkest thou, Simon? of whom do the kings of the earth take custom or tribute? of their own children, or of strangers?

Manx: 26 Doort Peddyr rish, Jeh joarreeyn. Doort Yeesey rishyn, Eishtagh, cha vel veg er y chloan dy eeck.
English: 26 Peter saith unto him, Of strangers. Jesus saith unto him, Then are the children free.

Manx: 27 Ny yei son nagh bee commys er ny chur hooin, gow uss gys y cheayn, as tilg magh dooan, as trog y chied eeast hig hood, as tra vees oo er vosley’n beeal echey, yiow peesh dy argid ayn, shen gow, as cur daue er my hons as er dty hon hene.
English: 27 Notwithstanding, lest we should offend them, go thou to the sea, and cast an hook, and take up the fish that first cometh up; and when thou hast opened his mouth, thou shalt find a piece of money: that take, and give unto them for me and thee.

Manx: CAB. XVIII.
English: Matthew Chapter 18

Manx: 1 Ec y tra cheddyn haink y vooinjer va sheer geyrt er Yeesey huggey, gra, Quoi syrjey ayns reeriaght niau?
English: 1 At the same time came the disciples unto Jesus, saying, Who is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven?

Manx: 2 As deie Yeesey er liannoo beg, as hoie e e kiongoyrt roo,
English: 2 And Jesus called a little child unto him, and set him in the midst of them,

Manx: 3 As doort e, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, mannagh jean shiu chyndaa as cheet dy ve myr cloan veggey, cha jed shiu stiagh ayns reeriaght niau.
English: 3 And said, Verily I say unto you, Except ye be converted, and become as little children, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven.

Manx: 4 Quoi-erbee er-y-fa shen nee e hene y injillaghey myr y liannoo beg shoh, e syrjey ta ayns reeriaght niau.
English: 4 Whosoever therefore shall humble himself as this little child, the same is greatest in the kingdom of heaven.

Manx: 5 As quoi-erbee nee soiaghey jeh leid y liannoo beg shoh ayns yn ennym ayms, te janoo soiaghey jeems.
English: 5 And whoso shall receive one such little child in my name receiveth me.

Manx: 6 Agh quoi-erbee ver oyr da annane jeh’n vooinjer veggey shoh ta credjal aynyms, dy huittym ayns peccah, veagh eh ny baare da, dy beagh clogh wyllin er ve croghit mish e wannal, as e dy ve baiht ayns divnit ny marrey.
English: 6 But whoso shall offend one of these little ones which believe in me, it were better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck, and that he were drowned in the depth of the sea.

Manx: 7 Smerrick da’n seihl, er coontey oyryn peccah: son shegin da nyn leid y ve ayn, agh smerrick da’n dooinney liorish ta sleih er nyn dayrn gys peccah.
English: 7 Woe unto the world because of offences! for it must needs be that offences come; but woe to that man by whom the offence cometh!

Manx: 8 Shen-y-fa my ta dty laue ny dty chass hene dy dty hayrn gys yn olk, giare jeed as tilg woid ad: te ny share dhyt goll stiagh ayns bea croobagh ny baccagh, ny daa laue ny daa chass y ve ayd, as oo dy ve tilgit ayns yn aile ta dy bragh farraghtyn.
English: 8 Wherefore if thy hand or thy foot offend thee, cut them off, and cast them from thee: it is better for thee to enter into life halt or maimed, rather than having two hands or two feet to be cast into everlasting fire.

Manx: 9 As my ta dty hooyl dy dty hayrn gys peccah, pluck assyd as tilg woid ee; te ny share dhyt goll stiagh ayns bea lesh yn hooyl, ny daa hooyl y ve ayd, as oo dy ve tilgit ayns aile nivrin.
English: 9 And if thine eye offend thee, pluck it out, and cast it from thee: it is better for thee to enter into life with one eye, rather than having two eyes to be cast into hell fire.

Manx: 10 Cur-jee twoai nagh soie shiu beg jeh annane jeh’n vooinjer veggey shoh; son ta mee gra riu, dy vel ny ainlyn ocsyn ayns niau, kinjagh cur-my-ner eddin yn Ayr ayms t’ayns niau.
English: 10 Take heed that ye despise not one of these little ones; for I say unto you, That in heaven their angels do always behold the face of my Father which is in heaven.

Manx: 11 Son ta mac y dooinney er jeet dy hauail shen ny va callit.
English: 11 For the Son of man is come to save that which was lost.

Manx: 12 Cre ta shiu dy smooinaght? My ta keead keyrrey ec dooinney, as annane jeu v’er gholl er shaghryn, nagh vel e fagail yn chiare-feed as yn nuyh jeig, as goll gys ny sleityn as shirrey yn cheyrrey hie er shaghryn?
English: 12 How think ye? if a man have an hundred sheep, and one of them be gone astray, doth he not leave the ninety and nine, and goeth into the mountains, and seeketh that which is gone astray?

Manx: 13 As my she shen dy vel e dy gheddyn ee, dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy vel e goall ny smoo dy voggey jeh’n cheyrrey shen, ny jeh’n chiare-feed as yn nuyh jeig, nagh jagh er shaghryn.
English: 13 And if so be that he find it, verily I say unto you, he rejoiceth more of that sheep, than of the ninety and nine which went not astray.

Manx: 14 Er yn aght keddyn cha nee aigney nyn Ayr t’ayns niau eh, annane jeh’n vooinjer veggey shoh dy hierraghtyn.
English: 14 Even so it is not the will of your Father which is in heaven, that one of these little ones should perish.

Manx: 15 ¶ Myrgeddyn my nee dty vraar aggair dhyt, immee as insh da e oill eddyr uss as eshyn nyn lomarcan; my eashtys e rhyt, t’ow er chosney dty vraar.
English: 15 Moreover if thy brother shall trespass against thee, go and tell him his fault between thee and him alone: if he shall hear thee, thou hast gained thy brother.

Manx: 16 Agh mannagh neasht e rhyt, gow mayrt annane ny jees elley, ayns beeal ghaa ny three dy eanishyn, dy vod dy chooilley ockle ve jeant mie.
English: 16 But if he will not hear thee, then take with thee one or two more, that in the mouth of two or three witnesses every word may be established.

Manx: 17 As mannagh der e geill dauesyn, insh eh da’n agglish: agh mannagh der e geill da’n agglish, jeagh er myr angreestee as myr publican.
