English: 17 And if he shall neglect to hear them, tell it unto the church: but if he neglect to hear the church, let him be unto thee as an heathen man and a publican.

Manx: 18 Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Cre-erbee nee shiu y chiangley er y talloo, bee eh kainlt ayns niau: as cre-erbee nee shiu y eysley er y talloo, bee eh feyslit ayns niau.
English: 18 Verily I say unto you, Whatsoever ye shall bind on earth shall be bound in heaven: and whatsoever ye shall loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.

Manx: 19 Reeshtagh ta mee gra riu, my nee jees jiuish cordail er y talloo my-chione nee erbee dy jean ad aghin er y hon, bee nyn aghin er ny yialdyn liorish my Ayr t’ayns niau.
English: 19 Again I say unto you, That if two of you shall agree on earth as touching any thing that they shall ask, it shall be done for them of my Father which is in heaven.

Manx: 20 Son raad ta ghaa ny three er nyn jaglym cooidjagh ayns m’ennyms, ayns shen ta mish nyn mastey.
English: 20 For where two or three are gathered together in my name, there am I in the midst of them.

Manx: 21 ¶ Eishtagh haink Peddyr huggey, as doort e, Cre cha mennick as ta orryms leih da my vraar, tra vees e janoo peccah m’oi? choud as shiaght keartyn?
English: 21 Then came Peter to him, and said, Lord, how oft shall my brother sin against me, and I forgive him? till seven times?

Manx: 22 Doort Yeesey rish, Cha vel mish gra rhyt, Choud as shiaght keartyn, agh choud as three feed as jeih keartyn shiaght.
English: 22 Jesus saith unto him, I say not unto thee, Until seven times: but, Until seventy times seven.

Manx: 23 ¶ Shen-y-fa ta reeriaght niau er ny holaghey gys ree dy row, ballish coontey ghoall jeh e harvaantyn.
English: 23 Therefore is the kingdom of heaven likened unto a certain king, which would take account of his servants.

Manx: 24 As tra ve er nianoo toshiaght dy choontey, haink fer huggey va liastyn jeih thousane talent.
English: 24 And when he had begun to reckon, one was brought unto him, which owed him ten thousand talents.

Manx: 25 Agh son wheesh as nagh row echey dy eeck, hug e hiarn sarey e hene dy ve creckit as e ven as e chloan as ooilley ny v’echey, as y feeaghyn dy ve eeckit.
English: 25 But forasmuch as he had not to pay, his lord commanded him to be sold, and his wife, and children, and all that he had, and payment to be made.

Manx: 26 Huit y chiarvaant er-y-fa shen sheese, as ghuee e er, gra, Cur daill dou, Hiarn, as neem ooilley y eeck dhyt.
English: 26 The servant therefore fell down, and worshipped him, saying, Lord, have patience with me, and I will pay thee all.

Manx: 27 Eisht va chiarn y chiarvaant shen er ny veyghey lesh chymmey, as ren e feysley er, as leih e da ny ve dy liastyn.
English: 27 Then the lord of that servant was moved with compassion, and loosed him, and forgave him the debt.

Manx: 28 Agh hie yn chiarvaant keddyn magh, as hooar e fer jeh ny sheshaghyn shiarvaantyn echey va liastyn da keead ping: as haar e greme er, as ghow e e er y scoarnagh, gra, Eeck shen ny t’ow dy liastyn.
English: 28 But the same servant went out, and found one of his fellowservants, which owed him an hundred pence: and he laid hands on him, and took him by the throat, saying, Pay me that thou owest.

Manx: 29 As huit e heshey-harvaant sheese ec e chassyn, as ghuee e er, gra, Cur daill dou, as neem ooilley y eeck dhyt.
English: 29 And his fellowservant fell down at his feet, and besought him, saying, Have patience with me, and I will pay thee all.

Manx: 30 As cha row e booiaght: agh hie e, as hilg e e ayns pryssoon, derrey eeckagh e ny ve dy liastyn.
English: 30 And he would not: but went and cast him into prison, till he should pay the debt.

Manx: 31 Myr shen tra honnick e heshaghyn harvaantyn kys hie e er, ghow ad dy holk rish, as haink ad, as dinsh ad da nyn jiarn ooilley ny va jeant.
English: 31 So when his fellowservants saw what was done, they were very sorry, and came and told unto their lord all that was done.

Manx: 32 Eisht deie e hiarn er, as doort e rish, O ghrogh harvaant, leih mish dhyts ooilley ny v’ow dy liastyn, er-y-fa dy ren oo aghin hym:
English: 32 Then his lord, after that he had called him, said unto him, O thou wicked servant, I forgave thee all that debt, because thou desiredst me:

Manx: 33 As nagh lishagh uss myrgeddyn v’er nianoo chymmey er dty heshey-harvaant, myr va chymmey ayms orts?
English: 33 Shouldest not thou also have had compassion on thy fellowservant, even as I had pity on thee?

Manx: 34 As va e hiarn jymmoosagh, as livrey e e hucsyn va goall kerraghey, derrey eeckagh e ooilley ny ve dy liastyn.
English: 34 And his lord was wroth, and delivered him to the tormentors, till he should pay all that was due unto him.

Manx: 35 Myr shen myrgeddyn nee my Ayr flaunyssagh riuish, mannagh leih shiu veih nyn greeaghyn dy chooilley ghooinney da e vraar e loghtyn.
English: 35 So likewise shall my heavenly Father do also unto you, if ye from your hearts forgive not every one his brother their trespasses.

Manx: CAB. XIX.
English: Matthew Chapter 19

Manx: 1 As haink eh gy kione, tra va Yeesey erreish ny goan shoh y loart, dy jimmee e veih Galilee, as dy daink e gys ardjyn Judea, er cheu elley dy Yordan:
English: 1 And it came to pass, that when Jesus had finished these sayings, he departed from Galilee, and came into the coasts of Judaea beyond Jordan;

Manx: 2 As deyr earrooyn moarey dy leih er, as ren e ad y leihys ayns shen.
English: 2 And great multitudes followed him; and he healed them there.

Manx: 3 ¶ Haink ny Phariseyn huggey myrgeddyn dy violaghey e, as doort ad rish, Vel eh lowal da dooinney e ven y chur ersooyl son dy chooilley oyr?
English: 3 The Pharisees also came unto him, tempting him, and saying unto him, Is it lawful for a man to put away his wife for every cause?

Manx: 4 Dreggyr eshyn as doort e roo, Nagh vel shiu er lhaih, eshyn chroo ad ec y toshiaght, dy chroo e ad fyrrynagh as bwoirrynagh?
English: 4 And he answered and said unto them, Have ye not read, that he which made them at the beginning made them male and female,

Manx: 5 As dy doort e, Er-yn-oyr shoh, nee dooinney fagail e ayr as e voir, as liannee e gys e ven: as bee ad nyn neesht yn eihl.
English: 5 And said, For this cause shall a man leave father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife: and they twain shall be one flesh?

Manx: 6 Shen-y-fa cha vel ad ny sodjey jees, agh yn eihl. Cre-erbee er-y-fa shen ta Jee er chur cooidjagh, ny lig da dooinney erbee y chur veih my chielley.
English: 6 Wherefore they are no more twain, but one flesh. What therefore God hath joined together, let not man put asunder.

Manx: 7 Doort adsyn rish, Cre’n oyr eishtagh doardee Moses screeuyn scarree y choyrt, as y ven y chur ersooyl?
English: 7 They say unto him, Why did Moses then command to give a writing of divorcement, and to put her away?

Manx: 8 Doort eshyn roo, Kyndagh rish creoghys nyn greeaghyn, lhow Moses diu nyn mraane y chur ersooyl: agh cha row eh myr shen er dyn toshiaght.
English: 8 He saith unto them, Moses because of the hardness of your hearts suffered you to put away your wives: but from the beginning it was not so.

Manx: 9 As ta mish gra riu, Quoi-erbee scarrys rish e ven, cheu-mooie jeh son maarderys, as phoosys ben elley, te brishey poosey: as quoi-erbee phoosys ish ta scart, te brishey poosey.
English: 9 And I say unto you, Whosoever shall put away his wife, except it be for fornication, and shall marry another, committeth adultery: and whoso marrieth her which is put away doth commit adultery.

Manx: 10 ¶ Doort y vooinjer va sheer geyrt er rish, My she shoh yn stayd ta dooinney as ben ayn, cha vel eh mie dy phoosey.
English: 10 His disciples say unto him, If the case of the man be so with his wife, it is not good to marry.

Manx: 11 Agh doort eshyn roo, cha nee dy chooilley ghooinney oddys shen y ghoal er,[***] cheu-mooie adsyn daue te er ny choyrt.
English: 11 But he said unto them, All men cannot receive this saying, save they to whom it is given.

Manx: 12 Son ta deney gennish ayn rug myr shen veih breinn nyn mayrey: as ta deney gennish ayn, v’er nyn nianoo gennish liorish deney: as ta deney gennish ayn, t’er nianoo ad hene gennish er graih reeriaght niau. Eshyn ta able shoh y ghoal er, lig e ghoal er eh.
English: 12 For there are some eunuchs, which were so born from their mother's womb: and there are some eunuchs, which were made eunuchs of men: and there be eunuchs, which have made themselves eunuchs for the kingdom of heaven's sake. He that is able to receive it, let him receive it.

Manx: 13 ¶ Eishtagh hug ad lieu huggey cloan veggey, dy voddagh e e lauyn y chur orroo, as padjer y ghoal: as hug y vooinjer va sheer geyrt er oghsan daue.
English: 13 Then were there brought unto him little children, that he should put his hands on them, and pray: and the disciples rebuked them.

Manx: 14 Agh doort Yeesey, Sur-jee cloan aegey, as ny jean-jee nyn liettal ad dy heet hyms: son jeh nyn leid ta reeriaght niau.
English: 14 But Jesus said, Suffer little children, and forbid them not, to come unto me: for of such is the kingdom of heaven.

Manx: 15 As hug e e lauyn orroo, as jimmee e veih shen.
English: 15 And he laid his hands on them, and departed thence.

Manx: 16 ¶ As cur-my-ner haink fer huggey as doort e rish, Vainshter vie, Cre’n red mie neems, dy vod yn vea veayn y ve aym?
English: 16 And, behold, one came and said unto him, Good Master, what good thing shall I do, that I may have eternal life?

Manx: 17 As doort eshyn rish, Cre’n fa t’ow genmys mee mie? cha vel annane erbee mie, agh annane; ta shen dy ghra, Jee: agh my sailts goll stiagh ayns bea, freil ny annaghyn.
English: 17 And he said unto him, Why callest thou me good? there is none good but one, that is, God: but if thou wilt enter into life, keep the commandments.

Manx: 18 Doort eshyn rish, Cre ny annaghyn? Doort Yeesey, Cha jean oo dunverys, Cha brish oo poosey, Cha jean oo geid, Cha nymmyrk oo feanish foalsey,
English: 18 He saith unto him, Which? Jesus said, Thou shalt do no murder, Thou shalt not commit adultery, Thou shalt not steal, Thou shalt not bear false witness,

Manx: 19 Cur arrym da dt’ayr as da dty voir: as, ver oo graih da dty naboo myr dhyt hene.
English: 19 Honour thy father and thy mother: and, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself.

Manx: 20 Doort y dooinney aeg rish, Ooilley ny annaghyn shoh ta mee er vrealley veih my aegid: Cre sodjey t’orrym dy yanoo?
English: 20 The young man saith unto him, All these things have I kept from my youth up: what lack I yet?

Manx: 21 Doort Yeesey rish, My bailt ve dy firrinagh mie, immee as creck as cur ny t’ayd da ny boughtyn, as bee berchys ayd ayns niau; as tar as eyr orryms.
English: 21 Jesus said unto him, If thou wilt be perfect, go and sell that thou hast, and give to the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven: and come and follow me.

Manx: 22 Agh tra cheayl y dooinney aeg yn raa shen, hie e ersooyl dy trimshagh; son va cummallyn moarey echey.
English: 22 But when the young man heard that saying, he went away sorrowful: for he had great possessions.

Manx: 23 ¶ Eishtagh doort Yeesey roosyn va sheer geyrt er, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy goan hed dooinney berchiagh stiagh ayns reeriaght niau.
English: 23 Then said Jesus unto his disciples, Verily I say unto you, That a rich man shall hardly enter into the kingdom of heaven.

Manx: 24 As reeshtagh ta mee gra riu, Te ny sassey da camel goll trooid croae snaidey, ny da dooinney berchiagh dy gholl stiagh ayns reeriaght Yee.
English: 24 And again I say unto you, It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.

Manx: 25 Tra cheayl yn vooinjer va sheer marish shoh, va’d er-skyn towse atchimagh, gra, Quoi eishtagh oddys ve er ny hauail?
English: 25 When his disciples heard it, they were exceedingly amazed, saying, Who then can be saved?

Manx: 26 Agh yeagh Yeesey orroo, as doort e roo, Da deney ta shoh niau-phossible, agh da Jee ta dy chooilley nee possible.
English: 26 But Jesus beheld them, and said unto them, With men this is impossible; but with God all things are possible.

Manx: 27 ¶ Eishtagh dreggyr Peddyr, as doort e rish, Cur-my-ner, ta shinyn er dregeil ooilley, as er neyrt orts; cre vees ainyn er-y-fa shen?
English: 27 Then answered Peter and said unto him, Behold, we have forsaken all, and followed thee; what shall we have therefore?

Manx: 28 Doort Yeesey roo, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, ec y yiennaghtyn reesht, tra nee mac y dooinney soie er stoyl-reeoil e ghloyr, dy jean shiuish myrgeddyn t’er neyrt orryms, soie er daa stoyl-reeoil yeig, briwnys daa heeloghe yeig Israel.
English: 28 And Jesus said unto them, Verily I say unto you, That ye which have followed me, in the regeneration when the Son of man shall sit in the throne of his glory, ye also shall sit upon twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.

Manx: 29 As yiow dy chooilley annane t’er hregeil thiyn, ny braaraghyn, ny shaaraghyn, ny ayr, ny moir, ny ben, ny cloan, ny talloo, er graih m’ennyms, keead filley, as eiraght ayns y vea veayn.
English: 29 And every one that hath forsaken houses, or brethren, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or lands, for my name's sake, shall receive an hundredfold, and shall inherit everlasting life.

Manx: 30 Agh bee ymmodee jeusyn ta hoshiaght, er jerrey, as jeusyn ta er jerrey, hoshiaght.
English: 30 But many that are first shall be last; and the last shall be first.

Manx: CAB. XX.
English: Matthew Chapter 20

Manx: 1 Son ta reeriaght niau casley rish dooinney va ny ar-thie, hie magh dy moghey, dy ailley labreeyn son e gharey-feeney.
English: 1 For the kingdom of heaven is like unto a man that is an householder, which went out early in the morning to hire labourers into his vineyard.

Manx: 2 As tra ve er chordail rish ny labreeyn son ping ’sy laa, hug e ad stiagh ayns e gharey-feeney.
English: 2 And when he had agreed with the labourers for a penny a day, he sent them into his vineyard.

Manx: 3 As hie e magh my-geart y tress oor, as honnick e feallagh elley ny shassoo nyn daaue ayns ynnyd y vargee,
English: 3 And he went out about the third hour, and saw others standing idle in the marketplace,

Manx: 4 As doort e roo, Gow-jee shiuish myrgeddyn stiagh ayns y gharey-feeney, as verryms diu cre-erbee ta cairagh. As hie ad rumboo.
English: 4 And said unto them; Go ye also into the vineyard, and whatsoever is right I will give you. And they went their way.

Manx: 5 Reeshtagh hie e magh my-geart y cheyoo as yn nuyoo oor, as ren e er yn aght keddyn.
English: 5 Again he went out about the sixth and ninth hour, and did likewise.

Manx: 6 As my-geart yn yn oor jeig, hie e magh, as hooar e feallagh elley ny shassoo nyn daaue, as doort e roo, Cre’n fa ta shiu nyn shassoo ayns shoh fey laa nyn daaue?
English: 6 And about the eleventh hour he went out, and found others standing idle, and saith unto them, Why stand ye here all the day idle?

Manx: 7 Doort adsyn rish, Er-yn-oyr nagh vel dooinney erbee er vailley shin. Doort eshyn roo, Gow-jee shiuish myrgeddyn stiagh ayns y gharey-feeney, as yiow shiu cre-erbee ta cairagh.
English: 7 They say unto him, Because no man hath hired us. He saith unto them, Go ye also into the vineyard; and whatsoever is right, that shall ye receive.

Manx: 8 Myr shen tra va’n fastyr er jeet, doort chiarn y gharey-feeney rish y stioort echey, Eie er ny labreeyn, as cur daue nyn vail, goall toshiaght veih yn vooinjer stierree gys y chied eallagh.
English: 8 So when even was come, the lord of the vineyard saith unto his steward, Call the labourers, and give them their hire, beginning from the last unto the first.

Manx: 9 As tra haink feallagh yn yn oor jeig, hooar ad dy chooilley ghooinney ping.
English: 9 And when they came that were hired about the eleventh hour, they received every man a penny.

Manx: 10 Agh tra haink y chied eallagh, heill ad dy voghe ad ny smoo, as hooar adsyn myrgeddyn dy chooilley ghooinney ping.
English: 10 But when the first came, they supposed that they should have received more; and they likewise received every man a penny.

Manx: 11 As tra va’d er ghoal eh, loar ad dy jymmoosagh rish yn far-thie,
English: 11 And when they had received it, they murmured against the goodman of the house,

Manx: 12 Gra, Cha vel yn vooinjer stierree shoh er nobbragh agh yn oor, as t’ow er nianoo ad corrym rooinyn, t’er nymmyrkey errey as chiass y laa.
English: 12 Saying, These last have wrought but one hour, and thou hast made them equal unto us, which have borne the burden and heat of the day.

Manx: 13 Agh dreggyr eshyn fer jeu, gra, Heshey vie, cha vel mish janoo aggair dhyt: Nagh choard uss rhyms son ping?
English: 13 But he answered one of them, and said, Friend, I do thee no wrong: didst not thou agree with me for a penny?

Manx: 14 Trog shen ny ta liat, as immee royd: m’aigney’s eh dy choyrt da’n fer stierree shoh; myr ta mee er chur dhyts.
English: 14 Take that thine is, and go thy way: I will give unto this last, even as unto thee.

Manx: 15 Nagh vel eh lowal dou, dy yanoo cre saillym rish my chooid hene? Vel dty hooyls olk, er-y-fa dy vel mish mie?
English: 15 Is it not lawful for me to do what I will with mine own? Is thine eye evil, because I am good?

Manx: 16 Myr shen bee adsyn ta er jerrey hoshiaght, as adsyn ta hoshiaght er jerrey: son ta ymmodee er nyn eam, agh beggan er nyn reih.
English: 16 So the last shall be first, and the first last: for many be called, but few chosen.

Manx: 17 ¶ As myr va Yeesey goll seose gys Jerusalem, ghow e yn daa ostyl yeig dy liattee er y raad, as doort e roo,
English: 17 And Jesus going up to Jerusalem took the twelve disciples apart in the way, and said unto them,

Manx: 18 Cur-my-ner ta shin goll seose gys Jerusalem, as bee mac y dooinney er ny vrah gys ny ard-saggyrtyn, as gys ny scruderyn, as deyree ad e gy baase,
English: 18 Behold, we go up to Jerusalem; and the Son of man shall be betrayed unto the chief priests and unto the scribes, and they shall condemn him to death,

Manx: 19 As livrey-ee ad e hucsyn jeh ny ashoonyn quaagh, dy chraidey mish, as dy chustey, as dy chrossey e: as er y tress laa nee e girree reesht.
English: 19 And shall deliver him to the Gentiles to mock, and to scourge, and to crucify him: and the third day he shall rise again.

Manx: 20 ¶ Eishtagh haink huggey moir cloan Zebedee, as e meck mâree, cur ooashley da, as shirrey aghin er.
English: 20 Then came to him the mother of Zebedee's children with her sons, worshipping him, and desiring a certain thing of him.

Manx: 21 As doort e ree, Cre bailt? Doort ish rish, Lhow da my ghaa vac dy hoie, yn derrey yeh er dty laue yesh, as y jeh elley er dty laue chiare ayns dty reeriaght.
English: 21 And he said unto her, What wilt thou? She saith unto him, Grant that these my two sons may sit, the one on thy right hand, and the other on the left, in thy kingdom.

Manx: 22 Agh dreggyr Yeesey as doort e, Cha s’eu cre ta shiu dy yearree. Vel shiu able giu jeh’n cappan ta mish giu jeh, as v’er nyn mashtey lesh y bashtey ta mish bashtit lesh? Doort adsyn rish, Ta shin able.
English: 22 But Jesus answered and said, Ye know not what ye ask. Are ye able to drink of the cup that I shall drink of, and to be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with? They say unto him, We are able.

Manx: 23 As doort e roo, Ivee shiu dy jarroo jeh my chappan, as bee shiu er nyn mashtey lesh y bashtey ta mish bashtit lesh: agh dy hoie er my laue yesh as er my laue chiare, cha vel shen liams dy choyrt, agh ny lomarcan dauesyn, er nyn son te kiaddit liorish my Ayr.
English: 23 And he saith unto them, Ye shall drink indeed of my cup, and be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with: but to sit on my right hand, and on my left, is not mine to give, but it shall be given to them for whom it is prepared of my Father.

Manx: 24 As tra cheayl yn jeih shoh, va’d feer jymmoosagh rish y daa vraar.
English: 24 And when the ten heard it, they were moved with indignation against the two brethren.

Manx: 25 Agh deie Yeesey orroo huggey, as doort e, Ta fys eu dy vel prinsyn ny ashoonyn quaagh gymmyrkey reill harrystoo, as ta ny deney moarey gymmyrkey torrity nyn mastey.
English: 25 But Jesus called them unto him, and said, Ye know that the princes of the Gentiles exercise dominion over them, and they that are great exercise authority upon them.

Manx: 26 Agh cha bee eh myr shen nyn mastey eauish: agh quoi-erbee eavish ballish ve moar, lig e ve ry hoi shirveish erriu.
English: 26 But it shall not be so among you: but whosoever will be great among you, let him be your minister;

Manx: 27 As quoi-erbee syrjey ballish y ve nyn mast eu, lig e ve yn chiarvaant eu.
English: 27 And whosoever will be chief among you, let him be your servant:

Manx: 28 Myr nagh daink yn mac dooinney dy ve shirveishit, agh dy hirveish, as dy chur e vioys ny liassaghey son ymmodee.
English: 28 Even as the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many.

Manx: 29 As tra va’d er nimmeeaght veih Jericho, deyr earrooyn moarey dy leih er.
English: 29 And as they departed from Jericho, a great multitude followed him.

Manx: 30 ¶ As cur-my-ner, va daa ghooinney doal nyn soie rish liattee yn raad, as tra cheayl ad dy row Yeesey goll shiaghey, deie ad, gra, Jean myghin orrin, O Hiarn, vac Ghavid.
English: 30 And, behold, two blind men sitting by the way side, when they heard that Jesus passed by, cried out, saying, Have mercy on us, O Lord, thou Son of David.

Manx: 31 As va’n pobble cur oghsan daue, dy voddagh ad nyn jengey chummal: agh deie adsyn wheesh shen smoo, gra, Jean myghin orrin, O Hiarn, vac Ghavid.
English: 31 And the multitude rebuked them, because they should hold their peace: but they cried the more, saying, Have mercy on us, O Lord, thou Son of David.

Manx: 32 As hass Yeesey, as deie e orroo, as doort e, Cre balliu mee dy yanoo er nyn son eu?
English: 32 And Jesus stood still, and called them, and said, What will ye that I shall do unto you?

Manx: 33 Doort adsyn rish, Hiarn, dy vod ny sooyllyn ain v’er nyn vosley.
English: 33 They say unto him, Lord, that our eyes may be opened.

Manx: 34 Myr shen va chymmey ec Yeesey orroo, as venn e rish ny sooyllyn oc: as chelleeragh hooar ny sooyllyn oc nyn soilshey, as deyr ad er.
English: 34 So Jesus had compassion on them, and touched their eyes: and immediately their eyes received sight, and they followed him.

Manx: CAB. XXI.
English: Matthew Chapter 21

Manx: 1 As tra va’d tayrn er-gerrey da Jerusalem; as dy row ad er jeet gys Bethphage, gys cronck ny Olivyn, hug Yeesey jees jeusyn va kinjagh geyrt er, er chaghteraght,
English: 1 And when they drew nigh unto Jerusalem, and were come to Bethphage, unto the mount of Olives, then sent Jesus two disciples,

Manx: 2 As doort e roo, Immee-jee gys y balley beg ta shiu dy akin, as chelleeragh yiow shiu assyl kainlt as lhie mâree: feysle-jee as cur-jee lieu ad hyms.
English: 2 Saying unto them, Go into the village over against you, and straightway ye shall find an ass tied, and a colt with her: loose them, and bring them unto me.

Manx: 3 As my loarys dooinney erbee veg riu, abbyr-jee shiuish, Ta feme ec y Chiarn orroo, as chelleeragh liggee e yn raad daue.
English: 3 And if any man say ought unto you, ye shall say, The Lord hath need of them; and straightway he will send them.

Manx: 4 Va ooilley shoh jeant, dy voddagh shen ve cooilleenit va loarit liorish y phadeyr, gra,
English: 4 All this was done, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet, saying,

Manx: 5 Insh-jee da inneen Sion, Cur-my-ner, ta dty Ree cheet hood, dy imlee, as ny hoie er assyl, as er lhie sharragh assyl.
English: 5 Tell ye the daughter of Sion, Behold, thy King cometh unto thee, meek, and sitting upon an ass, and a colt the foal of an ass.

Manx: 6 As hie adsyn rumboo, as ren ad myr va Yeesey er noardaghey daue.
English: 6 And the disciples went, and did as Jesus commanded them,

Manx: 7 As hug ad lieu yn assyl as y lhie, as hug ad orroo nyn eaddagh, as hug ad eshyn ny hoie er yn eaddagh.
English: 7 And brought the ass, and the colt, and put on them their clothes, and they set him thereon.

Manx: 8 As ren earrooyn moarey dy leih skeylley nyn gharmadyn er y raad; yiare feallagh elley banglanyn jeh ny biljyn, as skeyl ad ad er y raad.
English: 8 And a very great multitude spread their garments in the way; others cut down branches from the trees, and strawed them in the way.

Manx: 9 As deie yn pobble hie roish, as adsyn haink ny yei, gra, Hosanna gys mac Ghavid, bannit ta eshyn ta cheet ayns ennym y Chiarn, Hosanna ayns yn yrjid.
English: 9 And the multitudes that went before, and that followed, cried, saying, Hosanna to the Son of David: Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord; Hosanna in the highest.

Manx: 10 As tra ve er jeet gys Jerusalem, va ooilley’n ard-valley jymmoosagh, gra, Quoi e shoh?
English: 10 And when he was come into Jerusalem, all the city was moved, saying, Who is this?

Manx: 11 Doort y pobble, Shoh Yeesey yn phadeyr, ta veih Nazareth ayns Galilee.
English: 11 And the multitude said, This is Jesus the prophet of Nazareth of Galilee.

Manx: 12 ¶ As hie Yeesey stiagh ayns chiamble Yee, as deiyr e magh ooilley adsyn va creck as kionnaghey ayns y chiamble, as hilg e harrish ny buird ocsyn va caghlaa argid, as ny stuill ocsyn va creck calmanyn.
English: 12 And Jesus went into the temple of God, and cast out all them that sold and bought in the temple, and overthrew the tables of the moneychangers, and the seats of them that sold doves,

Manx: 13 As doort e roo, Te scruit, Bee my hies enmyssit thie yn phadjer, agh ta shiuish er nianoo eh ny ooig dy vaarlee.
English: 13 And said unto them, It is written, My house shall be called the house of prayer; but ye have made it a den of thieves.

Manx: 14 As haink ny doal as ny croobee huggey gys y chiamble, as ren e ad y leihys.
English: 14 And the blind and the lame came to him in the temple; and he healed them.

Manx: 15 As tra honnick ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny scruderyn ny reddyn yyndyssagh ve dy yianoo, as y chloan gemagh ayns y chiamble, as gra, Hosanna gys mac Ghavid, va’d feer jymmoosagh,
English: 15 And when the chief priests and scribes saw the wonderful things that he did, and the children crying in the temple, and saying, Hosanna to the Son of David; they were sore displeased,

Manx: 16 As doort ad rish, Vel oo clashtyn cre ta’d shoh dy ghra? Doort Yeesey roo, Ta mee, nagh lhaih shiuish rieau, magh ass beill ooikanyn as cloan er y cheeagh t’ow er gheddyn moylley firrinagh?
English: 16 And said unto him, Hearest thou what these say? And Jesus saith unto them, Yea; have ye never read, Out of the mouth of babes and sucklings thou hast perfected praise?

Manx: 17 As daag e ad, as hie e magh ass yn ard-valley gys Bethany, as ghow e aight ayns shen.
English: 17 And he left them, and went out of the city into Bethany; and he lodged there.

Manx: 18 Nish ayns y voghrey, myr ve goll reesht gys yn ard-valley, ve accryssagh.
English: 18 Now in the morning as he returned into the city, he hungered.

Manx: 19 As tra honnick e billey-figgagh er y raad, haink e huggey, as cha dooar e nee erbee er, agh ynrycan duillagyn, as doort e rish, Nar aase mess erbee orts veih shoh magh er son dy bragh. As chelleeragh ren y billey figgagh fioghey ersooyl.
English: 19 And when he saw a fig tree in the way, he came to it, and found nothing thereon, but leaves only, and said unto it, Let no fruit grow on thee henceforward for ever. And presently the fig tree withered away.

Manx: 20 As tra honnick yn vooinjer va sheer geyrt er shoh, ghow ad yyndyss, gra, Cre cha leah as ta’n billey figgagh er fioghey ersooyl?
English: 20 And when the disciples saw it, they marvelled, saying, How soon is the fig tree withered away!

Manx: 21 Dreggyr Yeesey, as doort e roo, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, My vees credjue eu, as mannagh jean shiu dooteil, nee shiu cha nee ynrycan shoh, ta jeant rish y billey-figgagh, agh my jir shiu rish y slieau shoh, Bee er dty scughey, as er dty hilgey ayns y cheayn, bee eh er ny yianoo.
English: 21 Jesus answered and said unto them, Verily I say unto you, If ye have faith, and doubt not, ye shall not only do this which is done to the fig tree, but also if ye shall say unto this mountain, Be thou removed, and be thou cast into the sea; it shall be done.

Manx: 22 As dy chooilley nee, cre-erbee nee shiu y hirrey ayns padjer, my vees eh lesh credjue, nee shiu y gheddyn eh.
English: 22 And all things, whatsoever ye shall ask in prayer, believing, ye shall receive.

Manx: 23 ¶ As tra ve er jeet stiagh ayns y chiamble, haink ny ard-saggyrtyn as shanstyr yn pobble huggey, myr ve gynsaghey, gra, Cre’n phooar t’ayds dy yannoo ny reddyn shoh? as quoi hug yn phooar shoh dhyt?
English: 23 And when he was come into the temple, the chief priests and the elders of the people came unto him as he was teaching, and said, By what authority doest thou these things? and who gave thee this authority?

Manx: 24 As dreggyr Yeesey as doort e roo, Fênyms jiuish yn red, as my inshys shiu dou eh, inshyms myrgeddyn diuish, cre’n phooar t’aym dy yanoo ny reddyn shoh.
English: 24 And Jesus answered and said unto them, I also will ask you one thing, which if ye tell me, I in like wise will tell you by what authority I do these things.

Manx: 25 Bashtey Ean, cre woish ve? veih niau, ny veih deney? As loar ad nyn mast oc hene, gra, My jir mad veih niau, jir eshyn rooin, Cre’n fa eisht nagh chred shiu eh?
English: 25 The baptism of John, whence was it? from heaven, or of men? And they reasoned with themselves, saying, If we shall say, From heaven; he will say unto us, Why did ye not then believe him?

Manx: 26 Agh my jir mad, Veih deney; ta aggle ain roish y pobble; son ta dy chooilley ghooinney goall Ean son phadeyr.
English: 26 But if we shall say, Of men; we fear the people; for all hold John as a prophet.

Manx: 27 As dreggyr ad Yeesey, as doort ad, Cha vel shin able insh. As doort e roo, Cha-moo inshyms diuish, cre’n phooar t’aym, dy yanoo ny reddyn shoh.
English: 27 And they answered Jesus, and said, We cannot tell. And he said unto them, Neither tell I you by what authority I do these things.

Manx: 28 ¶ Agh cre ta shiu dy smooinaghtyn? Va dooinney dy row, as daa vac echey, as haink e gys y chied vac as doort e, Vac, gow as obbree jiu ayns my gharey-feeney.
English: 28 But what think ye? A certain man had two sons; and he came to the first, and said, Son, go work to day in my vineyard.

Manx: 29 Dreggyr eshyn, as doort e, cha jem: agh ny lurg shen ghow e arrys as hie e.
English: 29 He answered and said, I will not: but afterward he repented, and went.

Manx: 30 As haink e gys yn nah vac as loar e rish myrgeddyn. As dreggyr eshyn, as doort e, Hem, vainshter, as cha jagh e.
English: 30 And he came to the second, and said likewise. And he answered and said, I go, sir: and went not.

Manx: 31 Quoi jeu shoh nyn neesht ren aigney e ayrey? Doort adsyn rish, Yn chied vac. Doort Yeesey roo, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy jed ny publicanee as ny streebaghyn stiagh ayns reeriaght Yee, reuish.
English: 31 Whether of them twain did the will of his father? They say unto him, The first. Jesus saith unto them, Verily I say unto you, That the publicans and the harlots go into the kingdom of God before you.

Manx: 32 Son haink Ean hiuish ayns raad y chairys, as cha chred shiu eh: agh chred ny publicanee as ny streebaghyn e. As tra honnick shiuish shoh, cha ghow shiu arrys ny lurg shen, dy voddagh shiu e y chredjal.
English: 32 For John came unto you in the way of righteousness, and ye believed him not: but the publicans and the harlots believed him: and ye, when ye had seen it, repented not afterward, that ye might believe him.

Manx: 33 ¶ Easht-jee rish coraa dorraghey elley: Va far-thie dy row, ren garey-feeney y hoiaghey, as ren e cley y mish, as chley e press-feeney ayn, as hrog e toor, as hoie e e rish fir-hie, as hie e gys cheer foddey.
English: 33 Hear another parable: There was a certain householder, which planted a vineyard, and hedged it round about, and digged a winepress in it, and built a tower, and let it out to husbandmen, and went into a far country:

Manx: 34 As tra va earish ny mess tayrn er-gerrey, hug e e ir-mooinjerey gys ny fir-hie, dy voddagh ad geddyn jeh’n mess echey.
English: 34 And when the time of the fruit drew near, he sent his servants to the husbandmen, that they might receive the fruits of it.

Manx: 35 As ghow ny fir-hie e ir-mooinjerey, as woail ad fer, as var ad fer elley, as chlagh ad fer elley.
English: 35 And the husbandmen took his servants, and beat one, and killed another, and stoned another.

Manx: 36 Reeshtagh hug e magh shiarvaantyn elley ny sliee ny’n chied eallagh; as ghell ad roosyn er yn aght keddyn.
English: 36 Again, he sent other servants more than the first: and they did unto them likewise.

Manx: 37 Agh er jerrey ooilley hug e huc e vac, gra, Bee ad arrymagh da my vac.
English: 37 But last of all he sent unto them his son, saying, They will reverence my son.

Manx: 38 Agh tra honnick ny fir-hie yn mac, doort ad nyn mast oc hene, Shoh’n Eirey, tar-jee, lig dooin e [y] varroo, as bee’n eiraght echey lien hene.
English: 38 But when the husbandmen saw the son, they said among themselves, This is the heir; come, let us kill him, and let us seize on his inheritance.

Manx: 39 As ghow ad e, as hilg ad e magh ass y gharey-feeney, as var ad e.
English: 39 And they caught him, and cast him out of the vineyard, and slew him.

Manx: 40 Tra hig er-y-fa shen chiarn y gharey-feeney, cre nee e rish ny fir-hie shen?
English: 40 When the lord therefore of the vineyard cometh, what will he do unto those husbandmen?

Manx: 41 Doort adsyn rish, Stroie-ee e fegooish myghin ny drogh gheney shen, as soiee e yn garey-feeney rish fir-hie elley, livrey-ys ny messyn da, ayns nyn imbaghyn.
English: 41 They say unto him, He will miserably destroy those wicked men, and will let out his vineyard unto other husbandmen, which shall render him the fruits in their seasons.

Manx: 42 Doort Yeesey roo, Nagh lhaih shiuish rieau ayns goo Yee, Yn chlagh ren adsyn va troggal y thie y vee-lowal, ta’n chlagh cheddyn er jeet dy ve yn ard-chlagh chorneilagh: shoh janoo yn Chiarn, as te yyndyssagh ayns ny sooyllyn ainyn?
English: 42 Jesus saith unto them, Did ye never read in the scriptures, The stone which the builders rejected, the same is become the head of the corner: this is the Lord's doing, and it is marvellous in our eyes?

Manx: 43 Shen-y-fa ta mish gra riu, Dy bee reeriaght Yee er ny ghoall veuish, as er ny choyrt da ashoon, ymmyrkys magh yn mess echey.
English: 43 Therefore say I unto you, The kingdom of God shall be taken from you, and given to a nation bringing forth the fruits thereof.

Manx: 44 As quoi-erbee huittys er y chlagh shen, bee e er ny vroo: agh quoi-erbee huittys y chlagh shen er, nee ee cha meen as joan jeh.
English: 44 And whosoever shall fall on this stone shall be broken: but on whomsoever it shall fall, it will grind him to powder.

Manx: 45 As tra va ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny Phariseyn erreish ny coraaghyn dorraghey echey y chlashtyn, dennee ad dy nee jeusyn ve loart.
English: 45 And when the chief priests and Pharisees had heard his parables, they perceived that he spake of them.

Manx: 46 Agh tra va’d aignagh dy ghoall e, ghow ad aggle roish y pobble, er-yn-oyr dy row ad jeaghyn er dy ve ny adeyr.
English: 46 But when they sought to lay hands on him, they feared the multitude, because they took him for a prophet.

Manx: CAB. XXII.
English: Matthew Chapter 22

Manx: 1 As dreggyr Yeesey as loar e roo reesht liorish coraaghyn dorraghey, gra;
English: 1 And Jesus answered and spake unto them again by parables, and said,

Manx: 2 Ta reeriaght niau er ny holaghey gys ree dy row ren bannish son e vac,
English: 2 The kingdom of heaven is like unto a certain king, which made a marriage for his son,

Manx: 3 As hug e magh e harvaantyn dy emagh orroosyn va cuirt gys y vannish, as cha row ad aignagh dy heet.
English: 3 And sent forth his servants to call them that were bidden to the wedding: and they would not come.

Manx: 4 Reeshtagh hug e magh shiarvaantyn elley, gra, Abbyr-jee roosyn ta cuirt, Cur-my-ner ta mee er naarlaghey my yinnair: ta my ghew as my veiyn beiht marroo, as dy chooilley nee aarloo; tar-jee gys y vannish.
English: 4 Again, he sent forth other servants, saying, Tell them which are bidden, Behold, I have prepared my dinner: my oxen and myfatlings are killed, and all things are ready: come unto the marriage.

Manx: 5 Agh hoie adsyn beg jeh, as hie ad rumboo, fer gys e valley as fer elley gys y dellal echey:
English: 5 But they made light of it, and went their ways, one to his farm, another to his merchandise:

Manx: 6 As ghow yn chooid elley ny shiarvaantyn echey, as ghell ad dy roonagh roo, as var ad ad.
English: 6 And the remnant took his servants, and entreated them spitefully, and slew them.

Manx: 7 Agh tra cheayl y Ree jeh, ve jymmoosagh: as hug e magh e heshaghtyn-caggee, as stroie e ny dunveryn shen, as losht e yn ard-valley oc.
English: 7 But when the king heard thereof, he was wroth: and he sent forth his armies, and destroyed those murderers, and burned up their city.

Manx: 8 Eishtagh doort e rish e harvaantyn, Ta’n vannish aarloo, agh y vooinjer va cuirt, cha row ad feeu.
English: 8 Then saith he to his servants, The wedding is ready, but they which were bidden were not worthy.

Manx: 9 Gow-jee magh er-y-fa shen gys ny raadjin moarey, as chooilleen as yiow shiu, cuir-jee gys y vannish.
English: 9 Go ye therefore into the highways, and as many as ye shall find, bid to the marriage.

Manx: 10 As hie ny shiarvaantyn shen magh gys ny raadjin moarey, as ren ad chooilleen as haink nyn raad y haglym cooidjagh, chammah sie as mie, as va thie ny banshey er ny lieeney lesh goaldee.
English: 10 So those servants went out into the highways, and gathered together all as many as they found, both bad and good: and the wedding was furnished with guests.

Manx: 11 ¶ As tra haink y Ree stiagh dy akin ny goaldee, honnick e dooinney ayns shen nagh row garmad-poost er.
English: 11 And when the king came in to see the guests, he saw there a man which had not on a wedding garment:

Manx: 12 As doort e rish, Charrey, kys haink uss stiagh ayns shoh, fegooish garmad-poost? as cha row fockle echey dy ghra.
English: 12 And he saith unto him, Friend, how camest thou in hither not having a wedding garment? And he was speechless.

Manx: 13 Eisht doort y Ree rish ny shiarvaantyn, Kiangle-jee e laue as cass, as gow-jee e ersooyl, as tilg-jee e ayns y dorraghys sodjey mooie: ayns shen vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn.
English: 13 Then said the king to the servants, Bind him hand and foot, and take him away, and cast him into outer darkness; there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.

Manx: 14 Son ta ymmodee er nyn eam, agh beggan er nyn reih.
English: 14 For many are called, but few are chosen.

Manx: 15 ¶ Eishtagh hie ny Phariseyn, as hug ad nyn goyrle dy cheilley, kys oddagh [ad] e y hayrn ayns rybbey, liorish e ocklyn.
English: 15 Then went the Pharisees, and took counsel how they might entangle him in his talk.

Manx: 16 As hug ad magh huggey shiartance jeusyn va’d hene er nynsaghey, marish ny Herodianee, gra, Vainshter, ta fys ain dy vel oo firrinagh, as dy vel oo gynsaghey raad Yee ayns firrinys, cha-moo t’ow ayns imnea roish dooinney erbee: son cha vel oo soiaghey jeh persoon deney.
English: 16 And they sent out unto him their disciples with the Herodians, saying, Master, we know that thou art true, and teachest the way of God in truth, neither carest thou for any man: for thou regardest not the person of men.

Manx: 17 Insh dooin er-y-fa shen, cre t’ow dy smooinaght, Vel eh lowal keesh y choyrt da Cesar, mannagh vel?
English: 17 Tell us therefore, What thinkest thou? Is it lawful to give tribute unto Caesar, or not?

Manx: 18 Agh dennee Yeesey yn olkys oc, as doort e, Cre’n fa ta shiu dy my violaghey, chrauee foalsey?
English: 18 But Jesus perceived their wickedness, and said, Why tempt ye me, ye hypocrites?

Manx: 19 Jeagh-jee dou argid y cheesh, as hug ad lieu huggey ping.
English: 19 Shew me the tribute money. And they brought unto him a penny.

Manx: 20 As doort e roo, Quoi gys ta’n jalloo as y scrieu shoh bennalt?
English: 20 And he saith unto them, Whose is this image and superscription?

Manx: 21 Doort adsyn rish, gys Cesar. Eishtagh doort e roo, Eeck-jee er-y-fa shen da Cesar, ny reddyn ta lesh Cesar: as da Jee ny reddyn ta lesh Jee.
English: 21 They say unto him, Caesar's. Then saith he unto them, Render therefore unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's; and unto God the things that are God's.

Manx: 22 Tra cheayl ad shoh, ghow ad yyndyss, as daag ad e, as hie ad rumboo.
English: 22 When they had heard these words, they marvelled, and left him, and went their way.

Manx: 23 ¶ Yn laa keddyn haink huggey ny Sadduceyn, ta gra nagh vel irree-seose-reesht dy ve ayn, as dênee ad jeh,
English: 23 The same day came to him the Sadducees, which say that there is no resurrection, and asked him,

Manx: 24 Gra, Vainshter, ta Moses er ghra, my ta dooinney geddyn baase, fegooish cloan, dy vel e vraar dy phoosey’n ven echey, as dy hroggal seose sluight gys e vraar.
English: 24 Saying, Master, Moses said, If a man die, having no children, his brother shall marry his wife, and raise up seed unto his brother.

Manx: 25 Nish boyn dooinyn shiaght braaraghyn, as hooar y chied vraar, tra ve er phoosey ben, baase, fegooish cloan, as daag e e ven gys yn nah vraar.
English: 25 Now there were with us seven brethren: and the first, when he had married a wife, deceased, and, having no issue, left his wife unto his brother:

Manx: 26 As hooar yn nah vraar myrgeddyn baase as y tress gys y chiaghtoo.
English: 26 Likewise the second also, and the third, unto the seventh.

Manx: 27 As er jerrey ooilley hooar y ven baase myrgeddyn.
English: 27 And last of all the woman died also.

Manx: 28 Shen-y-fa ec yn irree-reesht, quoi jeh’n chiaght vees ee echey son ben, son vie son ben daue ooilley.
English: 28 Therefore in the resurrection whose wife shall she be of the seven? for they all had her.

Manx: 29 Dreggyr Yeesey as doort e roo, Ta shiu fo marranys, as cha vel toiggal eu jeh goo, ny jeh pooar Yee.
English: 29 Jesus answered and said unto them, Ye do err, not knowing the scriptures, nor the power of God.

Manx: 30 Son ec yn irree-reesht, cha vel ad poosey ny er nyn goyrt ayns poosey; agh ta’d myr ainlyn Yee t’ayns niau.
English: 30 For in the resurrection they neither marry, nor are given in marriage, but are as the angels of God in heaven.

Manx: 31 Agh my-chione irree-seose-reesht ny merriu, nagh vel shiu er lhaih shen va loarit riu liorish Jee, gra,
English: 31 But as touching the resurrection of the dead, have ye not read that which was spoken unto you by God, saying,

Manx: 32 Mish Jee Abraham, as Jee Isaac, as Jee Yacob? cha vel Jee ny Yee jeh ny merriu, agh jeh ny bio.
English: 32 I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob? God is not the God of the dead, but of the living.

Manx: 33 As tra cheayl yn pobble shoh, ghow ad yyndyss jeh’n ynsaghey echey.
English: 33 And when the multitude heard this, they were astonished at his doctrine.

Manx: 34 ¶ Agh tra va ny Phariseyn er chlashtyn, dy row e er chur er ny Sadduceyn ve nyn dost, va’d er nyn jaglym cooidjagh.
English: 34 But when the Pharisees had heard that he had put the Sadducees to silence, they were gathered together.

Manx: 35 As denee fer jeu va ny er-ynsee jeh’n leigh, question jeh, er chee y violaghey e, gra,
English: 35 Then one of them, which was a lawyer, asked him a question, tempting him, and saying,

Manx: 36 Vainshter, cre yn ard anney ayns y leigh?
English: 36 Master, which is the great commandment in the law?

Manx: 37 Doort Yeesey rish, Ver oo graih da’n Chiarn dty Yee, lesh ooilley dty chree, as lesh ooilley dt’annym, as lesh ooilley dt’aigney.
English: 37 Jesus said unto him, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind.

Manx: 38 Shoh yn chied as yn ard anney.
English: 38 This is the first and great commandment.

Manx: 39 As ta’n nah anney casley rish, Ver oo graih da dty naboo, myr dhyt hene.
English: 39 And the second is like unto it, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself.

Manx: 40 Yn daa anney shoh bun y leigh as ny phaderyn.
English: 40 On these two commandments hang all the law and the prophets.

Manx: 41 ¶ Choud as va ny Phariseyn er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, dênee Yeesey jeu,
English: 41 While the Pharisees were gathered together, Jesus asked them,

Manx: 42 Gra, Cre ta shiu dy smooinaght jeh Creest? quoi da mac e? Doort adsyn rish, Mac Ghavid.
English: 42 Saying, What think ye of Christ? whose son is he? They say unto him, The Son of David.

Manx: 43 Doort eshyn roo, Kys eishtagh dy vel David liorish y spyrryd genmys e ny Hiarn, gra,
English: 43 He saith unto them, How then doth David in spirit call him Lord, saying,

Manx: 44 Doort y Chiarn rish my Hiarn’s, Soie uss er my laue yesh, derrey verrym dty noidjyn son stoyl fo dty chassyn.
English: 44 The LORD said unto my Lord, Sit thou on my right hand, till I make thine enemies thy footstool?

Manx: 45 My ta David eisht genmys e ny Hiarn, kys te yn mac echey?
English: 45 If David then call him Lord, how is he his son?

Manx: 46 As cha row dooinney erbee able fockle dy ansoor y chur da, cha-moo by loys da dooinney erbee (veih’n laa shen magh) question erbee sodjey y enaght jeh.
English: 46 And no man was able to answer him a word, neither durst any manfrom that day forth ask him any more questions.

Manx: CAB. XXIII.
English: Matthew Chapter 23

Manx: 1 Eishtagh loar Yeesey rish y pobble, as roosyn va sheer geyrt er,
English: 1 Then spake Jesus to the multitude, and to his disciples,

Manx: 2 Gra, Ta ny scruderyn as ny Phariseyn nyn soie ayns stoyl Voses.
English: 2 Saying, The scribes and the Pharisees sit in Moses' seat:

Manx: 3 Ooilley er-y-fa shen cre-erbee nee ad y oardaghey div dy realley, freil-jee as jean-jee eh; agh ny jean-jee lurg ny obbraghyn oc: son ta’d gra, as cha vel ad janoo.
English: 3 All therefore whatsoever they bid you observe, that observe and do; but do not ye after their works: for they say, and do not.

Manx: 4 Son ta’d kiangley erraghyn tromey as doillee dy ve er nyn ymmyrkey, as dyn goyrt ad er geayltyn deney, agh cha gleashee adsyn hene ad lesh annane jeh ny meir oc.
English: 4 For they bind heavy burdens and grievous to be borne, and lay them on men's shoulders; but they themselves will not move them with one of their fingers.

Manx: 5 Agh ooilley nyn obbraghyn ta’d dy yanoo, dy ve er nyn vakin liorish deney: ta’d janoo liane ny [†††]phylactereeyn oc, as cur chemmallyn moarey er nyn gharmadyn.
English: 5 But all their works they do for to be seen of men: they make broad their phylacteries, and enlarge the borders of their garments,

Manx: 6 As shynney lieu ny ard ynnydyn-soie y ve oc ec cuirraghyn, as ny ard stuill ayns ny kialteenyn,
English: 6 And love the uppermost rooms at feasts, and the chief seats in the synagogues,

Manx: 7 As sleih dy vannaghey daue ayns ny margaghyn, as dy ve enmyssit liorish deney, Rabbi, Rabbi.
English: 7 And greetings in the markets, and to be called of men, Rabbi, Rabbi.

Manx: 8 Agh ny bee-jee shiuish enmyssit Rabbi: son ta yn vainshter eu, ta shen dy ghra, Creest; as ta shiuish ooilley nyn mraaraghyn.
English: 8 But be not ye called Rabbi: for one is your Master, even Christ; and all ye are brethren.

Manx: 9 As ny enmys-jee dooinney erbee yn ayr eu er y talloo, son ta yn er ny Ayr diu, ta ayns niau.
English: 9 And call no man your father upon the earth: for one is your Father, which is in heaven.

Manx: 10 Cha-moo bee-jee enmyssit mainshteryn, son ta yn er ny vainshter erriu, ta shen dy ghra, Creest.
English: 10 Neither be ye called masters: for one is your Master, even Christ.

Manx: 11 Agh y fer syrjey nyn mast eu, bee e diu ny harvaant.
English: 11 But he that is greatest among you shall be your servant.

Manx: 12 As quoi-erbee nee e hene y hoiaghey seose, bee e er ny injillaghey, as eshyn nee e hene y injillaghey, bee e er ny hoiaghey seose.
English: 12 And whosoever shall exalt himself shall be abased; and he that shall humble himself shall be exalted.

Manx: 13 ¶ Agh smerg diuish, scruderyn as Phariseyn, chrauee-foalsey; son ta shiu jeih seose reeriaght niau noi deney: son cha vel shiu goll stiagh shiu hene, as ta shiu dyn liettal adsyn ta aarloo dy gholl stiagh.
English: 13 But woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye shut up the kingdom of heaven against men: for ye neither go in yourselves, neither suffer ye them that are entering to go in.

Manx: 14 Smerg diu, scruderyn as Phariseyn, chrauee-foalsey; son ta shiu cur mow thiyn mraane treoghe, as liggey erriu dy bee shiu foddey ec padjer; shen-y-fa ta kerraghey strimmey nyn gouyr.
English: 14 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye devour widows' houses, and for a pretence make long prayer: therefore ye shall receive the greater damnation.

Manx: 15 Smerg diu, scruderyn as Phariseyn, chrauee-foalsey; son ta shiu goll my-geart keayn as talloo, dy hayrn yn yoarree gys y chredjue, as tra te er jyndaa hiu, ta shiu dy yanoo e ny liannoo dy nivrin ghaa wheesh as shiu hene.
English: 15 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye compass sea and land to make one proselyte, and when he is made, ye make him twofold more the child of hell than yourselves.

Manx: 16 Smerg diu, leedeilee doall, ta gra, Quoi-erbee looys liorish y chiamble, nagh vel eh veg: agh quoi-erbee looys liorish aer y chiamble, dy negin da coontey choyrt.
English: 16 Woe unto you, ye blind guides, which say, Whosoever shall swear by the temple, it is nothing; but whosoever shall swear by the gold of the temple, he is a debtor!

Manx: 17 Mee-cheealagh as doall, son quoi smoo ta dy ve soit jeh, yn aer, ny’n chiamble ta casherickey yn aer?
English: 17 Ye fools and blind: for whether is greater, the gold, or the temple that sanctifieth the gold?

Manx: 18 As quoi-erbee looys liorish yn altar, nagh vel eh veg: agh quoi-erbee looys liorish y gioot t’er yn altar, dy vel er coontey choyrt.
English: 18 And, Whosoever shall swear by the altar, it is nothing; but whosoever sweareth by the gift that is upon it, he is guilty.

Manx: 19 Mee-cheealagh as doall: son quoi smoo ta dy ve soit jeh, yn gioot, ny’n altar ta casherickey yn gioot?
English: 19 Ye fools and blind: for whether is greater, the gift, or the altar that sanctifieth the gift?

Manx: 20 Quoi-erbee er-y-fa shen looys liorish yn altar, te loo liorish yn altar hene, as liorish dy chooilley nee ta er.
English: 20 Whoso therefore shall swear by the altar, sweareth by it, and by all things thereon.

Manx: 21 As quoi-erbee looys liorish y chiamble, te loo liorish y chiamble as liorishyn ta vaghey ayn.
English: 21 And whoso shall swear by the temple, sweareth by it, and by him that dwelleth therein.

Manx: 22 As eshyn nee loo liorish niau, te loo liorish stoyl-reeoil Yee, as liorishyn ta ny hoie er.
English: 22 And he that shall swear by heaven, sweareth by the throne of God, and by him that sitteth thereon.

Manx: 23 Smerg diu, scruderyn as Phariseyn chrauee-foalsey; son ta shiu geeck jaghee jeh myndey, anise as cumin, as cha vel shiu er chooilleeney currymyn symmyrtsee jeh’n leigh, cairys, myghin, as firrinys: ad shoh lishagh shiu ve’r nianoo, fegooish y chooid elley y agail gyn janoo.
English: 23 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye pay tithe of mint and anise and cummin, and have omitted the weightier mattersof the law, judgment, mercy, and faith: these ought ye to have done, and not to leave the other undone.

Manx: 24 Leedeilee doall, ta carwhillag snemmey erriu, agh sluggee shiu camel.
English: 24 Ye blind guides, which strain at a gnat, and swallow a camel.

Manx: 25 Smerg diu, scruderyn as Phariseyn, chrauee-foalsey; son ta shiu glenney yn cappan as y claare er cheu-mooie, agh cheu-stie ta’d laane dy hranlaase as dy niau-heeltys.
English: 25 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye make clean the outside of the cup and of the platter, but within they are full of extortion and excess.

Manx: 26 Pharisee doall, glen hoshiaght shen ny ta cheu-stie jeh’n chappan as jeh’n chlaare, dy vod yn cheu-mooie oc ve glen myrgeddyn.
English: 26 Thou blind Pharisee, cleanse first that which is within the cup and platter, that the outside of them may be clean also.

Manx: 27 Smerg diu, scruderyn as Phariseyn, chrauee-foalsey; son ta shiu goll rish oaiaghyn t’er nyn niallaghey, ta dy jarroo jeaghyn aalin er cheu-mooie, agh cheu-stie ta’d laane dy chrauyn ny merriu, as jeh dy chooilley vroid.
English: 27 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye are like unto whited sepulchres, which indeed appear beautiful outward, but are within full of dead men's bones, and of all uncleanness.

Manx: 28 Shen myr ta shiuish neesht er cheu-mooie cairagh ayns shilley deney, agh cheu-stie ta shiu laane dy chraueeaght-oalsey as dy vee-chairys.
English: 28 Even so ye also outwardly appear righteous unto men, but within ye are full of hypocrisy and iniquity.

Manx: 29 Smerg diu, scruderyn as Phariseyn, chrauee-foalsey; er-y-fa dy vel shiu troggal oaiaghyn ny phaderyn, as soiaghey magh liaghtyn ny deney cairagh,
English: 29 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! because ye build the tombs of the prophets, and garnish the sepulchres of the righteous,

Manx: 30 As gra, Dy beagh shinyn er ve ayns laghyn nyn ayraghyn, cha beagh shin er ve nyn baarteasyn maroosyn ayns fuill ny phaderyn.
English: 30 And say, If we had been in the days of our fathers, we would not have been partakers with them in the blood of the prophets.

Manx: 31 Shen-y-fa ta shiu nyn venishyn diu hene, dy nee yn chloan ocsyn shiu ren ny phaderyn y varroo.
English: 31 Wherefore ye be witnesses unto yourselves, that ye are the children of them which killed the prophets.

Manx: 32 Lieen-jee seose eishtagh towse nyn ayraghyn.
English: 32 Fill ye up then the measure of your fathers.

Manx: 33 Shiuish ard-nieughyn, sheeloghe dy ard-nieughyn, kys oddys shiu kerraghey nivrin y scapail?
English: 33 Ye serpents, ye generation of vipers, how can ye escape the damnation of hell?

Manx: 34 ¶ Shen-y-fa, cur-my-ner, ta mish coyrt hiu phaderyn, as deney creeney, as scruderyn; as part jeu nee shiu y varroo as y chrossey, as part jeu nee shiu y chustey ayns ny kialteenyn eu, as tranlaase y yanoo orroo veih ard-valley gys ard-valley.
English: 34 Wherefore, behold, I send unto you prophets, and wise men, and scribes: and some of them ye shall kill and crucify; and some of them shall ye scourge in your synagogues, and persecute them from city to city:

Manx: 35 Dy vod ooilley yn uill chairagh hie er deartey er y talloo tuittym erriu, veih fuill Abel cairagh, gys fuill Zacharias, mac Barachias, e ren shiu y varroo eddyr y chiamble as yn altar.
English: 35 That upon you may come all the righteous blood shed upon the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel unto the blood of Zacharias son of Barachias, whom ye slew between the temple and the altar.

Manx: 36 Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy jig dy chooilley nee jeu shoh er y cheeloghe shoh.
English: 36 Verily I say unto you, All these things shall come upon this generation.

Manx: 37 Yerusalem, Yerusalem, ta marroo ny phaderyn, as dyn glaghey adsyn t’er nyn goyrt er chaghteraght hood, cre cha mennick as va mish booiaght ve’r haglym dty chloan cooidjagh, ’naght myr ta kiark goall stiagh e hein fo my skainyn, as cha nee yn aigney eu ve?
English: 37 O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, thou that killest the prophets, and stonest them which are sent unto thee, how often would I have gathered thy children together, even as a hen gathereth her chickens under her wings, and ye would not!

Manx: 38 Cur-my-ner, ta’n thie eu faagit diu tregit.
English: 38 Behold, your house is left unto you desolate.

Manx: 39 Son ta mee gra riu, Nagh vaik shiu mish ny yei shoh, derrey jir shiu, Bannit ta eshyn ta cheet ayns ennym y Chiarn.
English: 39 For I say unto you, Ye shall not see me henceforth, till ye shall say, Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord.

Manx: CAB. XXIV.
English: Matthew Chapter 24

Manx: 1 As hie Yeesey magh as jimmee e veih’n chiamble; as haink y vooinjer va sheer geyrt er huggey, dy chur shilley da jeh stooamit y chiamble.
English: 1 And Jesus went out, and departed from the temple: and his disciples came to him for to shew him the buildings of the temple.

Manx: 2 As doort Yeesey roo, Nagh vaik shiu ooilley ny reddyn shoh? Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, nagh bee faagit yn chlagh er clagh elley, nagh bee er ny hilgey sheese.
English: 2 And Jesus said unto them, See ye not all these things? verily I say unto you, There shall not be left here one stone upon another, that shall not be thrown down.

Manx: 3 ¶ As myr ve ny hoie er cronck ny Olivyn, haink y vooinjer va sheer geyrt er huggey er lieh, gra, Insh dooin cooin vees ny reddyn shoh? as cre’n cowrey vees jeh’n cheet ayd as jeh jerrey’n teihll?
English: 3 And as he sat upon the mount of Olives, the disciples came unto him privately, saying, Tell us, when shall these things be? and what shall be the sign of thy coming, and of the end of the world?

Manx: 4 As dreggyr Yeesey as doort e roo, Cur jee twoai nagh moll dooinney erbee shiu.
English: 4 And Jesus answered and said unto them, Take heed that no man deceive you.

Manx: 5 Son hig ymmodee ayns m’ennyms, gra, Mish Creest, as nee ad ymmodee y volley.
English: 5 For many shall come in my name, saying, I am Christ; and shall deceive many.

Manx: 6 As clinnee shiu jeh caggaghyn, as jeh imraaghyn dy chaggaghyn: jeagh nagh bee shiu seaghnit: son shegin da dy chooilley nee jeu shoh cheet gys kione, agh cha bee yn jerrey foast.
English: 6 And ye shall hear of wars and rumours of wars: see that ye be not troubled: for all these things must come to pass, but the end is not yet.

Manx: 7 Son irree ashoon noi ashoon as reeriaght noi reeriaght, as bee gennaghyn as crampyn as craaghyn tallooin ayns ymmodee ynnydyn.
English: 7 For nation shall rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom: and there shall be famines, and pestilences, and earthquakes, in divers places.

Manx: 8 Bee ooilley shoh toshiaght trimshey.
English: 8 All these are the beginning of sorrows.

Manx: 9 Eisht livrey-ee ad shiu seose dy ve seaghnit, as marree ad shiu: as bee feoh ec dy chooilley ashoon erriu, er coontey yn ennym ayms.
English: 9 Then shall they deliver you up to be afflicted, and shall kill you: and ye shall be hated of all nations for my name's sake.

Manx: 10 As eishtagh gowee ymmodee oyr dy huittym ayns peccah, as brah-ee ad, as ver ad feoh yn derrey yeh da’n jeh elley.
English: 10 And then shall many be offended, and shall betray one another, and shall hate one another.

Manx: 11 As nee ymmodee phaderyn foalsey girree seose, as ymmodee y volley.
English: 11 And many false prophets shall rise, and shall deceive many.

Manx: 12 As er-yn-oyr dy jean olkys bishaghey, nee graih ymmodee feyraghey.
English: 12 And because iniquity shall abound, the love of many shall wax cold.

Manx: 13 Agh bee eshyn nee tannaghtyn firrinagh gys y jerrey, er ny hauail.
English: 13 But he that shall endure unto the end, the same shall be saved.

Manx: 14 As bee sushtal yn reeriaght er ny phreacheil ayns ooilley’n seihl, son fenish da dy chooilley ashoon, as eisht nee yn jerrey cheet.
English: 14 And this gospel of the kingdom shall be preached in all the world for a witness unto all nations; and then shall the end come.

Manx: 15 Tra hee shiu er-y-fa shen eajeeid yn traartys, ta loarit jeh liorish Daniel yn phadeyr, ny hassoo ayns yn ynnyd casherick (eshyn ta lhaih, lig da tastey ghoall).
English: 15 When ye therefore shall see the abomination of desolation, spoken of by Daniel the prophet, stand in the holy place, (whoso readeth, let him understand:)

Manx: 16 Eishtagh lig dauesyn t’ayns Judea roie gys ny sleityn;
English: 16 Then let them which be in Judaea flee into the mountains:

Manx: 17 Eshyn t’er mullagh y thie, ny lig da cheet neose, dy ghoall nee erbee ass e hie.
English: 17 Let him which is on the housetop not come down to take any thing out of his house:

Manx: 18 As ny lig dasyn t’ayns y vagher chyndaa back, dy chur lesh e eaddagh.
English: 18 Neither let him which is in the field return back to take his clothes.

Manx: 19 As smerg dauesyn ta torragh, as dauesyn ta cur keeagh ayns ny laghyn shen.
English: 19 And woe unto them that are with child, and to them that give suck in those days!

Manx: 20 Agh guee-jee shiuish nagh bee yn roie eu er chea ayns y yeurey, ny er y doonaght.
English: 20 But pray ye that your flight be not in the winter, neither on the sabbath day:

Manx: 21 Son bee seaghyn moar ec y tra shen, leid as nagh row er dy hoshiaght y teihll gys yn earish shen, as leid as nagh bee arragh dy bragh.
English: 21 For then shall be great tribulation, such as was not since the beginning of the world to this time, no, nor ever shall be.

Manx: 22 As mannagh beagh ny laghyn shen dy leah ec kione, cha beagh feill erbee er ny hauail, agh er graih yn chloan reiht, bee ny laghyn shen dy leah ec kione.
English: 22 And except those days should be shortened, there should no flesh be saved: but for the elect's sake those days shall be shortened.

Manx: 23 Eisht my jir dooinney erbee riu, Cur-my-ner, ta Creest ayns shoh, ny ayns shid; ny creid-jee eh.
English: 23 Then if any man shall say unto you, Lo, here is Christ, or there; believe it not.

Manx: 24 Son nee Creestyn foalsey as phaderyn foalsey girree, as cowraghyn moarey as yyndyssyn y hoilshaghey, ayns wheesh as dy mollagh ad (dy beagh eh possible) yn eer chloan reiht.
English: 24 For there shall arise false Christs, and false prophets, and shall shew great signs and wonders; insomuch that, if it were possible, they shall deceive the very elect.

Manx: 25 Cur-my-ner, ta mish er ninsh diu rolaue.
English: 25 Behold, I have told you before.

Manx: 26 Shen-y-fa my jir ad riu, Te ayns yn aasagh, ny gow-jee magh: Cur-my-ner, te ayns ny shamyryn follit, ny creid-jee eh.
English: 26 Wherefore if they shall say unto you, Behold, he is in the desert; go not forth: behold, he is in the secret chambers; believe it not.

Manx: 27 Son myr ta’n tendeil cheet ass y shar, as cur soilshey choud as gys y sheear, myr shen myrgeddyn vees cheet yn mac dooinney.
English: 27 For as the lightning cometh out of the east, and shineth even unto the west; so shall also the coming of the Son of man be.

Manx: 28 Son raad erbee dy bee yn corp, ayns shen vees ny urlaghyn er nyn jaglym.
English: 28 For wheresoever the carcase is, there will the eagles be gathered together.

Manx: 29 ¶ Chelleeragh lurg seaghyn ny laghyn shen, aasee yn ghrian dorraghey, as cha der yn aist e soilshey, as tuittee rollagyn yn aer, as bee pooaraghyn yn aer er nyn graa.
English: 29 Immediately after the tribulation of those days shall the sun be darkened, and the moon shall not give her light, and the stars shall fall from heaven, and the powers of the heavens shall be shaken:

Manx: 30 As eishtagh bee cowrey jeh’n Mac dooinney er ny akin ayns yn aer: as ec y tra shen nee ooilley sheeloghyn y tallooin dobberan, as hee ad yn Mac dooinney cheet ayns bodjallyn yn aer, lesh pooar as gloyr woar.
English: 30 And then shall appear the sign of the Son of man in heaven: and then shall all the tribes of the earth mourn, and they shall see the Son of man coming in the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.

Manx: 31 As ver e magh e ainlyn lesh feiyr moar cayrn, as nee ad e chloan reiht y haglym cooidjagh veih ny kiare geayghyn, veih yn derrey chione jeh’n aer gys y chione elley.
English: 31 And he shall send his angels with a great sound of a trumpet, and they shall gather together his elect from the four winds, from one end of heaven to the other.

Manx: 32 Ynsee-jee eisht coraa dorraghey jeh’n billey figgagh: tra ta’n banglane echey foast oor, as cur magh duillagyn, ta fys eu dy vel y sourey er-gerrey.
English: 32 Now learn a parable of the fig tree; When his branch is yet tender, and putteth forth leaves, ye know that summer is nigh:

Manx: 33 Myr shen myrgeddyn shiuish, tra hee shiu ooilley ny reddyn shoh, toig-jee dy vel e er-gerrey, dy jarroo ec ny dorryssyn.
English: 33 So likewise ye, when ye shall see all these things, know that it is near, even at the doors.

Manx: 34 Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, roish my vow yn cheeloghe shoh baase, dy bee dy chooilley nee jeu shoh cooilleenit.
English: 34 Verily I say unto you, This generation shall not pass, till all these things be fulfilled.

Manx: 35 Nee niau as talloo cherraghtyn, agh my ghoans cha jean cherraghtyn.
English: 35 Heaven and earth shall pass away, but my words shall not pass away.

Manx: 36 ¶ Agh er y laa as yn oor shen, cha vel fys ec dooinney erbee, ny ec ainlyn niau, agh ec my Ayr ny lomarcan.
English: 36 But of that day and hour knoweth no man, no, not the angels of heaven, but my Father only.

Manx: 37 Agh myr va laghyn Noe, myr shen myrgeddyn vees cheet yn Mac dooinney.
English: 37 But as the days of Noe were, so shall also the coming of the Son of man be.

Manx: 38 Son myr ayns ny laghyn va roish y thooilley, va’d gee as giv, poosey as coyrt ayns poosey, derrey yn laa hie Noe stiagh ayns yn arg,
English: 38 For as in the days that were before the flood they were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, until the day that Noe entered into the ark,

Manx: 39 As cha dug ad tastey, derrey haink y thooilley as ghow eh ad ooilley ersooyl, myr shen myrgeddyn vees cheet yn Mac dooinney.
English: 39 And knew not until the flood came, and took them all away; so shall also the coming of the Son of man be.

Manx: 40 Shen y tra vees jees ayns y vagher, bee yn derrey yeh goit, as y jeh elley fagit.
English: 40 Then shall two be in the field; the one shall be taken, and the other left.

Manx: 41 Bee daa ven blieh ec y wyllin, yn derrey yeh goit as y jeh elley fagit.
English: 41 Two women shall be grinding at the mill; the one shall be taken, and the other left.

Manx: 42 ¶ Bee-jee er nyn dwoai er-y-fa shen, son cha vel fys eu er oor cheet nyn Jiarn.
English: 42 Watch therefore: for ye know not what hour your Lord doth come.

Manx: 43 Agh shoh toig-jee, dy beagh fys er ve ec maishter y thie cre’n oor veagh y maarlagh er jeet, veagh e er watchal, as cha beagh e er liggey da e hie y vrishey stiagh.
English: 43 But know this, that if the goodman of the house had known in what watch the thief would come, he would have watched, and would not have suffered his house to be broken up.

Manx: 44 Shen-y-fa bee-jee shiuish myrgeddyn aarloo, son ec leid yn oor as nagh vel shiu smooinaght er, hig yn Mac dooinney.
English: 44 Therefore be ye also ready: for in such an hour as ye think not the Son of man cometh.

Manx: 45 Quoi eisht yn chiarvaant firrinagh as creeney, ta e hiarn er nianoo ny er-reil er e hie, dy chur daue nyn meaghey ayns earish cooie?
English: 45 Who then is a faithful and wise servant, whom his lord hath made ruler over his household, to give them meat in due season?

Manx: 46 Bannit ta’n chiarvaant shen yiow e hiarn janoo myr shen ec y cheet echey.
English: 46 Blessed is that servant, whom his lord when he cometh shall find so doing.

Manx: 47 Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy livrey e dys y churrym echey ooilley e chooid.
English: 47 Verily I say unto you, That he shall make him ruler over all his goods.

Manx: 48 Agh my jir y drogh harvaant shen ayns e chree, Ta my hiarn liggey shiaghey yn cheet echey,
English: 48 But and if that evil servant shall say in his heart, My lord delayeth his coming;

Manx: 49 As toshiaght y yanoo dy woalley e heshaghyn-harvaant, as dy ee as dy iv marish y vooinjer veshtal:
English: 49 And shall begin to smite his fellowservants, and to eat and drink with the drunken;

Manx: 50 Hig chiarn y chiarvaant shen ec laa nagh bee e jeaghyn er y hon, as ayns oor nagh bee e twoaiagh jeh,
English: 50 The lord of that servant shall come in a day when he looketh not for him, and in an hour that he is not aware of,

Manx: 51 As giaree e e veih my chielley, as pointee e e chronney marish ny crauee-foalsey: ayns shen vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn.
English: 51 And shall cut him asunder, and appoint him his portion with the hypocrites: there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.

Manx: CAB. XXV.
English: Matthew Chapter 25

Manx: 1 Eisht bee reeriaght niau er ny holaghey gys jeih moidynyn, ghow ny lampyn oc, as hie magh quail y dooinney-poost.
English: 1 Then shall the kingdom of heaven be likened unto ten virgins, which took their lamps, and went forth to meet the bridegroom.

Manx: 2 As va queg jeu creeney as queg ommijagh.
English: 2 And five of them were wise, and five were foolish.

Manx: 3 Hug adsyn va ommijagh lieu ny lampyn oc, agh cha dug ad lieu ooil mâroo.
English: 3 They that were foolish took their lamps, and took no oil with them:

Manx: 4 Agh hug y vooinjer chreeney lieu ooil ayns ny siyn oc marish nyn lampyn.
English: 4 But the wise took oil in their vessels with their lamps.

Manx: 5 Choud as va’d feeau er y dooinney-poost, huit ad ooilley er saveenagh as cadley.
English: 5 While the bridegroom tarried, they all slumbered and slept.

Manx: 6 As ec main-uy va eam er ny choyrt, Cur-my-ner ta’n dooinney-poost cheet, gow-jee magh ny whail.
English: 6 And at midnight there was a cry made, Behold, the bridegroom cometh; go ye out to meet him.

Manx: 7 Eisht dirree ooilley ny moidynyn shen, as hooar ad aarloo nyn lampyn.
English: 7 Then all those virgins arose, and trimmed their lamps.

Manx: 8 As doort y vooinjer ommijagh roosyn va creeney, Cur-jee dooinyn jeh’n ooil eauish, son ta ny lampyn ain goll ass.
English: 8 And the foolish said unto the wise, Give us of your oil; for our lamps are gone out.

Manx: 9 Agh dreggyr y vooinjer chreeney, gra, Cha jean, er aggle nagh bee dy liooar ain dooin hene as diuish neesht, te ny share diu roie dys y vooinjer ta creck, as kionnaghey er nyn son hene.
English: 9 But the wise answered, saying, Not so; lest there be not enough for us and you: but go ye rather to them that sell, and buy for yourselves.

Manx: 10 As choud as va’d goll dy chionnaghey, haink y dooinney-poost, as hie yn vooinjer va aarloo stiagh marish gys y vannish, as va’n dorrys jeiht.
English: 10 And while they went to buy, the bridegroom came; and they that were ready went in with him to the marriage: and the door was shut.

Manx: 11 Ny lurg shen haink ny moidynyn elley, gra, Hiarn, Hiarn, fosle dooin.
English: 11 Afterward came also the other virgins, saying, Lord, Lord, open to us.

Manx: 12 Agh dreggyr eshyn as doort e, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, nagh voddym goall riu.
English: 12 But he answered and said, Verily I say unto you, I know you not.

Manx: 13 Bee-jee er nyn dwoai er-y-fa shen, son cha vel fys eu er y laa ny’n oor nee yn Mac dooinney cheet.
English: 13 Watch therefore, for ye know neither the day nor the hour wherein the Son of man cometh.

Manx: 14 ¶ Son te marragh dooinney va goll er troailt gys cheer foddey, deie er e harvaantyn as livrey daue e chooid:
English: 14 For the kingdom of heaven is as a man travelling into a far country, who called his own servants, and delivered unto them his goods.

Manx: 15 As da fer jeu, hug e queg talentyn, da fer elley jees, as da fer elley annane, da dy chooilley ghooinney lurg roshtin e hushtey, as chelleeragh ghow e e yurnah.
English: 15 And unto one he gave five talents, to another two, and to another one; to every man according to his several ability; and straightway took his journey.

Manx: 16 Eishtagh hie yn fer v’er gheddyn ny queg talentyn, as ren e dellal lieu, as chosne e queg talentyn elley.
English: 16 Then he that had received the five talents went and traded with the same, and made them other five talents.

Manx: 17 As myr shen eshyn v’er gheddyn jees, chosne eshyn myrgeddyn jees elley.
English: 17 And likewise he that had received two, he also gained other two.

Manx: 18 Agh y fer v’er gheddyn annane, hie e as chley e ayns y talloo, as dollee e argid e hiarn.
English: 18 But he that had received one went and digged in the earth, and hid his lord's money.

Manx: 19 Agh lurg foddey dy earish haink chiarn ny shiarvaantyn shen, as ren e coontey roo.
English: 19 After a long time the lord of those servants cometh, and reckoneth with them.

Manx: 20 As haink eshyn v’er gheddyn ny queg talentyn as hug e lesh queg talentyn elley, gra, Hiarn, livrey uss doos queg talentyn; cur-my-ner, ta mee er chosney queg talentyn elley mâroo.
English: 20 And so he that had received five talents came and brought other five talents, saying, Lord, thou deliveredst unto me five talents: behold, I have gained beside them five talents more.

Manx: 21 Doort e Hiarn rish, Smie t’ow er nianoo, harvaant vie as firrinagh, t’ow er ny ve firrinagh ayns y veggan, livreyms moarane gys dty churrym; gow stiagh gys boggey dty hiarn.
English: 21 His lord said unto him, Well done, thou good and faithful servant: thou hast been faithful over a few things, I will make thee ruler over many things: enter thou into the joy of thy lord.

Manx: 22 Haink eshyn myrgeddyn v’er gheddyn yn daa halent, as doort e, Hiarn, livrey uss doos daa halent: cur-my-ner, ta mee er chosney daa halent elley mâroo.
English: 22 He also that had received two talents came and said, Lord, thou deliveredst unto me two talents: behold, I have gained two other talents beside them.

Manx: 23 Doort e Hiarn rish, Smie t’ow er nianoo, harvaant vie as firrinagh, t’ow er ny ve firrinagh ayns y veggan, livreyms moarane gys dty churrym: gow stiagh gys boggey dty hiarn.
English: 23 His lord said unto him, Well done, good and faithful servant; thou hast been faithful over a few things, I will make thee ruler over many things: enter thou into the joy of thy lord.

Manx: 24 Agh y fer v’er gheddyn yn yn talent, haink e as doort e, Hiarn, va fys ayms dy nee dooinney creoi oo; buinn raad nagh ren oo cuirr, as chaglym raad nagh ren oo skeylley:
English: 24 Then he which had received the one talent came and said, Lord, I knew thee that thou art an hard man, reaping where thou hast not sown, and gathering where thou hast not strawed:

Manx: 25 As ghow mee aggle, as hie mee as dollee mee dty halent ayns y talloo; cur-my-ner, shen y raad ta dty chooid.
English: 25 And I was afraid, and went and hid thy talent in the earth: lo, there thou hast that is thine.

Manx: 26 Dreggyr e hiarn, as doort e rish, Harvaant vee-chairagh as niau-harroogh, va fys ayds, dy row mish buinn raad nagh ren mee cuirr, as chaglym raad nagh ren mee skeylley.
English: 26 His lord answered and said unto him, Thou wicked and slothful servant, thou knewest that I reap where I sowed not, and gather where I have not strawed:

Manx: 27 Lishagh oo er-y-fa shen ve’r chur my argid dauesyn ta janoo vondeish liorish argid y yeasaght, as eishtagh ec y cheet aym, oddin ve’r gheddyn my chooid hene lesh bishaghey.
English: 27 Thou oughtest therefore to have put my money to the exchangers, and then at my coming I should have received mine own with usury.

Manx: 28 Gow-jee er-y-fa shen yn talent veih, as cur-jee eh dasyn ta jeih talentyn echey.
English: 28 Take therefore the talent from him, and give it unto him which hath ten talents.

Manx: 29 Son da dy chooilley annane ta echey, vees er ny choyrt; as bee towse smoo echey: agh veihsyn nagh vel echey, vees er ny ghoall ersooyl shen ny ta echey.
English: 29 For unto every one that hath shall be given, and he shall have abundance: but from him that hath not shall be taken away even that which he hath.

Manx: 30 As tilg-jee yn chiarvaant niau-harroogh ayns y dorraghys sodjey mooie, ayns shen vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn.
English: 30 And cast ye the unprofitable servant into outer darkness: there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.

Manx: 31 ¶ Tra hig yn Mac dooinney ayns e ghloyr, as ooilley e ainlyn casherick marish, shen y tra hoiys e er stoyl-reeoil e ghloyr.
English: 31 When the Son of man shall come in his glory, and all the holy angels with him, then shall he sit upon the throne of his glory:

Manx: 32 As kiongoyrt rish vees dy chooilley ashoon er nyn jaglym, as scarree e ad veih my chielley, myr ta bochilley cur scarrey eddyr e chirree as ny goair.
English: 32 And before him shall be gathered all nations: and he shall separate them one from another, as a shepherd divideth his sheep from the goats:

Manx: 33 As soiee e ny kirree er e laue yesh, agh ny goair er e laue chiare.
English: 33 And he shall set the sheep on his right hand, but the goats on the left.

Manx: 34 Eisht jir y Ree roosyn er e laue yesh, Tar-jee, my chloan bannit jeh my Ayr, gow-jee myr eiraght yn reeriaght ta kiarit er nyn son eu, er dy hoshiaght y teihll.
English: 34 Then shall the King say unto them on his right hand, Come, ye blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world:

Manx: 35 Son va mee accryssagh, as hug shiu beaghey dou: va mee paagh as hug shiu jough dou: Va mee my yoarree, as ghow shiu stiagh mee:
English: 35 For I was an hungred, and ye gave me meat: I was thirsty, and ye gave me drink: I was a stranger, and ye took me in:

Manx: 36 Rooisht as ren shiu my choamrey: va mee ching, as haink shiu dy my yeaghyn: va mee ayns pryssoon, as haink shiu hym.
English: 36 Naked, and ye clothed me: I was sick, and ye visited me: I was in prison, and ye came unto me.

Manx: 37 Eishtagh nee yn chloan chairagh e y reggyrt, gra, Hiarn, cooin honnick shin oo accryssagh, as dy dug shinyn beaghey dhyt? ny paagh as dy dug shin jough dhyt?
English: 37 Then shall the righteous answer him, saying, Lord, when saw we thee an hungred, and fed thee? or thirsty, and gave thee drink?

Manx: 38 Cooin honnick shin oo dty yoarree, as dy ghow shin stiagh oo? ny rooisht, as dy ren shin dty choamrey?
English: 38 When saw we thee a stranger, and took thee in? or naked, and clothed thee?

Manx: 39 Ny cooin honnick shin oo ching, ny ayns pryssoon, as dy daink shin dy dty yeaghyn?
English: 39 Or when saw we thee sick, or in prison, and came unto thee?

Manx: 40 As freggyree yn Ree, as jir e roo, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, ayns wheesh as dy vel shiu er nianoo eh son y fer sloo jeu shoh my vraaraghyn, ta shiu er nianoo eh er my hons.
English: 40 And the King shall answer and say unto them, Verily I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of these my brethren, ye have done it unto me.

Manx: 41 Eishtagh jir e roosyn myrgeddyn er y laue chiare, Immee-jee voym chloan chursit gys yn aile dy bragh farraghtyn, ta kiarit son y drogh spyrryd as e ainlyn.
English: 41 Then shall he say also unto them on the left hand, Depart from me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire, prepared for the devil and his angels:

Manx: 42 Son va mee accryssagh, as cha dug shiu beaghey dou: Va mee paagh, as cha dug shiu jough dou.
English: 42 For I was an hungred, and ye gave me no meat: I was thirsty, and ye gave me no drink:

Manx: 43 Va mee my yoarree, as cha ghow shiu stiagh mee: rooisht, as cha ren shiu my choamrey: ching as ayns pryssoon, as cha daink shiu dy my yeaghyn.
English: 43 I was a stranger, and ye took me not in: naked, and ye clothed me not: sick, and in prison, and ye visited me not.

Manx: 44 Eisht nee adsyn myrgeddyn e y reggyrt, gra, Hiarn, cooin honnick shin oo accryssagh, ny paagh, ny dty yoarree, ny rooisht, ny ching, ny ayns pryssoon, as nagh chooin shin liat?
English: 44 Then shall they also answer him, saying, Lord, when saw we thee an hungred, or athirst, or a stranger, or naked, or sick, or in prison, and did not minister unto thee?
